White, middle-class ‚Äî so I must‚Äôve done something wrong?‚Äô said&nbspthe actorClick to followThe Independent CultureChris O‚ÄôDowd has said it is ‚Äúnot necessarily the case‚Äù that men have ‚Äúbeen the beneficiaries of the patriarchy‚Äù.The Bridesmaids star, who is set to appear in new BBC Two drama State of the Union, argued it is not only women who have been victims of the patriarchy and that we do not talk enough about how ‚Äúdamaging‚Äù it has been for men.‚ÄúOne part of the conversation about the changing state of man that we have not fully talked about yet is how damaging the patriarchy has been to men ‚Äì&nbspand it‚Äôs a minefield to even say that,‚Äù O‚ÄôDowd told The Times.&nbsp&nbsp‚ÄúYet the truth is, we haven‚Äôt benefited, necessarily, from thinking we are the providers. We have benefited hugely in other ways, but by thinking that we are there to protect, not to feel, and to be aggressive ‚Äî all those things that are beaten into us, or certainly me ‚Äî well, that hasn‚Äôt been healthy.‚Äù&nbspCreated with Sketch. Show all 30Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Pretty Woman certainly isn‚Äôt good, with an undercurrent of sleaze so disquieting that it‚Äôs no real surprise to learn it was once planned to be a gritty sex work drama that ended in tragedy. But Julia Roberts is pure star-is-born loveliness here, beloved by the camera and endlessly watchable as a result, her joyous pluck overshadowing the rest of the film‚Äôs murkier elements. That Disney, the studio behind the film, imagined its aspirational romcom hero as a rich businessman prowling Hollywood Boulevard for an escort is slightly maddening. That Pretty Woman somehow pulls it off‚Ä¶ even more so.There are a few moments in this high-school re-telling of George Bernard Shaw's Pygmalion ‚Äì in which, due to an elaborate bet, popular jock Zach (Freddie Prinze Jr) attempts to turn artsy nerd Laney Boggs (Rachael Leigh Cook) into the Prom Queen in six weeks ‚Äì that pull the rug out from under your feet. One such moment is when Laney finds out about Zach‚Äôs ploy. ‚ÄúAm I a bet? Am I a bet? Am I a f**king bet?‚Äù It is raw, painful, and elevates the film well above your average high-school romcom.Saving Face is both a romantic comedy about gay women, and a romantic comedy about two Asian-Americans, making it a double rarity in the genre. But its loveliest quality is its Manhattan earthiness, with its smoky streets, subway cars, fire escapes and cheap take-out places, all backdrops to the tentative relationship between surgeon Michelle Krusiec and dancer Lynn Chen.Partly because she was its last high-profile ‚Äúqueen‚Äù, Katherine Heigl has often been positioned as the actor that killed the romantic comedy. Which is unfair for a host of reasons, but specifically because both Knocked Up and 27 Dresses are such pristine examples of how great the romcom can still be. 27 Dresses is the more traditional of the pair, Heigl surrounded by stock characters (including Judy Greer once again cast as the sad-sack best friend, as she did in the Jennifer Lopez vehicle The Wedding Planner) and playing a brunette and therefore unlucky-in-love single New Yorker obsessed with weddings. But she is such a delightfully prickly and neurotic presence that it makes up for the film‚Äôs lesser qualities. We truly didn‚Äôt appreciate her at the time.530 26. Playing by Heart (1998)Not strictly a romantic comedy, buoyed as it is by serious drama involving everything from infidelity to AIDS, Playing by Heart is one of those talky, interconnected, Robert Altman-esque indies that dominated so much of American cinema in the Nineties. But the reason it‚Äôs here is because two of its many storylines feature lighter pairings that appear unlikely on paper but somehow become incredibly compelling and tender in execution. In one, Angelina Jolie and Ryan Phillippe meet at an LA bar and begin a romance in another, Gillian Anderson and Jon Stewart meet in a bookstore and begin dating. Both stories develop from there, with Sean Connery, Gena Rowlands, Ellen Burstyn and Madeleine Stowe among the recognisable faces orbiting them. But whatever the tone of each seemingly unrelated story, Playing by Heart is driven by a lovely, nostalgic sense of Los Angeles ennui at the end of the 20th century. No one has heard of this movie, and that‚Äôs a shame.Crazy Rich Asians may not have saved the romantic comedy last summer, as everyone predicted it would, but it remains a breathless celebration of the genre ‚Äì with a far-too-late-in-the-day but still wholly appreciated ersity at its centre. Constance Wu is the New York economics professor who discovers her apparently Average Joe fiancee is in fact Singapore royalty. What follows is a fish-out-of-water comedy that both indulges in its gorgeous opulence while never becoming too in awe of it. Michelle Yeoh is a standout, as a high society matriarch intimidatingly protective of her son.Few romantic comedies are more nakedly aspirational about big-city jobs, capitalism and the social power of being busy than One Fine Day, a mid-Nineties comedy about two single parents thrust together when their hectic schedules mean their children miss the class trip. There are far too many big cellphones here, but Michelle Pfeiffer and an ER-era George Clooney, as the squabbling pair at its centre, must surely rank as one of the most beautiful romantic comedy couples in recent memory.The first black, mainstream romantic comedy to possess the same aspirational sheen as their white counterparts, Boomerang is a lively battle-of-the-sexes comedy with Eddie Murphy as a powerful, womanising advertising executive spurned by his female doppelganger (Robin Givens). Grace Jones, Eartha Kitt and a young Halle Berry make for wonderful supporting players, but Boomerang‚Äôs secret weapon is Givens, who gives a performance with so much sparkiness that it‚Äôs enraging her volatile marriage to Mike Tyson overshadowed much of her acting career.Released a decade after Knocked Up, Seth Rogen‚Äôs adorable if occasionally bro-heavy first stab at the romcom, Long Shot bears the fruits of a man who has fixed some of his more regressive tendencies in the interim, producing something smarter, more sensitive and as interested in the feelings, neuroses and dialogue of his female co-star as he is to himself. He is a left-wing journalist recruited as a speechwriter for his former babysitter (Charlize Theron), who is now the US Secretary of State, and the pair forge an unshakable bond despite their wildly juxtaposed looks and vocations in life. Against the odds, Theron and Rogen are adorable together, while the film strikes a wonderful balance between sweetness and crudity. Long Shot may have flopped at the box office, but it‚Äôs the closest thing we‚Äôve had to a romcom classic in years.A perfect encapsulation of the Fifties, specifically the allure of the European jet-set, the idealised rat-a-tat-tat magic of big-city journalists, and the otherworldly regality of Audrey Hepburn, Roman Holiday is more of a time machine than most of the films here. But it‚Äôs also a true-blue classic, its ‚Äúfamous woman paired with ordinary man‚Äù plot inspiring everything from Notting Hill to The Lizzie McGuire Movie, and appropriately beloved as a result. There‚Äôs no Hilary Duff, obviously, but we won‚Äôt hold that against it.Forgetting Sarah Marshall is a bit like peering into a time capsule a reminder of a time when Russell Brand was (nearly) a Hollywood A-lister, and people believed Jason Segel could be a movie star. Of the post-Judd Apatow era of romantic comedies, this remains the best, however ‚Äì nicely balancing genuine sweetness and pathos (Mila Kunis is at the peak of her adorability as Segel‚Äôs love interest) with A-grade smut (Segel‚Äôs two full-frontal nude scenes remain hilariously shocking no matter how often you‚Äôve seen them). There‚Äôs also a puppet musical thrown in for good measure, which is never not welcome.Very loudly not fun but still something quietly extraordinary, The Break-Up is a romcom in reverse, with Jennifer Aniston and Vince Vaughn a couple at the end of their tether, who really shouldn‚Äôt be together and break up before the opening credits roll, and then muddle through the following 90 minutes figuring out what to do next. Aniston, always underrated as a movie star, is brilliantly magnetic, while Vaughn nicely downplays the manic energy that tends to suffocate his on-screen partners in his other roles. The film‚Äôs closer, a thoughtful, heartfelt celebration of having once loved someone regardless of how it all ended, is one of the bravest things an expensive studio romcom has done in recent decades.This satirical comedy set at a gay conversion camp has, quite clearly, a lot more than romance on its mind. But Jamie Babbit‚Äôs pink satin-coloured debut is most memorable for the brewing relationship between Clea DuVall‚Äôs Graham and Natasha Lyonne‚Äôs Megan. One is more in denial about their sexuality than the other, but they discover a mutual attraction while being held under the thumb of Cathy Moriarty‚Äôs conversion camp den mother ‚Äì who, it should be said, is somehow more of a drag queen than her colleague (played by a de-glammed RuPaul).1430 17. Four Weddings and a Funeral (1994)An underwritten female lead in the form of Andie MacDowell‚Äôs Carrie is the only fly in this wry, warm-hearted ointment. Revolving around a group of friends as they attend ‚Äì you guessed it ‚Äì four weddings and a funeral, this film marks the first of many collaborations between Hugh Grant and screenwriter Richard Curtis. We can probably all agree that the hopeless, stuttering Charlie should have ended up with his best friend Fiona (Kristin Scott-Thomas), but without his devastating indifference towards her, we would never have been blessed with one of the most magnanimous displays of unrequited love ever committed to film. The film‚Äôs worth your time, too, for its quietly progressive, heart-wrenching gay subplot.As much a ludicrously beautiful romcom as it is a nostalgic snapshot of the New York hip-hop scene at the turn of the 21st century, Brown Sugar casts Taye Diggs as an A&ampR executive for a record label and Sanaa Lathan, magnetised to so many black romcoms during this time, as the editor for XXL Magazine. Friends since childhood, they‚Äôre perfect for one another, but involved with other people (the similarly too-beautiful-for-words real-life couple Boris Kodjoe and Nicole Ari Parker). Queen Latifah and Mos Def are their perfectly cast best friends, just to add to the film‚Äôs early-Noughties charm.Most great romcoms are lucky enough to have one stand-out set piece that becomes embedded in the cultural landscape. Love Actually, the annually inescapable Christmas romcom behemoth from Richard Curtis, has about six or seven. Because it‚Äôs as famous as it is, Love Actually oddly has a tendency to be underrated, dismissed as too cutesy or misogynist, too awkwardly Blairite in its politics. And all of that, in fairness, is true. But it‚Äôs also a real classic of the form ‚Äì masterfully structured, endlessly watchable, and filled with familiar faces, sweet romances and heartache. It‚Äôs love in all its colours, often cringeworthy, sometimes monstrous, but always compelling to watch unfold.The secret masterpiece of the teen movie boom birthed in 1999, and truthfully one of the last of that era, Get Over It grabs so many elements from its subgenre predecessors (a Shakespearean undercurrent, sexually excitable animals and cameos from one-hit-wonders of the time) that it‚Äôs a wonder it‚Äôs so brilliant. Ben Foster is the recently-dumped high school basketball player who signs up for the school play (a musical version of A Midsummer Night‚Äôs Dream, naturally) to woo back his ex, only to fall for the adorable younger sister (Kirsten Dunst) of his best friend. Surrounding them are an array of recognisable faces, including Mila Kunis, Martin Short, Zoe Saldana and the literal Sisqo, while it features one of the finest Backstreet Boys-era boyband spoofs this side of Josie and the Pussycats.1830 13. 500 Days of Summer (2009)Beloved and loathed in equal measure, 500 Days of Summer is notorious among a certain generation of young people who grew up with Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Zooey Deschanel as quirky hipster pin-ups. And it‚Äôs likewise already something of a nostalgic masterpiece, beloved in first-year university film studies classes if then loudly rejected come graduation. There‚Äôs a lot to say about where its allegiances lie (is Deschanel‚Äôs Summer the movie‚Äôs villain, or its rational, realistic hero?), but that discussion also swallows up appreciation for what is for the most part a clever and funny comedy, and a movie that sincerely celebrates the conventions of the genre.It is funny in hindsight that there was such a stink over the casting of the Texan Renee Zellweger as the very English Bridget Jones. Because could you now imagine anyone else playing her? Her accent flawless (in that very prim, written-by-Richard-Curtis way), Zellweger similarly nails the spirited, neurotic melancholy that makes Bridget such a likable character, despite all the reasons we probably wouldn‚Äôt be able to stand her in reality. Like most of Curtis‚Äôs work, there is a lovely comfort to Bridget Jones, full as it is of slapstick, silly jumpers and new-Millennium London, featuring Colin Firth and Hugh Grant as ‚Äúadorable dork‚Äù and ‚Äúmagnificent bastard‚Äù, respectively, and a perfect Christmas finale. It‚Äôs truly one of the best of the genre.2030 11. 13 Going on 30 (2004)If every romantic comedy is a fantasy, then 13 Going on 30 is the ultimate fantasy romcom. As if she has watched too many herself, unhappy tween Jenna Rink wishes she could be 30, flirty and thriving, and wakes up one morning a high-powered magazine editor who looks like Jennifer Garner, and whose dorky neighbour has transformed into Mark Ruffalo. By turns incredibly touching and genuinely funny, 13 Going on 30 is brought to life by Garner, who plays the adult-bodied Jenna as a guileless spark plug of self-doubt, glee and determination. Also features none of the weird child molesting undertones of Big, which we should forever be thankful for.With Nora Ephron having slipped off this mortal coil, Nancy Meyers has more or less claimed her spot as Hollywood‚Äôs most dependable creator of sensitive and funny love stories set within designer kitchens. She has a largely great filmography, but Something‚Äôs Gotta Give remains her masterpiece. Diane Keaton and Jack Nicholson, both twinkling with lived-in Seventies-movie-star ease, play variations on their off-screen personas: her the exasperated neurotic, him the womanising letch. They‚Äôre thrown together in the Hamptons, stumble upon an unexpected attraction, and wrestle with what it all means. Keanu Reeves, as Keaton‚Äôs doctor and secondary love interest, is additionally a dream.There‚Äôs a great Arrested Development storyline in which Jason Bateman‚Äôs character doesn‚Äôt realise his love interest is mentally ill because she‚Äôs an eccentric British woman who looks like Charlize Theron. It may or may not have been inspired by Serendipity, the greatest romantic comedy ever made about a deranged and beautiful Englishwoman fixated on fate, chance and the cosmos. Kate Beckinsale and John Cusack meet by chance at Christmastime in New York, share a blissful evening together but then go their separate ways, Beckinsale sure that they must only date if the universe doesn‚Äôt otherwise intervene. Some time later, the pair are engaged to other people, but can‚Äôt shake their memories of that fateful Christmas Eve. Sweet, cosy and completely irresistible, Serendipity is a rare Christmas movieromantic comedy twofer and features two lovely performances at its centre. Absolutely bonkers, to be fair, but few films on this list aren‚Äôt.2330 8. 10 Things I Hate About You (1999)Gut-wrenching to watch in the wake of Heath Ledger‚Äôs death, but still one of the smartest, most convincingly heartwarming comedies of the last 20 years. Ledger and Julia Stiles are a pair of ‚Äúunappealing‚Äù high schoolers whose romance is engineered by Stiles‚Äôs younger sister, who can only date once she does. There is much to love here, from the film‚Äôs feminist politics (10 Things remains the holy grail of its era, in that regard) to its delightful supporting cast. But it‚Äôs Ledger and Stiles that burn the screen. Their chemistry is so authentic, charming and sexy that it‚Äôs almost uncomfortable to watch, with only the fact that they‚Äôre both ridiculously beautiful encouraging you never to turn away.Christmas has never been better presented in all its melancholy splendor than in Billy Wilder‚Äôs The Apartment, with two lonely souls both left dispirited by the holiday season yet finding each other hopelessly up in one another‚Äôs lives. Jack Lemmon is unsurprisingly wonderful as one half of the film‚Äôs central twosome, who loans out his apartment to his lecherous bosses so they can conduct their affairs, but it is Shirley Maclaine who provides the film with its heart ‚Äì she is bruised and brittle but eager for connection, and perfectly embodies the dizzying emotions of the winter season.Considering how many people adore My Best Friend‚Äôs Wedding, it‚Äôs always surprising to re-discover how monstrous its apparent heroine is. Julia Roberts has had better-received roles before and since, but there‚Äôs something fascinatingly daring about her work here, playing a single woman in love with her best friend and determined to destroy his wedding to a lovely if naive rich girl she has decided is evil. Cameron Diaz, as the bride-to-be, is an adorable revelation, Rupert Everett a hoot as Roberts‚Äôs then-radical ‚Äúgay best friend‚Äù. And the sheer darkness on display here, mixed with that funny and expensive Nineties-romcom sheen, makes it one of the most intriguing romcoms in history, and secretly one of its very best.You could argue that June and Joseph ‚Äì the dead, park bench couple ‚Äì have the most poignant love story in this film, but the one between world-famous movie star Anna (Julia Roberts) and very-much-not-famous bookshop owner Will (Hugh Grant at perhaps his most charming, foppish and floppy-haired) comes a close second.A fizzy treasure of a comedy that set the tone for much of what came after it, The Philadelphia Story casts a never-haughtier Katharine Hepburn as a feisty heiress stuck between three men: her dull fianc√© (John Howard), a prickly journalist (James Stewart) and the ex (Cary Grant) still hopelessly in love with her. Everyone speaks incredibly fast, romantic tribulations occur in elegant mansion estates and the film‚Äôs central trio embody an impossible movie-star glamour you can‚Äôt help but begin to miss as soon as they appear on screen.We know. Where you stand on Woody Allen‚Äôs work, particularly the stuff not revolving around the apparent inability of young women to resist the allure of a scrawny, bespectacled middle-aged neurotic, is one of those endless pop culture questions we‚Äôve all asked ourselves in recent years. If anything, though, watch Annie Hall for Diane Keaton at her most Diane Keatonish ‚Äì daffy, stylish and impossibly cool, she becomes so much more than an idealised fantasy figure through sheer force of will. Annie Hall, admittedly, is a masterpiece, if you can look past the obvious.While Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan‚Äôs most famous prior romcom collaboration, 1993‚Äôs Sleepless in Seattle, has a dark melancholy that makes it less immediately pleasurable to watch, their 1998 reunion in You‚Äôve Got Mail is the kind of movie built for comforting rewatches beneath a blanket. Or at least once every year at Christmas. The pair play sworn enemies waged in a war over the future of Ryan‚Äôs ludicrously serene independent book shop, but find love when interacting anonymously online. Despite the dial-up modems and archaic dialogue (‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs email?‚Äù everyone seems on the verge of asking), You‚Äôve Got Mail hasn‚Äôt aged poorly, proving how timeless chemistry-driven love stories between beautiful movie stars can be. There are far too many big cellphones here, but Michelle Pfeiffer and an ER-era George Clooney, as the squabbling pair at its centre, must surely rank as one of the most beautiful romantic comedy couples in recent memory.The first black, mainstream romantic comedy to possess the same aspirational sheen as their white counterparts, Boomerang is a lively battle-of-the-sexes comedy with Eddie Murphy as a powerful, womanising advertising executive spurned by his female doppelganger (Robin Givens). Grace Jones, Eartha Kitt and a young Halle Berry make for wonderful supporting players, but Boomerang‚Äôs secret weapon is Givens, who gives a performance with so much sparkiness that it‚Äôs enraging her volatile marriage to Mike Tyson overshadowed much of her acting career.Released a decade after Knocked Up, Seth Rogen‚Äôs adorable if occasionally bro-heavy first stab at the romcom, Long Shot bears the fruits of a man who has fixed some of his more regressive tendencies in the interim, producing something smarter, more sensitive and as interested in the feelings, neuroses and dialogue of his female co-star as he is to himself. He is a left-wing journalist recruited as a speechwriter for his former babysitter (Charlize Theron), who is now the US Secretary of State, and the pair forge an unshakable bond despite their wildly juxtaposed looks and vocations in life. Against the odds, Theron and Rogen are adorable together, while the film strikes a wonderful balance between sweetness and crudity. Long Shot may have flopped at the box office, but it‚Äôs the closest thing we‚Äôve had to a romcom classic in years.A perfect encapsulation of the Fifties, specifically the allure of the European jet-set, the idealised rat-a-tat-tat magic of big-city journalists, and the otherworldly regality of Audrey Hepburn, Roman Holiday is more of a time machine than most of the films here. But it‚Äôs also a true-blue classic, its ‚Äúfamous woman paired with ordinary man‚Äù plot inspiring everything from Notting Hill to The Lizzie McGuire Movie, and appropriately beloved as a result. There‚Äôs no Hilary Duff, obviously, but we won‚Äôt hold that against it.Forgetting Sarah Marshall is a bit like peering into a time capsule a reminder of a time when Russell Brand was (nearly) a Hollywood A-lister, and people believed Jason Segel could be a movie star. Of the post-Judd Apatow era of romantic comedies, this remains the best, however ‚Äì nicely balancing genuine sweetness and pathos (Mila Kunis is at the peak of her adorability as Segel‚Äôs love interest) with A-grade smut (Segel‚Äôs two full-frontal nude scenes remain hilariously shocking no matter how often you‚Äôve seen them). There‚Äôs also a puppet musical thrown in for good measure, which is never not welcome.Very loudly not fun but still something quietly extraordinary, The Break-Up is a romcom in reverse, with Jennifer Aniston and Vince Vaughn a couple at the end of their tether, who really shouldn‚Äôt be together and break up before the opening credits roll, and then muddle through the following 90 minutes figuring out what to do next. Aniston, always underrated as a movie star, is brilliantly magnetic, while Vaughn nicely downplays the manic energy that tends to suffocate his on-screen partners in his other roles. The film‚Äôs closer, a thoughtful, heartfelt celebration of having once loved someone regardless of how it all ended, is one of the bravest things an expensive studio romcom has done in recent decades.This satirical comedy set at a gay conversion camp has, quite clearly, a lot more than romance on its mind. But Jamie Babbit‚Äôs pink satin-coloured debut is most memorable for the brewing relationship between Clea DuVall‚Äôs Graham and Natasha Lyonne‚Äôs Megan. One is more in denial about their sexuality than the other, but they discover a mutual attraction while being held under the thumb of Cathy Moriarty‚Äôs conversion camp den mother ‚Äì who, it should be said, is somehow more of a drag queen than her colleague (played by a de-glammed RuPaul).1430 17. Four Weddings and a Funeral (1994)An underwritten female lead in the form of Andie MacDowell‚Äôs Carrie is the only fly in this wry, warm-hearted ointment. Revolving around a group of friends as they attend ‚Äì you guessed it ‚Äì four weddings and a funeral, this film marks the first of many collaborations between Hugh Grant and screenwriter Richard Curtis. We can probably all agree that the hopeless, stuttering Charlie should have ended up with his best friend Fiona (Kristin Scott-Thomas), but without his devastating indifference towards her, we would never have been blessed with one of the most magnanimous displays of unrequited love ever committed to film. The film‚Äôs worth your time, too, for its quietly progressive, heart-wrenching gay subplot.As much a ludicrously beautiful romcom as it is a nostalgic snapshot of the New York hip-hop scene at the turn of the 21st century, Brown Sugar casts Taye Diggs as an A&ampR executive for a record label and Sanaa Lathan, magnetised to so many black romcoms during this time, as the editor for XXL Magazine. Friends since childhood, they‚Äôre perfect for one another, but involved with other people (the similarly too-beautiful-for-words real-life couple Boris Kodjoe and Nicole Ari Parker). Queen Latifah and Mos Def are their perfectly cast best friends, just to add to the film‚Äôs early-Noughties charm.Most great romcoms are lucky enough to have one stand-out set piece that becomes embedded in the cultural landscape. Love Actually, the annually inescapable Christmas romcom behemoth from Richard Curtis, has about six or seven. Because it‚Äôs as famous as it is, Love Actually oddly has a tendency to be underrated, dismissed as too cutesy or misogynist, too awkwardly Blairite in its politics. And all of that, in fairness, is true. But it‚Äôs also a real classic of the form ‚Äì masterfully structured, endlessly watchable, and filled with familiar faces, sweet romances and heartache. It‚Äôs love in all its colours, often cringeworthy, sometimes monstrous, but always compelling to watch unfold.The secret masterpiece of the teen movie boom birthed in 1999, and truthfully one of the last of that era, Get Over It grabs so many elements from its subgenre predecessors (a Shakespearean undercurrent, sexually excitable animals and cameos from one-hit-wonders of the time) that it‚Äôs a wonder it‚Äôs so brilliant. Ben Foster is the recently-dumped high school basketball player who signs up for the school play (a musical version of A Midsummer Night‚Äôs Dream, naturally) to woo back his ex, only to fall for the adorable younger sister (Kirsten Dunst) of his best friend. Surrounding them are an array of recognisable faces, including Mila Kunis, Martin Short, Zoe Saldana and the literal Sisqo, while it features one of the finest Backstreet Boys-era boyband spoofs this side of Josie and the Pussycats.1830 13. 500 Days of Summer (2009)Beloved and loathed in equal measure, 500 Days of Summer is notorious among a certain generation of young people who grew up with Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Zooey Deschanel as quirky hipster pin-ups. And it‚Äôs likewise already something of a nostalgic masterpiece, beloved in first-year university film studies classes if then loudly rejected come graduation. There‚Äôs a lot to say about where its allegiances lie (is Deschanel‚Äôs Summer the movie‚Äôs villain, or its rational, realistic hero?), but that discussion also swallows up appreciation for what is for the most part a clever and funny comedy, and a movie that sincerely celebrates the conventions of the genre.It is funny in hindsight that there was such a stink over the casting of the Texan Renee Zellweger as the very English Bridget Jones. Because could you now imagine anyone else playing her? Her accent flawless (in that very prim, written-by-Richard-Curtis way), Zellweger similarly nails the spirited, neurotic melancholy that makes Bridget such a likable character, despite all the reasons we probably wouldn‚Äôt be able to stand her in reality. Like most of Curtis‚Äôs work, there is a lovely comfort to Bridget Jones, full as it is of slapstick, silly jumpers and new-Millennium London, featuring Colin Firth and Hugh Grant as ‚Äúadorable dork‚Äù and ‚Äúmagnificent bastard‚Äù, respectively, and a perfect Christmas finale. It‚Äôs truly one of the best of the genre.2030 11. 13 Going on 30 (2004)If every romantic comedy is a fantasy, then 13 Going on 30 is the ultimate fantasy romcom. As if she has watched too many herself, unhappy tween Jenna Rink wishes she could be 30, flirty and thriving, and wakes up one morning a high-powered magazine editor who looks like Jennifer Garner, and whose dorky neighbour has transformed into Mark Ruffalo. By turns incredibly touching and genuinely funny, 13 Going on 30 is brought to life by Garner, who plays the adult-bodied Jenna as a guileless spark plug of self-doubt, glee and determination. Also features none of the weird child molesting undertones of Big, which we should forever be thankful for.With Nora Ephron having slipped off this mortal coil, Nancy Meyers has more or less claimed her spot as Hollywood‚Äôs most dependable creator of sensitive and funny love stories set within designer kitchens. She has a largely great filmography, but Something‚Äôs Gotta Give remains her masterpiece. Diane Keaton and Jack Nicholson, both twinkling with lived-in Seventies-movie-star ease, play variations on their off-screen personas: her the exasperated neurotic, him the womanising letch. They‚Äôre thrown together in the Hamptons, stumble upon an unexpected attraction, and wrestle with what it all means. Keanu Reeves, as Keaton‚Äôs doctor and secondary love interest, is additionally a dream.There‚Äôs a great Arrested Development storyline in which Jason Bateman‚Äôs character doesn‚Äôt realise his love interest is mentally ill because she‚Äôs an eccentric British woman who looks like Charlize Theron. It may or may not have been inspired by Serendipity, the greatest romantic comedy ever made about a deranged and beautiful Englishwoman fixated on fate, chance and the cosmos. Kate Beckinsale and John Cusack meet by chance at Christmastime in New York, share a blissful evening together but then go their separate ways, Beckinsale sure that they must only date if the universe doesn‚Äôt otherwise intervene. Some time later, the pair are engaged to other people, but can‚Äôt shake their memories of that fateful Christmas Eve. Sweet, cosy and completely irresistible, Serendipity is a rare Christmas movieromantic comedy twofer and features two lovely performances at its centre. Absolutely bonkers, to be fair, but few films on this list aren‚Äôt.2330 8. 10 Things I Hate About You (1999)Gut-wrenching to watch in the wake of Heath Ledger‚Äôs death, but still one of the smartest, most convincingly heartwarming comedies of the last 20 years. Ledger and Julia Stiles are a pair of ‚Äúunappealing‚Äù high schoolers whose romance is engineered by Stiles‚Äôs younger sister, who can only date once she does. There is much to love here, from the film‚Äôs feminist politics (10 Things remains the holy grail of its era, in that regard) to its delightful supporting cast. But it‚Äôs Ledger and Stiles that burn the screen. Their chemistry is so authentic, charming and sexy that it‚Äôs almost uncomfortable to watch, with only the fact that they‚Äôre both ridiculously beautiful encouraging you never to turn away.Christmas has never been better presented in all its melancholy splendor than in Billy Wilder‚Äôs The Apartment, with two lonely souls both left dispirited by the holiday season yet finding each other hopelessly up in one another‚Äôs lives. Jack Lemmon is unsurprisingly wonderful as one half of the film‚Äôs central twosome, who loans out his apartment to his lecherous bosses so they can conduct their affairs, but it is Shirley Maclaine who provides the film with its heart ‚Äì she is bruised and brittle but eager for connection, and perfectly embodies the dizzying emotions of the winter season.Considering how many people adore My Best Friend‚Äôs Wedding, it‚Äôs always surprising to re-discover how monstrous its apparent heroine is. Julia Roberts has had better-received roles before and since, but there‚Äôs something fascinatingly daring about her work here, playing a single woman in love with her best friend and determined to destroy his wedding to a lovely if naive rich girl she has decided is evil. Cameron Diaz, as the bride-to-be, is an adorable revelation, Rupert Everett a hoot as Roberts‚Äôs then-radical ‚Äúgay best friend‚Äù. And the sheer darkness on display here, mixed with that funny and expensive Nineties-romcom sheen, makes it one of the most intriguing romcoms in history, and secretly one of its very best.You could argue that June and Joseph ‚Äì the dead, park bench couple ‚Äì have the most poignant love story in this film, but the one between world-famous movie star Anna (Julia Roberts) and very-much-not-famous bookshop owner Will (Hugh Grant at perhaps his most charming, foppish and floppy-haired) comes a close second.A fizzy treasure of a comedy that set the tone for much of what came after it, The Philadelphia Story casts a never-haughtier Katharine Hepburn as a feisty heiress stuck between three men: her dull fianc√© (John Howard), a prickly journalist (James Stewart) and the ex (Cary Grant) still hopelessly in love with her. Everyone speaks incredibly fast, romantic tribulations occur in elegant mansion estates and the film‚Äôs central trio embody an impossible movie-star glamour you can‚Äôt help but begin to miss as soon as they appear on screen.We know. Where you stand on Woody Allen‚Äôs work, particularly the stuff not revolving around the apparent inability of young women to resist the allure of a scrawny, bespectacled middle-aged neurotic, is one of those endless pop culture questions we‚Äôve all asked ourselves in recent years. If anything, though, watch Annie Hall for Diane Keaton at her most Diane Keatonish ‚Äì daffy, stylish and impossibly cool, she becomes so much more than an idealised fantasy figure through sheer force of will. Annie Hall, admittedly, is a masterpiece, if you can look past the obvious.While Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan‚Äôs most famous prior romcom collaboration, 1993‚Äôs Sleepless in Seattle, has a dark melancholy that makes it less immediately pleasurable to watch, their 1998 reunion in You‚Äôve Got Mail is the kind of movie built for comforting rewatches beneath a blanket. Or at least once every year at Christmas. The pair play sworn enemies waged in a war over the future of Ryan‚Äôs ludicrously serene independent book shop, but find love when interacting anonymously online. Despite the dial-up modems and archaic dialogue (‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs email?‚Äù everyone seems on the verge of asking), You‚Äôve Got Mail hasn‚Äôt aged poorly, proving how timeless chemistry-driven love stories between beautiful movie stars can be. And considering how brilliant Ryan is here, oscillating between tough strength and soft vulnerability, it is no surprise that she is still regarded as the star most associated with the genre.Truthfully, it couldn‚Äôt be anything else. Not only did When Harry Met Sally kickstart the romcom boom that dominated the Nineties, it also invented much of what we recognise today as clich√©s: from the sardonic best friend (played to perfection by Carrie Fisher), to the late-night phone calls while watching old movies, the ChristmasNew Year‚Äôs climax, the ‚Äúneurotic Jewish man‚Äù‚ÄúShiksa goddess woman‚Äù pairing at its centre, and the hilarious honesty when it comes to sex, never bettered than in the film‚Äôs iconic diner-orgasm scene. Romantic comedies are only clich√©d because When Harry Met Sally set such a glorious benchmark for why these films work in the modern era, assisted by Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan at their most golden, and a gorgeously structured script that leaps through time, written by the queen of the genre herself, Nora Ephron. Nothing will ever better this.He added: ‚ÄúAnd we are learning, as time goes on, to try to get through that. Thankfully, women are really helping. So it feels like men have been the beneficiaries of the patriarchy, but I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs necessarily the case.‚ÄúModern men mostly feel a lot of guilt for the fact that we‚Äôre men, even if, most of the time, I feel I haven‚Äôt done anything wrong. But I‚Äôm a man. White, middle-class ‚Äî so I must‚Äôve done something wrong? Being part of the patriarchy is a double-edged sword.‚ÄùO'Dowd&nbspwill star&nbspin&nbspState of the Union alongside Rosamund Pike. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsSmall investors who have put millions of pounds into TV presenter‚Äôs Happiness Architecture Beauty firms face ‚Äò97 per cent&nbsploss‚ÄôClick to followThe IndependentSmall investors who have sunk millions of pounds into the eco-friendly building business of Kevin McCloud, one of Britain‚Äôs favourite property show presenters, have been told they could lose up to 97 per cent of their money.&nbspMr McCloud, who has presented Channel 4‚Äôs Grand Designs for two decades, has promised investors returns of up to 9 per cent a year from his Happiness Architecture Beauty (HAB) companies.&nbspBut this week those who bought ¬£2.4m worth of HAB mini-bonds in January 2017 were informed they would lose 74 per cent of their money in the best case&nbspor 97 per cent in the worst.&nbspAnother group of investors, who poured ¬£1.9m into one of the HAB companies in 2013 and were promised idends of at least 5 per cent by the end of 2016, say they have not received a penny, with many feeling ‚Äúangry and betrayed‚Äù, according to .&nbspMr McCloud has said he went through ‚Äúa great deal of heartache and pain‚Äù as he tried to keep the main HAB company afloat amid project delays, ‚Äúsystemic faults‚Äù and large debts.‚ÄúI stand shoulder to shoulder with those who have lost money,‚Äù he told the newspaper. ‚ÄúI will of course do everything in my power to improve the current situation.‚ÄùCreated with Sketch. Show all 11Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Mr McCloud himself faces a demand for repayment from a restructuring company that has taken control of part of his empire.The Independent contacted HAB, requesting to speak to Mr McCloud, but did not hear back.&nbspIn March, the TV presenter issued a statement via the HAB website saying he is ‚Äúpersonally very sorry‚Äù for the delays and problems that affected a housing project in Kings Worthy near Winchester in Hampshire.&nbspAccording to a statement posted on the website just two weeks before, all apart from one home at the site had been sold. On Friday, the website still showed the remaining property ‚Äì a five-bedroom house ‚Äì as available for sale at a price of ¬£875,000.One HAB investor, who put in several thousand pounds, was quoted as saying: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm disappointed that what I saw as an idealistic project seems to be collapsing on a sour note, with the original directors having departed and investors seemingly left to bear the entire financial burden of a failed enterprise.‚ÄùOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. These so-called red giants then begin to lose their outer layers of material into space. More than half of such a star's mass can be shed in this manner, forming a shell of surrounding gas. At the same time, the star's core shrinks and grows hotter, emitting ultraviolet light that causes the expelled gases to glow. Two galaxies are seen interacting with one another. This pair of galaxies is known as UGC2369 and they are being drawn together by mutual gravitational attraction. title: africa visa uk elderly refused visit home office family racism
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsRefusals by Home Office to grant visit visas to elderly African relatives&nbspon basis of&nbspincome potentially unlawful and constitutes racism,&nbspimmigration lawyers sayClick to followThe IndependentA new toothbrush, a towel and a pile of neatly folded men‚Äôs jumpers sit on the bed in the spare room of Cecilia Tipa‚Äôs London home, lovingly placed there last month in preparation for her father‚Äôs visit to the UK. With them sit a pair of slippers&nbspand a straw hat ‚Äì items to prepare the 85-year-old Zimbabwean native&nbspfor the unpredictable British weather. Little did she know that a month later they would be gathering dust.The 60-year-old care home worker, who moved to Britain in 1999, had been looking forward to her father‚Äôs visit for months. Paul Tipa, an agriculture worker, has never left landlocked Zimbabwe, so it would be a chance to not only show him around London, but to take him to the seaside for the first time. Plus, he would be able to meet his&nbspthree-year-old,&nbspBritish-born&nbspgreat granddaughter, Ariella.Tipa, 85, had been looking forward to visiting his daughter Celia in the UK for the first timeCeclia&nbspsays she had ‚Äòeverything lined up‚Äô for her father‚Äôs visit, including clothing, slippers and toiletries‚ÄúI feel it‚Äôs so unfair. I felt part of the country, part of the culture. But this really proved to me that I don‚Äôt belong. I feel like an outsider,‚Äù says Cecilia.&nbsp‚ÄùI have worked so hard, contributed. I am law abiding. I just want him to come this one time. Now I‚Äôm going to work and I‚Äôm thinking, why am I doing this?‚ÄúHe is my father. He is the one who gave me the opportunity to be doing what I‚Äôm doing here. So he should have the right to visit me. He has no reason to overstay, especially in the cold here. He doesn‚Äôt like to be cold.Ariella&nbsp(left), for the first time‚ÄùCaring for elderly patients every day, other elderly fathers, and I am denied the right to see my own.‚ÄùCecilia is one of many African nationals who have lived and worked in the UK for decades, yet have been denied the right to have their elderly relatives visit them on the grounds that their family members do not have sufficient income in their home country.African people twice as likely to be refused UK visas, finds reportLawyers say&nbspthese refusals amount to a ‚Äúmisapplication‚Äù of the immigration rules and are&nbsppotentially unlawful, as the applicant‚Äôs own financial circumstances should be ‚Äúentirely irrelevant‚Äù if a third party ‚Äì such as their offspring in the UK ‚Äì has proven they can fund their visit. They also argue that citing their income and background in this way is a form of racism.It comes amid existing concern about&nbspracial bias in the visa system, after a report last month found that African people were more than twice as likely to be refused a UK visa as applicants from other parts of the world.In another case, Zimbabwean national Spiwe Jaji, 49, who was granted refugee status after coming to the UK in 2002, and has since worked as a healthcare assistant and now a nurse, says she feels&nbsp‚Äúbetrayed‚Äù by the UK after the Home Office refused her mother‚Äôs visit visa for a similar reason.Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailRettia Jaji, Spiwe‚Äôs mother, was told she couldn‚Äôt visit her daughter because she did not have enough income in her native ZimbabweAll of her family still live in her home country, and while she has made several visits to see them, it has been limited to two or three weeks due to her limited annual leave. Since her father past away three years ago, she has longed for her mother, 74-year-old Rettia Jaji, a farmer, to spend some time with her in England. &nbsp‚ÄúWhen I do go home I‚Äôm just rushing around seeing relatives. I don‚Äôt have time to stay with my mum properly. When my dad passed away I didn‚Äôt even have time to get closure,‚Äù says Spiwe.‚ÄúMy mum wouldn‚Äôt even want to stay for the full six months of the visa, let alone stay longer than that. She has got livestock. She has been in that village or more than 50 years. How can she abandon it? She goes to see her husband‚Äôs grave every day.passsed away three years ago, she has longed for her mother, 74-year-old Rettia Jaji, a farmer, to spend some time with her in England (Spiwe Jaji)‚ÄúI look after older people in this country with compassion and love. I see old ladies like my mum every day and take good care of them. But they won‚Äôt allow me to have my mum come and just stay with me for even just one or two months.‚ÄúIt feels like they are racially discriminating against Africans. I don‚Äôt think they are even assessing our applications, just denying them.‚ÄùIn a third case, London-based Nigerian national Elizabeth Ezeronye, who has been living and working in the UK for more than a decade and has British citizenship, says she feels&nbsp‚Äúlet down‚Äù by the UK government after her 64-year-old mother, Regina Chukwu, was denied a visit visa.Ezeronye and her husband Okezie, who both work with vulnerable people, were disappointed when the Home Office rejected Regina‚Äôs visa application to see her grandson for the first timeThe 34 year old, who works as a team leader in a care home, and whose husband Okezie is a support worker for vulnerable adults, says she wanted her mother to meet her eight-month-old baby, Charles, for the first time and help her to care for the child during the remainder of her maternity leave.Describing the moment she saw the refusal letter, she says: ‚ÄúI cried. We had provided a letter saying we have a two-bedroom flat and that she was going to stay with us. All the bank statements, pay slips, to prove it. It feels like they didn‚Äôt look at any of those documents.‚ÄúI work with vulnerable people, and the one thing we ask for, for my mum to visit, on all our expenses. Is it because she‚Äôs an African? Because she‚Äôs Nigerian? I don‚Äôt know. It feels racist and unjust.‚ÄúI treat vulnerable people everyday. It is my passion. I give back to the system. story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsSwift spoke out for LGBT+ equality, while Missy Elliot blew people away with a medley of some of her greatest hitsClick to followThe Independent CultureTaylor Swift and Lil Nas X led the winners as this year‚Äôs VMAs, with the night‚Äôs top honour going to Missy Elliot.The show took place in New Jersey for the first time, and featured an opening performance by&nbspSwift with two tracks from her album ‚ÄúLover‚Äù ‚Äì ‚ÄúYou Need to Calm Down‚Äù and an acoustic rendition of the title track.Swift took home video of the year for ‚ÄúYou Need to Calm Down‚Äù, which was released as an LGBT+ anthem during Pride month. In her acceptance speech, she spoke about the equality act: ‚ÄúBy voting for this video, you showed that you want a world where everyone is treated equally,‚Äù she said.Created with Sketch. Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.This song is sadly marred by the controversy that surrounded its accompanying video (its references to films such as Out of Africa drew accusations that it presented a ‚Äúwhite colonialist fantasy‚Äù.) The track itself is a dreamy, lush soundscape filled with breathless sighs and dramatic pauses that recall Swift‚Äôs fellow old Hollywood obsessive, Lana Del Rey.A pop-punk song! Swift is at her most energetic on a song that has more than a hint of Toni Basil‚Äôs ‚ÄúMickey‚Äù, from the hand-clapping beat to the distorted scuzz added to her vocals.420 17) ‚ÄúMiss Americana &amp the Heartbreak Prince‚ÄùSwift evokes Lana Del Rey again as she sings over a stuttery beat about two characters that could have been plucked right out of Hollywood‚Äôs golden age.520 16) ‚ÄúBack to December‚ÄùThis was a first for Swift, who apologises to an ex who treated her perfectly, while she perhaps didn‚Äôt value the relationship as much. It‚Äôs a noteworthy song simply to point out that Swift, who has faced multiple accusations of ‚Äúusing‚Äù her relationships to drag her ex-boyfriends, is more than capable of self-criticism.A Swift classic about star-crossed lovers, inspired by (what else?) Romeo and Juliet. This is a country pop song is a prime example of Swift‚Äôs skill as a story teller ‚Äì one who understands the power of a forbidden romance.720 14) ‚ÄúOut of the Woods‚Äù   Swift emulates Bruce Springsteen on this Eighties synth-pop ‚Äúget in the car and go‚Äù epic, which lasts not a second too long and ends so abruptly that it leaves you gasping to catch your breath.Photo by Mark MetcalfeGetty ImagesOne of the most underrated songs on Reputation has Swift embracing the role of villain after years of being accused of using men as a songwriting tool, along with the fallout from her feud with Kanye West and Kim Kardashian. If you can‚Äôt hear James Brown in the foot-stomping opener ‚ÄúMove on Up a Little Higher‚Äù by Brother Joe May, you‚Äôre not listening hard enough. The road to Motown from ‚ÄúLord, Lord, Lord‚Äù by Professor Alex Bradford is narrow indeed, but you could still take a side-turning and follow his ecstatic whoops straight to Little Richard, who borrowed them, and on to the Beatles who copied them from him. The swooping chord changes in James Cleveland‚Äôs ‚ÄúMy Soul Looks Back‚Äù are magnificent. All the irreplaceable soul voices, from Aretha Franklin to Bobby Womack, were steeped in gospel. This is a great place to hear where they came from. Companion album The Great Gospel Women is a marvel, too. CH‚ÄúA lot of the music scene is just a wanking, self-congratulatory boys club,‚Äù said this angel-voiced, transgender artist in 2012. Four years later, the seismic drums and radical ecofeminist agenda of Hopelessness shook that club‚Äôs crumbling foundations to dust. The horrors of drone warfare, paedophilia and global warming are held up to the bright lights in disconcertingly beautiful rage. HBKurt Cobain had one goal with In Utero: to pull Nirvana away from what he dubbed the ‚Äúcandy-ass‚Äù sound on Nevermind ‚Äì the album that had turned them into one of the biggest rock bands on the planet ‚Äì and take them back to punk-rock. He asked Pixies‚Äô producer Steve Albini to oversee production.  It didn‚Äôt exactly eschew commercial success upon release (it went on to sell 15m copies worldwide), but the heaviness the band felt as they recorded it bears down on the listener from the opening track. Disheartened by the media obsession with his personal life and the fans clamouring for the same old shit, In Utero is pure, undiluted rage. ‚ÄúGO AWAYYYYYYYYYYY‚Äù he screams on ‚ÄúScentless Apprentice‚Äù, capturing the essence of Patrick Suskind‚Äôs novel Perfume: Story of a Murderer and using it as a metaphor for his disgust at the music industry, and the press. ROCurtis Mayfield had been spinning golden soul music from doo-wop roots with The Impressions for more than a decade before releasing his first solo album, which contains some of his greatest songs. While some point to the 1972 Blaxploitation soundtrack Superfly as the definitive Mayfield album, Curtis is deeper and more joyous, its complex arrangements masterly. Mayfield‚Äôs sweet falsetto sings of Nixon‚Äôs bland reassurances over the fuzz-bass of ‚Äú(Don‚Äôt Worry) If There Is a Hell Below We‚Äôre All Going to Go‚Äù doleful horns give the politically conscious ‚ÄúWe the People Who Are Darker Than Blue‚Äù a profound emotional undertow ‚ÄúMove On Up‚Äù is simply one of the most exhilarating songs in pop. To spend time with Curtis is to be in the presence of a beautiful soul. CHBefore they went their own way, Fleetwood Mac decided to tell a story that would be the quintessential marker for American rock culture in the Seventies. As Lindsey Buckingham and Stevie Nicks tossed the charred remains of their relationship at one another on ‚ÄúDreams‚Äù and ‚ÄúGo Your Own Way‚Äù, the rest of the band conjured up the warm West Coast harmonies, the laid back California vibes of the rhythm section and the clear highs on ‚ÄúGold Dust Woman‚Äù, in such a way that Rumours would become the definitive sound of the era. At the time of its release, it was the fastest-selling LP of all time its success turned Fleetwood Mac into a cultural phenomenon. ROA virtual unknown to rock fans just a year before ‚Äì Hendrix used Are You Experienced? to assert himself as a guitar genius who could combine pop, blues, rock, R&ampB, funk and psychedelia in a way no other artist had before. That‚Äôs even without the essential contributions of drummer Mitch Mitchell and bassist Noel Redding, who handed Are You Experienced? the rhythmic bridge between jazz and rock. Few album openers are as exquisite as ‚ÄúPurple Haze‚Äù. Few tracks are as gratifying, as sexy, as the strut on ‚ÄúFoxy Lady‚Äù. And few songs come close to the existential bliss caused by ‚ÄúThe Wind Cries Mary‚Äù. Hendrix‚Äôs attack on the guitar contrasted against the more polished virtuosos in rock at the time ‚Äì yet it is his raw ferocity that we find ourselves coming back to. Few debuts have changed the course of rock music as Hendrix did with his. RODisco‚Äôs crowning glory is this album that Chic‚Äôs Nile Rodgers and Bernard Edwards made with Kathy Sledge and her sisters Debbie, Joni and Kim. Nile and ‚ÄôNard were at the peak of their powers, classic songs were pouring out of them ‚Äì We Are Family was released in the same year as the epochal ‚ÄúGood Times‚Äù by Chic ‚Äì and this album has four of them, ‚ÄúLost in Music‚Äù, ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs the Greatest Dancer‚Äù, ‚ÄúThinking of You‚Äù and the title track itself. Sister Sledge gave Rodgers a chance to work with warmer, gutsier vocals than the cool voices he used to give Chic records such laid-back style and the result is a floor-filling dance party, punctuated by mellow ballads. title: brexit us uk trade agreement chlorine washed chickens
story: IM Subscribe NowIM Subscribe NowCreated with Sketch.IM  Subscribe NowIM  Subscribe NowSubscribe NowSubscribe NowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsThe British government has promised not to skimp on food standards after leaving the EU ‚Äì but in the land of chlorinated chicken and hormone-fed beef, a post-Brexit trade deal still offers tantalising possibilities. Clark Mindock reports from IowaClick to followThe Independent USWith the UK facing an uncertain future as Boris Johnson marches the country towards a no-deal Brexit, American farmers can‚Äôt help but see something of a golden opportunity to bring their goods into a new market.While many US farmers have historically been turned away from trading with the UK over fears for the implications of practices such as washing chickens in chlorine, or the use of genetically modified crops, Britain‚Äôs impending exit from the EU has left some dreaming of a change to that situation.On a blistering summer day in Iowa, the idea is hard to avoid for farmers such as Leon Sheets, a pork producer from the northeast of the state who also maintains 600 acres of row crops.‚ÄúHey, let‚Äôs have the conversation. Let‚Äôs work out a deal,‚Äù Sheets says, emulating the kind of language one might expect from Donald Trump.When prodded further, Sheets acknowledges&nbspthat he hopes to see a post-Brexit trade deal that would allow for the introduction of products that have previously been off the table: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what the goal is ‚Äì no restrictions, so products can move freely back and forth.‚ÄùIt is an issue that has received backing from prominent American farming executives, even if some lip service has been given to having ‚Äúa conversation‚Äù about the US food standards that have worried some in the UK.Currently farming exports to Britain ‚Äì including wine, nuts and fruit ‚Äì are worth only about $1.8bn (¬£1.47bn), a fraction of the total overall sales of $133bn. That means there is potentially massive room for growth, under the right circumstances.With the US saying that the UK will be ‚Äúfirst in line‚Äù for a trade deal following Brexit, Zippy Duvall, the head of the American Farm Bureau, recently said that they are eagerly watching for ways to begin a trade partnership ‚Äì but that Britain had to accept US standards.PM warned US trade deal ‚Äòhighly unlikely‚Äô if Ireland has hard borderGovernment finally hands firms customs numbers for post-Brexit tradeTrump vows to continue China trade war even if recession hits USAs Britain seeks new trade deals, can we learn a lesson from Poldark?UK told to accept US food standards in any trade deal‚ÄúYou know, here in America we treat our water with chlorine,‚Äù Duvall, a poultry farmer himself, told the BBC.He claimed it was not a public health issue, saying: ‚ÄúSo there is no scientific basis that says that washing poultry with chlorine wash just to be safe of whatever pathogens might be on that chicken as it was prepared for the market should be taken away. If there was something wrong with it our federal inspection systems would not be allowing us to use that.‚ÄùOnly the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailChlorine-washed chicken was banned by the European Union in 1997, which virtually stopped all exports from the United States of US chicken meat, which is often treated with the antimicrobial wash.The wash itself, though, is not the issue.US farmers say Trump‚Äôs trade war is hurting, but they still back himThe EU‚Äôs Food Safety Authority said in 2005 that ‚Äúexposure to chlorite residues arising from treated poultry carcasses would be of no safety concern‚Äù. Chlorine-washed bagged salads are sold in the UK and other countries in the EU, for instance.But what is of concern is that relying on chlorine washes ‚Äì which proponents say makes harmful bacteria virtually undetectable ‚Äì at the end of the process allows farmers to keep unsanitary conditions for the chickens earlier on. And the wash could allow for crowded abattoirs where disease could theoretically spread with greater ease.While it is tricky to compare the rates of food-borne illnesses between two countries, two separate studies would suggest that the US experiences higher rates of salmonella infection. One British government study from 2014 found that there were roughly 55 salmonella infections per 100,000 people, when analysing 2009 data. A separate study of the US found a rate of 350 infections per 100,000 people, using data from 2002-08.When it comes to deaths, the US also reports higher numbers. While the US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention reports around 380 deaths a year due to food-borne salmonella, England and Wales had zero such deaths between 2006 and 2015, according to the most recently available data from Public Health England.Gail Soutar, the chief European Union exit and international trade adviser for the National Farmers Union (NFU), says there was a considerable level of anxiety that a hasty and chaotic Brexit could leave UK farmers competing against a flood of international goods coming in, and undermining their prices.Soutar says she is particularly concerned at the prospect of a no-deal outcome, and the impact that subsequently high tariffs on UK agricultural products could have. Farmers, she worries, could be threatened by a flood of new goods being brought in from the US, which could undermine efforts to honour European Union standards ‚Äì with the EU, for now, a much larger trading partner than the US.‚ÄúThere is a concern that we are going to see an increase of imports coming into the UK under a no-deal situation,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt remains absolutely key that we get a deal with the EU.‚ÄùUK politicians have at least paid lip service to the notion that standards will not be abandoned in pursuit of a deal, with former environment secretary Michael Gove telling an NFU conference in&nbspFebruary that they would not abandon those requirements ‚Äúin pursuit of trade deals‚Äù.But thousands of miles away in Iowa, the outcome of negotiations between the UK and EU are understandably less of a concern for farmers. Whereas UK farmers may be feeling some anxiety, American farmers are clearly sensing opportunity.Bill Tenneger, a pig producer in northwest Iowa, says&nbspDonald Trump‚Äôs trade war with China had been hurting farmers like him, but he thinks Mr Trump could potentially capitalise on a weak negotiating position following Brexit.But he adds&nbsphe hopes&nbspit would help British people out too: ‚ÄúI think trade agreements are good. Hey, it‚Äôs a small world. We‚Äôve all got to get along in the world. I‚Äôve travelled all over the world representing the pork industry.‚ÄúIn the end, I don‚Äôt care what culture you go to or you get embedded in, they all just want to feed their families and support their families and have the government leave them alone.‚ÄùShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users‚Äô, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: The elites talk about No Deal asit will be the worst thing to ever hit Blighty.It will be a calamity, they say. A disaster. Across the country, far from the political bubbles and ivory towers inhabited by these anti-Brexit hysterics, people are far more chilled out about the prospect of No Deal.You hear it in everyday ¬≠conversations: ‚ÄúIf the EU won‚Äôt give us a good deal, let‚Äôs leave without one.‚ÄùMOST READ IN OPINION" data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Remainers have no right to complain now that the tables have turned " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   Tm-comp-Beeflix.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTOBY YOUNG Its time for the BBC to become Beebflix and get rid of licence fee completely " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   RR-COMP-page.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentALLY ROSS Cs Celebs Go Dating may be cheap trash, but its also strangely brilliant " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   CM-COMPOSITE-ALLY-ROSS.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentALLY ROSS Gemma Collins show is the same every week - she stuffs her face  shouts orders " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   TM-comp-Epstein.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Andrew must front up about Epstein relationship ‚Äî The Firms rep is at stake " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT-e.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTREVOR KAVANAGH BoJo cannot risk being side-tracked and humiliated by bullying Brussels You see it on Question Time when the audience applauds a list who says we should walk away from the EUit keeps messing us about. And you see it in opinion polls, too.Much to the horror of the Brexit-bashing elites, polls show that ordinary people do not think No Deal will be the end of the world as we know it.A recent Opinium poll asked people what we should doBoris Johnson fails to wring concessions from the EU and to change the Withdrawal Agreement to make it more palatable to MPs.A whopping  per cent said we should go ahead with Brexit on October  ‚Äî Boris‚Äôs ¬≠promised exit day ‚Äî evenwe don‚Äôt have a deal.Just  per cent said we should cancel Brexit altogether and  per cent said we should continue with negotiations.This echoes a YouGov poll from a few months ago. It asked what we should dothe EU refused to grant an extension to talks on the exit deal.Forty-four per cent said we should say adios without a deal. Forty-two per cent said we should revoke Brexit and stay bound to Brussels.This is all incredibly revealing. No, it does not suggest millions of us are reckless and crazy and hell-bent on jumping off the ‚Äúclf edge‚Äù.Most Brits, including Boris himself, would prefer to leave with a deal,a good one can be struck.No, what the polls show is that there is only so much baloney from the EU that we are willing to take.If Eurocrats carry on behaving stubbornly and arrogantly by refusing to reopen talks about the Withdrawal Agreement, then we should show some self-respect and walk away ‚Äî that is what people are saying.This captures one of the key ides between the elites and ordinary people today. The political and media classes dread No Deal because they have lost faith in Britain.They view the UK as a tiny, pathetic island that could never possibly cope outside of the EU.They think we need to be looked after by the apparently caring, maternal figure of the Brussels bureaucracy. Andwe do the political equivalent of cutting the apron strings, we will be doomed, apparently.In the rest of the country, meanwhile, people have far more faith in the nation.They believe we are more than capable of being a sovereign, independent country that strikes its own trade deals and writes its own laws.They see the country not as a useless little island, but as a plucky, resourceful nation that should reach out to the world without being beholden to any of it.The ide over No Deal reveals how much disagreement there is between the political elites and the people today.It is hard to remember a time when the chasm between Us and Them was as wide as it is right now.The th Century Prime ¬≠Minister Benjamin Disraeli once said the UK feels like ‚Äútwo nations‚Äù. In one nation there are the posh and well-educated, and in the other there are ¬≠ordinary working people.These ‚Äútwo nations‚Äù have entirely dferent ‚Äúhabits, thoughts, and feelings‚Äù, he wrote. It is asthey are ‚Äúinhabitants of dferent planets‚Äù.It feels like that again today. On the planet of the Remainer elites, No Deal will be terrible, Boris is the worst PM ever, and anyone who ¬≠disagrees is probably a racist.But on the planet inhabited by the rest of us, No Deal will be fine. And support for the Boris-led Conservative Party is rising. Surging, in fact.The latest Britain Elects ¬≠opinion poll shows that  per cent of us would vote for the Tories, compared with just  per cent for Labour.From their increasingly isolated planet, the chattering classes rage against No Deal, denounce Boris as ‚Äúfar Right‚Äù, and bad-mouth Britain.But their shrill cries make no impact on our planet. In our more sane world, we still want Brexit to happen and we think Britain is a good, decent, capable country.The elites should come over to our planet. story: Rory McCarty, , responded to reports of an infestation before witnessing the worst case of bed bugs ever at a house in Maryland, US.Rory, who has worked in pest control for  years, was horried to find an endless amount of bed bugs scurrying all over the bed and mattress.The pest controller shared a video of his gruesome discovery, which shows Rorys colleague lting up the mattress to reveal hundreds of insects crawling across the bedding.In the video, Rory was heard telling his colleagues not to put their pants against the mattress, before telling them to lt the bed carefully and keep a safe distance.Rory said: Oh my goodness. story: But I‚Äôm afraid it isn‚Äôt enough ‚Äî not nearly enough.If the BBC is to continue to be funded by the taxpayer, it must slash costs and scrap the licence fee altogether.This year has been an annus horribilis for the Beeb.Its dficulties began in February with the launch of BBC Scotland, a new channel north of the border with an annual budget of ¬£million.Unfortunately, very few people have been tuning in.BBC Scotland‚Äôs flagship current affairs programme, The Nine, is watched by just , people ‚Äî even fewer than Alex Salmond‚Äôs weekly chat show on Russia Today.But it‚Äôs more than tune in to The Seven, BBC Scotland‚Äôs nightly news show.The Seven is one of  programmes on the new channel that at certain points between February  and June  had zero viewers, according to the British Audience Research Board.That‚Äôs quite an achievement, given that Scotland has a population of five-and-a-half million and the average viewer north of the border spends three hours and  minutes a day watching television.Then, in June, the BBC announced it would be breaking its promise to provide free TV licences to the over-s.The Director-General, Tony Hall, agreed to take on that responsibility from the Government as a condition of the BBC‚Äôs Royal Charter being renewed in .According to the terms of the deal, the Corporation would be able to put up the licence fee each year and, in , it would fund free TV licences for pensioners from June , .The Beeb‚Äôs Royal Charter was duly renewed and the licence fee went up in , in  and again in .Yet apparently it can no longer afford to keep its pledge. From next June, only those over-s on pension credit will be eligible for free TV licences ‚Äî just one in five people.That means .million pensioners, including more than , service veterans, will have to find ¬£. a yearthey want to continue watching television.To add insult to injury, the BBC then disclosed how much money it is paying its stars.Anti-Brexit activist and Match Of The Day presenter Gary Lineker is on ¬£,,, Graham Norton is on ¬£, and Claudia Winkleman is on ¬£,.Lineker‚Äôs salary alone would pay for more than , TV licences.Asthat wasn‚Äôt bad enough, earlier this month the Beeb said it intends to spend ¬£million on an advertising campaign to attract young viewers and listeners.That‚Äôs more than the annual budget of Radio .It‚Äôs particularly high, given that the BBC can advertise on its own TV channels and radio stations for free. Apparently, the money is going to be spent on targeting young people on social media.Are we really supposed to believe that the BBC cannot afford to pay for pensioners‚Äô TV licences, but can fritter away ¬£million on Facebook adverts There‚Äôs almost nothing Auntie won‚Äôt stoop to in its desperate pursuit of the ‚Äúyoof‚Äù audience.It has earmarked ¬£million to promote its new Sounds app ‚Äî including spending ¬£, to transform the London Eye into the ‚ÄúLondon Ear‚Äù ‚Äî and poured money into a series of increasingly tawdry podcasts, such as Gemma Collins talking about her le, a reality-show round-up called Reality Tea, and Unexpected Fluids, in which teenagers tell embarrassing ¬≠stories about when sex goes wrong.It‚Äôs all a far cry from Lord Reith‚Äôs mission to explain.No doubt the BBC is concerned about how few young people it manages to attract ‚Äî and this manests itself in other ways, too, such as its massive investment in apps and podcasts and its extensive online coverage of ITV‚Äôs Love Island.Last year, Ofcom revealed that  to -year-olds are spending an average of an hour and  minutes per day consuming BBC content, which is about half the amount for all age groups.Even more worrying for the Corporation, one in eight young Brits consumes no BBC content at all. Why should they fork out ¬£. for the licence fee, particularly as many of them will already be paying for subscription TV services The fundamental problem the Beeb faces is that consumers are becomingly increasingly accustomed to paying for the TV content they want to watch and resent having to pay a mandatory flat tax to a single provider.The equivalent would beeveryone who owns a phone, tablet or laptop had to pay ¬£. for an ‚Äúinternet licence‚Äù to fund Apple‚Äôs iTunes, regardless of whether or not they use the service.It‚Äôs time to do away with the licence fee ‚Äî for everyone, not just the over-s.That would mean stripping down the state-funded parts of the BBC to its core news and current affairs output and funding that out of general taxation.It should sell off its profitable private isions ‚Äî such as BBC Studios, which has annual revenues of more than ¬£billion ‚Äî and plough the money into creating its own subscription service.With its global brand recognition and unrivalled back catalogue, not to mention its reputation for high-quality drama, the BBC could easily compete with commercial providers such as Netflix and Amazon Prime.Promising to scrap the licence fee would surely be a vote-winner for Boris Johnson.No s, no buts. title: big cat yorkshire dog photograher
story: John Pearson, , was taking pictures at St Aidans Nature Reserve near Leeds when the mysterious creature caught his eye.He said: Im an amateur photographer so I just go out taking photos, I have done for a while.When I saw it, I didnt think it was a cat - it looked too big, and I was quite far away.  days after the original administration was dissolved.Noises from Tory Brexiteers have suggested that Boris could ignore a vote of no confidence ‚Äì in an effort to push brought Brexit by the story: NewsExpert says hot water bottle trick will help you sleep in hot weatherThis August Bank Holiday looks set to be the hottest on record, with the Met Office issuing a level three heatwave warningShareCommentsByJane LavenderAssistant EditorChris Kitching:,  AUG NewsA hot water bottle could be the key for getting a good nights sleep "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Those most in danger are the elderly, people with underlying health conditions and babies and very young children.The level three heatwave ¬†warning is in place for the East of England, where temperatures will likely hit -C between Saturday and Monday amid a number of big events, including Ed Sheeranaposs homecoming gigs in Ipswich, Suffolk. ¬†The rest of England is under level twoor level one status, while no critical weather warnings have been issued for Northern Ireland, Scotland or Wales.And with the temperatures reaching record breaking levels this weekend people will be finding it hard to sleep in the heatwave. However, one expert has come up with an unexpected tip to help people nod off when temperatures are soaring. Believe it or not, a hot water bottle could be just the thing you need to kelp you get a good nightaposs sleep. Expert James Wilson, AKA The Sleep Geek,explained: It can take us a bit of time to get used to the warmer weather at bedtime, particularlywe are staying in a place that doesn‚Äôt have air conditioning.  ¬† It is important that we feel cooler before bed as one of the important parts of the process our body‚Äôs go through to sleep is a drop in core temperature. If we are struggling to sleep because of the heat a great tip is to trick your body into thinking its core temperature has dropped. To do this you can either have¬† a lukewarm shower or alternatively, and this is a particular favourite of mine, fill a hot water bottle with lukewarm water and place your feet on it about half an hour before bed. The lukewarm water raises our core temperature slightly and our body reacts to it by trying to shed the excess heart, which means we then get a drop in core temperature and voila. We have created the right conditions core temperature wise for us to get better sleep.  ¬† The change in weather comes after weeks of unseasonable and unsettled weather which led to heavy rain and flooding in parts of the country.
