title: bard of salford john cooper clarke promises a right good night in dundee visit
story: John Cooper Clarke is ready to rock# and Dundee should be afraid, very afraid.He may be in his older years, but he is not holding back.And the man known as the punk poet has vowed to perform in his unmistakable style ‚Äì machine gun delivery studded with factory floor language.The rasping Salford accent is still there and the humour as cutting as a surgeon‚Äôs scalpel.And for the real devotees, John has teased them by telling the Tele exclusively that he has begun planning his memoirs.In typical fashion he says: ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt kept a f****** diary, but I have got a good memory.‚ÄúIn fact, my memory is long and my vengeance is total.‚ÄùTo the musicians and celebs who have crossed JCC in the past, start praying now because the master could even recall the gig I saw him perform at Strathclyde University in the early s and who was playing on the same bill.For the record, it was Siouxsie and the Banshees ‚Äì and I couldn‚Äôt remember that, despite being a few years younger than the man.Back in the day, John easily recalls everyone being angry young men and women. The hate for Thatcher was pure and the depth of feeling surged through concerts and rallies.He says with a chuckle: ‚ÄúThem were the days.‚ÄúWe thought it was bad then, but everything can get worse, as we see now. It‚Äôs a case of careful what you wish for.‚ÄúI don‚Äôt get involved in politics now, like I say when didn‚Äôt anyone complain about politicians ‚ÄúCan you point me to a golden era where# everybody liked being ruled  F***ing never!‚ÄúBut there are some real creeps nowadays. But then again I expect the worst from any politician.‚ÄùSo what can fans in Dundee expect when John rolls into town for his show at the city‚Äôs Gardyne Theatre on Saturday October  Without missing a beat he fires back: ‚ÄúA right f****** good night!‚ÄúAnd they can expect more of the same#and then some. There will be a few classics and there will maybe be a few extra poems.‚ÄúThen I will add a bit of fun and I can guarantee ‚Äì solid, copper-plated guarantee ‚Äì that everybody is going to leave with a smile on their face.‚ÄùJohn has fond memories of Dundee and spoke of savouring the atmosphere of a waterfront hotel and added: ‚ÄúI love coming to Scotland and Dundee. I‚Äôve been many times and the reaction of the crowd is great.‚ÄúI was here last year and saw the VA which is fabulous. I know of DC Thomson and the Sunday Post, the Beano and the Dandy plus Oor Wullie.‚ÄúMaybe I will buy one of those sculptures.‚ÄùPosh hotels and venues seem a world away from the clubs and student venues of the s with smoke-filled rooms and plastic tumblers full of warm beer.He used to travel to the shows on public transport and chuckles at the memory.John said: ‚ÄúYeah, long time ago now, mate. Now I have a driver and I am too old for public transport.‚ÄúBut I still love doing live gigs. It‚Äôs smashing. Anywhere where there‚Äôs people is greatI‚Äôm doing my stuff.‚ÄúI am working on my book of poems right now. It‚Äôs called ‚ÄòThe Luckiest Man Alive‚Äô and I‚Äôm also working on the memoirs. vw, px"  ‚ÄúI am thinking of calling that ‚ÄòI Wanna Be Yours‚Äô after the Arctic Monkeys. I just hope to live long enough to finish it.‚ÄúBut I am not finishing up any time soon. I have never even thought about that. I am not retiring, not yet and not in the foreseeable future.‚ÄùJohn has the tour to contend with first and is also lining up some television work.And at the age of  there is definitely no holding him back. So look out for many more tours to come from the man who wants to be yours.

story: A BwB article in April triggered memories for Rob Boag.For his latest offering, he said: ‚ÄúHis name lay dormant, cramped into a crevice of memory for more than half-a-century.‚ÄúAnd there he was in an April BwB article ‚Äì Billy Houliston ‚Äì and my mind began to release Billy like a genie from a bottle.‚ÄúAlong with Billy, other names surfaced such as Billy Steel, Lawrie Reilly, Jimmy Mason, Willie Waddell and the brilliant Jimmy Cowan.‚ÄúThese are names of legends and ghosts from the past.‚ÄúI was  years of age in April  when my family were huddled around the wireless listening to England v Scotland at Wembley.BLETHER: #Basher# Billy Houliston lived up to nickname and gave England #discomfort#" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp basher-lived-up-to-nickname-and-gave-england-discomfort embed # secretsCJnnwsFTq" data-secret"sCJnnwsFTq" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"‚ÄúAfter the kick-off, England‚Äôs attack on Scotland‚Äôs goal was relentless and, for the first  minutes, it was Scotland‚Äôs goalkeeper Jimmy Cowan v England.‚ÄúTime after time, just when the commentator was about to call a goal for England, Cowan‚Äôs fingertips deflected the ball over the bar or past the post.‚ÄúCowan played a blinder.‚ÄúThen, slowly and surely, Scotland broke free from the English siege and, with the talents and brilliance of Steel, Mason and Waddell and the hustle of Houliston, the Scots began to control the game and dominate England.‚ÄúIt finished a - victory for the Scots. Scotland was a proud and triumphant country that April Saturday in .‚ÄùCanadian resident Rob continued: ‚ÄúIt was almost a decade later that I gained insight into the backdrop of that victory at the famous London venue.‚ÄúScottish centre-forward Houliston and England goalkeeper Frank Swt were two characters who had destined roles to play in this international.‚ÄúOn any Saturday night during the late s and s, Frankie Davie‚Äôs pub on Lf Road, Lochee, Dundee, was the sports centre of the universe.‚ÄúAnd on one of those Saturdays, I moved my way to the bar through a packed house of former sportsmen with a smog of blue tobacco smoke hovering over their heads as they sipped on pints of heavy and relived past glories.‚ÄúI found the spot where my dad, uncles and their friends held court over sports topics and stories. A pint had been ordered for me, I nodded to everyone and picked up on the thread of conversation.‚ÄúSwt, Manchester City and England goalkeeper, was the topic.‚ÄúHector Duncan was the storyteller, and he said, Swt had a ‚Äòpair o‚Äô hands the size o‚Äô luggies‚Äô.‚ÄúAnd large hands they were, known in Manchester as the goalie with ‚ÄòFrying Pan Hands‚Äô.‚ÄúA big man and a showman, Swt dominated his area and intimidated opposing centre-forwards.‚ÄúSo, who would the SFA select as centre against Frank Swt in the upcoming  Wembley International #Find out next week#.

title: dundee 0 ict 0 dee held by caley in dens draw
story: Dundee had to settle for a share of the spoils as they were held by Inverness Caley Thistle in stuffy conditions at Dens Park.On a hot and sticky afternoon neither side hit top gear and the goalless outcome was a fair,frustrating, result.Dundee welcomed back striker Kane Hemmings after his missed the narrow Betfred Cup defeat against Aberdeen on Sunday because of a minor knock.And on the bench was teenager Josh McPake, signed on loan from Rangers earlier in the week.Missing was midfielder Jamie Ness, a late call off after he was laid low by illness.The home side made the early running, but when Aaron Doran skipped past a couple of challenges and shot from  yards, it took a fine stop by Jack Hamilton to keep the scores level.A good passing move at the other end saw the ball worked to Danny Johnson. His shot was well struck, but Mark Ridgers in the Caley goal saved well.Both teams were knocking the ball around without creating much, but Dee skipper Paul McGowan went close when he curled a -yarder just over in the st minute.Dundee were having a good spell and shortly after, Declan McDaid saw a fine free kick well saved by Ridgers.Two minutes before the break Shaun Byrne set up Hemmings for a shot, but he pulled his angled drive a foot wide.Just over two minutes into the second half Doran went close again for the visitors when he shot inches over from the edge of the area.As Dundee looked for the opener, Johnson saw a low shot deflected just wide as he tried to capitalise on a James Keatings error.The home side were working hard to break the deadlock, but for all their effort chances were few and far between.In a bid add that vital spark in the final third, on the hour mark James McPake handed a debut to his namesake Josh as he replaced Johnson.It was clear the home team were not prepared to settle for a point and shortly after another attacker, Andrew Nelson, was sent on for teenager Fin Robertson.With seven minutes left Hemming missed a glorious chance when he headed over unchallenged from a McDaid free kick.And that meant a point was all Dundee were going to get.

title: dundee united boss says international scene not the priority for young players
story: There was international recognition for a couple of Dundee United kids last week as Scott Banks and Chris Mochrie were both named in squads.Wide man Banks, , will be with the Scotland U s in Spain next month as they take on Japan in two friendlies.And this week will see -year-old old Mochrie at Largs for a couple days as part of a training camp with the SFA‚Äôs U  group.Even so, eyebrows were raised as Banks and striker Louis Appere were overlooked for the coming U  Euro qualiers against San Marino and Croatia.However, Tangerines boss Robbie Neilson is not complaining, simply because he believes first-team football at club level is more important to young players‚Äô development than these age-group internationals.‚ÄúFor a start, I think because we are in the Championship it‚Äôs dficult for the boys to get in the U s,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúThere are boys playing up in the top flight and down in England as well, so they get called up. For me, the s squad does not bother me. There have been thousands of boys down the years that‚Äôve got  caps in the s and never had a career in the game.‚ÄúFor us it‚Äôs about first-team football, getting them into our team and seeing what happens after that.‚ÄùThat desire to get his kids first-team football is why Robbie has loaned out the likes of Declan Glass and Matty Smith, both now at Cove Rangers.Youth players Alassan Jones and Michael McArthur have also gone out to juniors Broughty Athletic, who were instrumental in Appere‚Äôs development last season.‚ÄúThere is no point in having guys here that are real good prospects and not getting them a game.‚ÄúThey just end up fading out and their career gets ruined.‚ÄúWe have to make sure we give them the best opportunity to play here.‚ÄúIf they are not quite there yet then they go somewhere  and come back in six months# time but, when they do, we have to make sure there is an opportunity for them here.‚Äù

title: james mcpake accepts share of blame for dundee draw with inverness caley thistle
story: Boss James McPake has accepted his share of the blame for Dundee‚Äôs below-par performance in Saturday‚Äôs goalless draw with Inverness Caley Thistle.After pushing Aberdeen all the way to extra time in the Betfred Cup six days earlier, the Dark Blues looked sluggish as they could not find a way past the Highlanders at Dens Park.While the gaffer was unhappy about that, for him, it was a case of collective responsibility that stretched beyond those on the park.‚ÄúWe‚Äôre inconsistent at the minute. We‚Äôre getting periods of games where we look really good, then periods where we look not convinced at what we‚Äôre doing,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúA lot of that lies with me as well.‚ÄúI‚Äôm changing it, putting people on and changing shape, so I‚Äôll go away and, as a staff, we‚Äôll have a look at that and seewe can pinpoint where we‚Äôre going wrong as well.‚ÄùHe refused to use either the sticky conditions or the fact his team had taken Aberdeen to extra time as a reason for the drop in levels.‚ÄúThere was no issue with that at all. There are no excuses. Teams will come here and make it stuffy. We need to create an atmosphere.‚ÄúThe atmosphere was created last week because we were in Aberdeen‚Äôs faces and there was an extra , Aberdeen fans.‚ÄúWe could have created that same atmosphere by being the same Dundee team that came out on Sunday last week and had a right go at Aberdeen.‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the bit I need to get right, me and my staff ‚Äì and we will.‚ÄùThere was an injury scare when teenage midfielder Fin Robertson came off in the second half after feeling his hamstring.Dundee are confident, however, the problem was no more than cramp and they expect the -year-old to be available for Friday night‚Äôs derby at Tannadice.Likewise, fellow-midfielder Jamie Ness is expected toafter missing out on Saturday because of a bought of sickness.‚ÄúJamie had a bit of sickness. That‚Äôs football, you get injuries, you get illnesses, you get suspensions,‚Äù added the manager.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs disappointing but again that‚Äôs not an excuse as to why we weren‚Äôt at it and why we failed to break down Inverness.‚ÄùDundee‚Äôs few hundred remaining tickets for Friday night went on general sale today and are expected to be snapped up quickly.That will make the first derby in over three years a complete sell-out despite it being shown live on television.

title: a note of chamber music coming to crear
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is¬† only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe UK‚Äôs leading string orchestra, the Scottish Ensemble , has announced the first half of Scottish tour¬† # and Argyll is on the list of venues.The ensemble will perform Mendelssohn and Enescu‚Äôs stunning octets, and will be led by the outstanding Norwegian violinist Marianne Thorsen.Though written for just eight instruments, both of these sophisticated works have the drama, richness and depth of a full-blown symphony. They also make for an excellently contrasting pair.From Mendelssohn‚Äôs exuberant opening bars, we are swept through music that is complex yet captivatingly, joyously melodic throughout, while Enescu‚Äôs is moody, breathlessly dramatic and, in parts, simply volcanic.Guest directed by Marianne Thorsen, SE will explore the specic charm of seeing a small group of musicians performing live. With fewer instruments, the fabric of the music becomes more tangible, subtle shts in mood may have a new-found presence, and pieces you think you know well might offer surprising new colours when heard live. With fewer musicians on stage, it is easier to follow each inidual path and witness the beautul alchemy of eight artists creating something together.Thorsen is an acclaimed soloist and passionate chamber musician. Former leader of the Nash Ensemble, she regularly performs with Norway‚Äôs Trondheim Soloists, one of the founding ensembles of The Bridge network and festival.The first half of the tour, which is called Chamber Notes, will call at Crear Studio, Kilberry, on August , followed by a performance at Mull Theatre, Tobermory, on August  before moving on to Inverness and Dundee.Other Scottish dates, including Edinburgh and Glasgow, are programmed for February .PIC:Marianne Thorsen. no_aMarianne Thorsen

I think this situation leaves the NHS patients in limbo.I am sure we would rather that the current dentist and all of her staff be given a chance to voice their opinions on this matter as much and as well as the local populace.Yes, it will be brilliant to have both dentists in the town. There is the possibility that those on the local list who are currently treated well by the dental department at the hospital maybe still seen by the dentist and her staff, but I would like this to be confirmed by the local NHS trust.Brian MacDonald, CrinanSir,Hundreds of¬†people across Scotland have been helped through their exam results by a¬†local¬†group of Skills Development Scotlandcareers advisers.Based across the north of Scotland, the advisers were part of a team taking calls at the SDS Exam Results Helpline from am on results day.The helpline is a vital service, supporting young people and their families at what can be one of the most stressful times of their lives.Expert advice and guidance is available all year round, not just on results day.Our professionally qualied careers advisers are working in every state secondary school in Scotland and from our network of high street centres across the country.In schools, careers services are delivered one-to-one, in classrooms and at school events across all year groups, supporting young people to develop the skills to make informed career decisions throughout their lives. There is also support for parents and carers.At SDS centres customers can get information, advice and guidance about jobs, the local labour market, training courses and apprenticeships as well as how to prepare for interviews and help with CVs and applications.The work of SDS careers advisers in schools and centres is supported by Scotland‚Äôs careers website myworldofwork, where you can access advice  hours a day. It is packed with career information, advice and tools such as the CV builder. There is also a dedicated exam results section.Details of the local SDS centres are available at myworldofwork centres and information about events and opportunities is also available on Facebook.Pauline Graham, Project Manager for the SDS Exam Results HelplineSir,I had a great time at this year#s Islay Show. It was fantastic to speak to so many of my constituents.It was also wonderful to see many local business stalls promoting Islay#s dynamic and booming economy.The show was well attended with lots of families, both local and visitors, having a fun day out and luckily the sun was shining most of the day.A huge thanks to all the organisers and everyone  who contributed to the event.Councillor Alastair RedmanSir,I have real concerns about the deteriorating condition of some Argyll cemeteries.Constituents from Islay recently joined Councillor Alastair Redman in highlighting the poor upkeep of cemeteries in the area he represents.Councillor Redman reported that there were also problems at other cemeteries in his ward, including the cemetery at Carradale in East Kintyre.I understand that Argyll and Bute Council confirmed that they now, at last, have plans in place to address the problems at Kilnaughton.It remains disappointing, however, that things are allowed to deteriorate to the extent that the maintenance of cemeteries has become a matter of public concern.Frankly, it is very surprising that a cemetery where interments are actually still taking place has been undermined in this way and there must surely be an obligation to ensure this doesn‚Äôt happen.My experience is that communities in the Highlands and Islands pay special regard to the final resting places of fellow members of their communities and will be perplexed to discover that they appear to be uncared-for.Donald Cameron, Highlands and Islands MSP

title: lets not negotiate away scotland the brand
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is¬† only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowIf there is an accusation that could not be thrown at Ruth Watson, founder of the Keep Scotland the Brand campaign, it is that she lacks enthusiasm.The Argyllshire Advertiser caught up with the founder of the Keep Scotland the Brand campaign at the recent Mid Argyll Show.She is a firm believer that Scotland#s iconic food and drink products should be protected from imitation where. The means for¬† protection is the European Union PGIdesignation, to promote and protect names of quality agricultural products and foodstuffs.Ruth, an experienced journalist, explained: #I became concerned about two years ago when, during Japan EU Canadatrade talks, the UK government did not submit one PGI for protection.#Across Europe, , food names were protected. It worries me greatly.#She continued: #I am also concerned about how hard it is becoming to source local food and drink. I live in rural Angus, and the carrots grown down the road from me started le just as Angus carrots, but they went away for packaging and came back as Great British carrots. Technically that is correct, butwe believe in supporting local farmers and making clear choices about food miles and quality, this is ridiculous.#She stressed: #This is not a protectionist campaign. I welcome trade with any part of the world as long as the farm assured quality is there.##Keep Scotland the Brand is about valuing the integrity of our food and drink and recognising that Scotland is the brand. Across the world, people recognise Scotland as a quality brand.#One in five Scots is employed in the food and drink sector, so it is vitally important to keep our brand quality.#We trust the food on our shelves at the moment. Butthe trade deals being proposed go through we#ll end up with a multi-tiered system of quality. If the Americans get the trade deal they want, the high food standards we have are really only going to be accessible to those who can afford to pay.#It#s bad enough people having to go to food banks to survive, without people not knowing why their kids are getting ill.Ruth Watson is keen to emphasise that Keep Scotland the Brand is not a political campaign and it#s not about Brexit.#It is a campaign looking at the realities of what is before us,# she says. #I think that we have to look with some alarm at the trade deals that have been done. The UK government just has not protected our food brands.##I do this campaign on a voluntary basis from my kitchen table,# she went on. #Many people do not know what is coming. Food is treated as a commodity rather than something we should be grateful for every day, that is how successful our farmers have been.#I just believe thatfarming fails, my community is going under.##I#ve been talking to elected representatives, I go round shows. I#ll talk to anyone about this.#But what can ordinary people do Ruth is quite clear. #Get out there and talk to each other, spread the word on social media, speak to politicians.#But most of all support our local farmers.#

title: plans-unveiled-new-community-campus-earlston
story: PLANS have been unveiled to create a Community Campus in Earlston.The project will see the site of the villages primary school redeveloped.And a drop-in session is being held next month for members of the public to have their say on the proposals.Councillor Sandy Aitchison, executive member for neighbourhoods and locality services, said: ldquoWe know through Earlstonrsquos community-led plan published last year that there is a real desire in the village for a dedicated community facility and a redeveloped primary school.ldquoAs a result, the council has developed the plans for a Community Campus which we will believe will enhance opportunities for learning and social interaction across Earlston and beyond.ldquoAt same time as discussing the new campus plans, we want the views of the public regarding other properties in the village."The scheme is part of the local authoritys Fit for  project, which looks at ways to improve the Borders.Councillor Gordon Edgar, executive member for roads and Infrastructure, said: ldquoFit for  has a number of key themes which includes making best use of our properties.ldquoThe council has on average, spent poundm each year in the running costs of property which includes refurbishing and repairing the current estate.ldquoHowever, the sheer size of that estate means that investment is spread too thinly and makes it impossible to sustain safe and fit-for-purpose properties.ldquoWe want the council to be bolder and braver when it comes to making decisions about estates and engage with communities and partners on how we can together meet changing customer needs and community demands.ldquoThe Fit for  property events are a start of these discussions.The event, which takes place on Thursday, September  at Earlston Primary from pm-pm, will also give people the chance to discuss current services in the town and the provision of a new playpark.In a joint statement, Leaderdale and Melrose councillors Kevin Drum, Tom Miers and David Parker added: ldquoWe need the views of the Earlston public on properties in the village, including their thoughts on the plans for the new Earlston Community Campus which we believe will be welcomed by local residents who have requested an improved community facility for a number of years.ldquoWe would encourage as many people as possible to come along and contribute to the event.Anyone seeking more information ahead of the event can email communityengagement@scotborders.gov.uk

title: 43-year-old-woman-admits-causing-ambulance-disturbance-a7
story: BACKGROUND reports have been ordered for a Hawick woman involved in a fracas while being transported to Borders General Hospital.Grace Smith, , of Fisher Avenue, pleaded guilty at Jedburgh Sherf Court to a charge of behaving in a threatening or abusive manner in an ambulance on the A at Ashkirk on November .She admitted shouting and swearing, struggling with police officers and running from an ambulance on an unlit road during the hours of darkness.Procurator fiscal Graham Fraser said the accused reported that she had been assaulted by being struck in the face in a Hawick public house.She had complained of a sore face and was intoxicated but there was no evidence of an assault.The fiscal said that due to the circumstances an ambulance was summoned and it was considered appropriate to take Smith to Borders General Hospital.But at .pm when the ambulance was about five miles south of Hawick paramedics called the police because she was being unruly.Mr Fraser said the ambulance had to stop because of her conduct and Smith jumped out of the vehicle and was running along the road and ambulance personnel ran after her and escorted her back to the ambulance.Mr Fraser said: "Police officers arrived on the scene and her behaviour was described as emotional and volatile. She started struggling with police and had to be placed in handcuffs."He added that Smith stated thatshe was let out she would kill herself.A cigarette lighter was found in her underwear with which she intended to use to cut herself.Sentence was deferred until September .

title: council-backs-plans-return-jim-clark-rally
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council is backing plans for theof the Jim Clark Rally later this year.Organisers of the popular event have earmarked the weekend of November  and  for the closed roads race.Following the deaths of three people in  a major investigation into closed road motor sport was launched by the Scottish Government.Earlier this year organisers were given the green light to start preparations once more for hosting the event after new legislation was passed - but they still requirepermission from Scottish Borders Council.Senior councillors havetoday confirmed that it is minded to approve plans.A recent local authority consultation on the organiserrsquos plan received more than  responses, with an overwhelming majority supporting the proposals for  rally stages, using four routes, over the two days.Councillor Euan Jardine said: ldquoIrsquod like to thank everyone who took part in the consultation."A number of specic points were raised and these have been passed to the event organiser and discussed through our Safety Advisory Group meetings.ldquoWe are all operating under new legislation in planning for this event and that has its own requirements and a signicant amount of work is still required before we could provide formal approval and a Motor Sport Order for the event.ldquoHowever, we are confident that the outstanding matters can be dealt with through the intense planning process that is ongoing and for the event to take place as currently proposed.The Councilrsquos Safety Advisory Group process enables the local authority and other concerned groups to discuss event plans, including safety arrangements.Councillor Mark Rowley said: ldquoWhilst a smaller event than in previous years, there is no doubt that a Jim Clark Rally in November would provide an economic boost to the Berwickshire area, and the Scottish Borders generally."This would be particularly welcome outwith the normal visitor season and would be a great finale to the year which has seen the successful opening of the Jim Clark Motorsport Museum in Duns.ldquoThe economic impact of the proposed event is, as written in the new legislation, a consideration for the Council in assessing whether it should go ahead, however our priority, first and foremost, is that it is as safe as possible for all involved.

title: beyond-borders-celebrating-10-years
story: TOP writers, broadcasters, politicians and artists are heading to Innerleithen this weekend for the Beyond Borders International Festival.The event which is celebrating its th anniversary, is being held at Traquair House.A number of activities will be on throughout the weekend in the main marquee in front of the house.And in the old walled garden where there will be music, exhibitions, film, food tastings, meditation sessions and yoga.The global impact of climate change will take centre stage throughout the festival including a  discussion addressing the vital role of women in climate action a youth climate change summit with school strikers taking part in discussions and events and Carbon Casualties, a photography exhibition from the New York Times which is on display in the garden.Other programme highlights include the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon former UN Special Envoy to Syria, Staffan de Mistura and journalists Lindsey Hilsum Razia Iqbal Allan Little Jim Naughtie and Sarah Smith.For a historical perspective, Professor Bettany Hughes Sir Tom Devine Sir Hew Strachan and Rosemary Goring will all be appearing.The event will also welcome remarkable female cultural leaders from Afghanistan, Kashmir, Pakistan, Syria and Yemen to take part in sessions on the art of peace building.This festival which also includes walks, storytelling and bike rides, began  years ago as the inspiration of Mark Muller Stuart QC who lives at Traquair with his we, Catherine.He told us: "The festival proves that the thirst for human debate and the desire to listen to the first-hand experiences and stories of others remains undiminished notwithstanding the rise of the digital age."What better place to do it than in the tranquil setting of Traquair in the Scottish Borders."

title: vandals-target-primary-schools-days-pupils-return
story: POLICE have launched an investigation after vandals ransacked a Peebles primary school - just days before pupils were due tofrom the summer holidays.Parents of Halyrude Primary School were horried after discovering the destruction caused by thugs at the weekend.Vandals undermined months of hard work by fundraisers and volunteers by destroying the polytunnel as well as the plants inside.Not content with ripping apart the tunnel, they also smashed a window in the school building and pushed over all the new picnic benches.The culprits also appear to have tried to force entry to a locked shed.A Police Scotland spokesperson said: "We are investigating following a report of vandalism to a primary School in Peebles."The incident happened sometime overnight between Saturday and Sunday, August  and , and resulted in a window being broken and a vegetable patch being disturbed."Inquiries to identy those responsible are ongoing."The school purchased the new greenhouse structure after landing a windfall from the Tesco Bags of Help earlier this year.The project was made possible with help from members of the Peebles CAN team and parent volunteers.And green-fingered pupils were hoping to harvest ingredients for lunches, but vandals have destroyed those plans.Locals took to the Peeblesshire Community Vandalism page to voice their disgust and dismay, with offers to help to clean up the destruction pouring in from residents.Parents said there was a large amount of broken glass within the grounds, and there are reports of trails of blood on the ground.One local said it was very ldquobrazen of the louts to carry out these attacks at the school considering it is situated next door to the local police station.One parent added: ldquoThis is sickening. How can anyone think it is okay to do this "Someone knows who is responsible for this. Do the right thing and call it in to the police.Anyone with information should contact Police Scotland on .

title: mobile-recycling-service-arrives-borders
story: MOBILE recycling is set for ato the Borders.From next month a pilot, which allows for wood, electrical items, batteries and cooking oil as well as garden waste to be deposited, will be launched in Jedburgh.Andthe scheme is successful it will be rolled out to West Linton, Lauder, Coldstream and Newcastleton.The mobile recycling service is the latest effort by Scottish Borders Council for the region to become a landfill-free area.Councillor Gordon Edgar said: ldquoThe Borders public has helped save poundmillion a year on landfill tax thanks to their efforts in recycling.ldquoHowever, we still have around  per cent of waste in our general bins which could have been recycled."Not only does this have an impact on the local environment, this costs taxpayers over poundm a year which could be spent where.ldquoWe are always looking at ways to increase recycling in the Scottish Borders.ldquoThis mobile recycling service pilot scheme is our latest effort."The four-month mobile pilot will run from Sunday, September  to the Sunday before Christmas.A survey will carried out during the same period to gauge use and views ahead of a decision being made about a roll-out.Councillor Edgar added: "It is important to emphasise this is a pilot scheme, with the results of the pilot and survey to be considered fully before a final decision is made."The mobile recycling service will operate every Sunday in Lothian Park Car Parkbetween am and pm.middot

title: additional-needs-summer-camp-goes-bang
story: A SUMMER camp for children with additional needs has been hailed a huge success.The Borders Additional Needs Groupteamed up with Live Borders to host five days of fun and adventure at the Leader Valley School in Earlston.An inaugural camp was held last year over three days.But thanks to funding from Cash for Kids and Tescos Bags for Le, the  camp was extended - with more than  children enjoying the activities.And hopes are high that next years will be even bigger.Pauline Charles from BANG told us: ldquoThroughout my years of experience, I never expected the camp to be as good as this."Wersquove had  people through our doors and over  children."We have young carers, parent carers, siblings, grandparents, foster carers ndash itrsquos been overwhelming.ldquoLive Borders staff and BANG will evaluate this project, look at worked well, and what we can improve and start to redesign rsquos respite camp."Cash for Kids donated pound, towards the camp with pound, coming from Tescos.Plans are already taking shape for more camps throughout .Pauline added: "Parents have been asking for Easter, Summer and October camps."Irsquom working now with another charity to develop a bigger project next year.ldquoWe were very privileged to be able to use Leader Valley School and thatrsquos down to the relationship with SBC."The environment and the school lsquomakersquo the project. It provides a safe environment.All of the children were given the opportunity to take part in sporting activities, music and art projects.And it was also a chance for parents and carers to relax.Sports Development Manager from Live Borders, John McBay said: "Itrsquos been action-packed for the children, but above all, itrsquos been about fun and the children feeling very safe.ldquoThe parents are the critical bit - they often get missed in families where additional needs are required."We have to make sure that mum and dad have the opportunity just to chill out and relax.ldquoThe parents have all got together and been chatting and thought this has been a great outlet for them."They have all learnt from each other about some of the challenges they face at home and dferent copping strategies.ldquoWe would love to do this on a more regular basis and not just the holidays.

title: ban-boozed-up-bgh-driver
story: A motorist who admitted driving while almost three times the legal alcohol limit has been banned from the road for  months at Jedburgh Sherf Court.Thirty eight year old Robert McLeod, of Stonefield Place in Hawick, pleaded guilty to driving with a breath alcohol count of  microgrammes - the legal limit being .The offence happened at the Borders General Hospital car park on October  and on the A at Ashkirk.He had initially been charged with driving while almost seven times the legal limit. McLeod was accused of having a breath alcohol count of  microgrammes but put forward a defence of post incident drinking.Following negotiations between the Crown and McLeods lawyer, the lower reading of  was accepted.In addition to the disqualication period, McLeod was fined pound.

title: erin-designs-women-39-s-tour-scotland
story: ONE Peebles cycling fan has made her mark on the very first Womens Tour of Scotland.Some of the biggest names in womens cycling took part in the three-day event earlier this month.And the winner of the Best Young Rider was presented with a jersey designed by schoolgirl Erin Acherman.The -year-olds design, inspired by the hills of the Tweed Valley, was the pick of the peloton for race organisers.Erins prize included one of her own jerseys signed by all the the inaugural tour winners.Mum Judith told us: "Erin was inspired by the hills in the Tweed Valley and part of her prize was to go in the convoy car and hear all the race excitement from a prime spot."Despite dficult conditions for much of the three stages, the Womens Tour of Scotland has been hailed as a huge success.Riders from some of the worlds top teams set off from Dundee for Dunfermline on stage one.Day two of the race took the riders from Perth to Glasgow.And the finale involved a loop through Peeblesshire from the start and finish in Edinburgh.An estimated , cycling fans lined the  kilometre route over the three days.Winner of the race was -year-old American Leah Thomas from Team Bigla.And it was another Bigla team member, Nikola Noskovao won Erins Best Young Rider jersey.

title: last-ditch-plea-save-local-drama-group
story: A STRUGGLING local am-dram group is hoping help is at hand so the show can go on.Denholm Drama Group has been putting on performances for  years.But times are tough, as the group may now be forced to close, due to a lack of support.In recent years, the local drama enthusiasts have had to cut short or completely cancel their tours, due to not having enough members to produce performances.At the recent AGM an ultimatum was agreed... to either fold or make only last ditch attempt to rally support.Alan Dowler Smith from Denholm Drama Group said: "Many of our regular members have left, for one reason or another, and the Group has been struggling for some years to find plays that suit a small number of actors, particularly men."Additionally, our backstage members are not getting any younger, and the logistics of transporting a portable theatre around the countryside are becoming unsustainable."In the past, the group was somewhat a village staple.Exactly when it was formed is unclear, but it was certainly around in the s, when it performed in the old village hall.The groups first recorded performances began in  when pantomimes took place every year at the village primary school, often involving the school children.But in , a catastrophic fire put the groups future at risk.The societys assets were totally lost, and with no insurance cover, the future looked bleak.With generous donations from local organisations and grant aid from Scottish Borders Council, new equipment was purchased and the Group found a new role, touring local village and town halls, mostly performing one-act plays.Now,  years on, the group are struggling once again, and are on the verge of disbandment.Alan said: "It has been decided that as a last-ditched effort, a more robust recruitment drive will be carried out before September comes."However,insufficient interest is expressed, with deep regret the group will close down for ever, bringing a sad end to more than six decades of service to the local community."Anyone who wishes to register their interest in joining Denholm Drama Group should call Alan Bowler-Smith on .

title: innerleithen-music-festival-goes-swing
story: THE range of entertainment at last weekendrsquos Innerleithen Music Festival lsquosurpassed our high expectationsrsquo, according to Robin Dempsey from the coordinating committee.The core venues of Live  Local at the Vale Club and the St Ronanrsquos Hotel brought in the crowds for their continuous programme of fantastic bands.There were almost  performances between them, giving a stage for many local acts.But there was a wide iety on offer where, from outstanding classical music with The Taylor Family  Friends to colourful belly-dancing at the Union Club, taking in Gaelic singing, ukulele, border pipes and line-dancing on the way.Possibly the biggest audience over the weekend was at the Church of Scotland for Innerleithen born and bred Tommy Ashby who has achieved wide acclaim on the UK circuit.Meanwhile, at the late night Festival Club, in the middle of the many contributions from festival regulars, there was the unexpected pleasure of an impromptu demonstration of Breton folk dancing from a visiting French group.Robin told the Peeblesshire News: ldquoIt feels like the festival has completed a transition from its early years focussed on large scale concerts to a vibrant community based event."It was heart-warming to see so many locals and visitors, young and old, coming together to share their love of music, whether as performers or in the audience."

title: walking-festival-organisers-hail-volunteer-army
story: ORGANISERS of the forthcoming Scottish Borders Walking Festival are hailing the volunteers who have helped pull the packed programme of events together.Since the end of last year a small army of locals from Selkirk and the surrounding valleys have been mapping, plotting and organising.And they have been rewarded with a festival of walks and social events which are selling out fast.Sue Briggs, chair of the  Festival team, told us: ldquoItrsquos been amazing."People say they couldnrsquot run a festival without volunteers and in our case itrsquos  percent true."There are only four of us on the Festival team and the local community has really risen to the occasion and given us a huge amount of support."As well as leading the  planned walks, volunteers will also drive visitors to the drop-off points.Many other volunteers are also organising the social events which will be held throughout the week-long festival.And they will also be manning a pop-up cafe in the Victoria Halls to provide a warm welcome for the walkers.Among the many special offers of help which are being made, are the young people of Rowlands who are serving up ldquoHot and Tasty Comfort Food every weekday evening from pm to pm during the festival.InChorus community choir from Peebles will provide a ldquosinging send-off on the opening day - Saturday, September .Craigdon Mountain Sports are providing a boot clinic in the Victoria Halls on the opening weekend, and local choir Safety in Numbers are hosting a musical stroll around the Haining on the Sunday.Selkirk Community Shed are busily creating wooden walking figures for the entrances to the town.And many businesses have also offered support with raffle prizes.Sue added: "The Scottish Borders Walking Festival is very much a joint effort between the Festival team and the people of Selkirk and the Yarrow and Ettrick Valleys."The Scottish Borders Walking Festival takes place in Selkirk and the Ettrick and Yarrow valleys from Saturday, September  to Saturday, September .Late availability tickets can be purchased from www.borderswalking

title: 14-year-old-found-major-search-peebles
story: POLICE and mountain rescue teams were called out last night to search for a missing teenager near Peebles.A police helicopter was also deployed as the operation continued into the early hours of this morning.The -year-old was eventually located just before am in a remote part of Glentress Forest.And he was taken off the hill without suffering any injuries.A spokesman for Tweed Valley Mountain Rescue said: "This was a great outcome to what could have been a prolonged search job across a massive area."

title: eildon-eradicate-emissions-electric-vans
story: A BORDERS housing association is eradicating emissions with a new fleet of electric vehicles.Eildon introduced the new Nissan LEAF cars and Nissan E-NV vans earlier this month.And dedicated charging points have also been introduced at the social landlords headquarters in Selkirk.The vehicles have all been leased in partnership with Scottish Borders Council.John Duncan, director of Property Assets at Eildon commented: ldquoEildon is committed to ensuring we comply with the legislative requirements set for national targets, but we want to go beyond that, and positively promote best practice as a responsible and forward-looking organisation."Innovative new methods like this are key to what we are aiming to achieve, and this new electric fleet demonstrates our commitment.The new vehicles produce zero emissions, and with improvements in battery technology they can travel up to  miles on a single charge.The new charging points, which are live on Charge Place Scotland, are open to the public for vehicle charging.

title: strike-demo-planned-scottish-borders-council-hq
story: UP to  strikers and supporters are expected to hold a demonstration outside Scottish Borders Council headquarters on Thursday.A dispute between workers in the roads department and bosses at the local authority led to a vote being taken in June.A total of . percent of the Unite union members voted to take strike action over changes to their terms and conditions.The first day of industrial action will take place on Thursday.A spokesman for Unite told us: "Between  and  strikers and supporters are expected to assemble."The workers in the roads department have been treated with contempt and the latest efforts by the council to draft in contracted workers to cover workers taking action is disgraceful.ldquoInstead of positively engaging with the workers and Unite, the council seem intent on escalating the dispute."Unite will explore every legal avenue to challenge this aggressive action.ldquoUnite also believes that there is a strong legal case that workers are being offered unlawful financial inducements to break the existing collective bargaining agreements.The reasoning behind the dispute has been refuted by the local authority chief executive Tracey Logan.She told us: "Some of the allegations made by Unite about the planned strike by a small number of roads department staff on August  are absolutely unfounded and cannot be left unchallenged.ldquoThe council has not changed terms and conditions for this staff group, nor have we failed to consult the trade unions or the staff affected.ldquoIn fact, we discovered some months ago that a small number of staff in this section had been claiming a higher rate of overtime than they were entitled to under the agreed terms and conditions.ldquoThey were also claiming for time to travel to work when working weekend overtime, which again is not in line with the agreement in place.ldquoGiven that Unite agreed to these terms and conditions, I am surprised and disappointed that they now want some of their members to be given more favourable pay rates than others, and for this small group be able to claim additional allowances that their other members cannot."The strike is set to coincide with a meeting of Scottish Borders Council on Thursday morning between .am and .am.

title: pets-factor-2019-voting-re-opens
story: The votes have been counted and we can now reveal those who have made it into the Top  of our fantastic new-look Pets Factor competition.In this weeks paper youll find photos of all the pets made it to round two of our contest and who are still in the running to win the title and the pound cash prize.And this year wersquove joined forces with our friends at Border Vets to make our competition bigger and better than ever.The vets practice, which has branches at Innerleithen, Galashiels and Selkirk, have given us goody bags worth pound for the winner, pound for the runner-up and pound for the third placed pet.The aim at Border Vets is to help your pet live a long, happy and healthy le.Visit bordervets for details of their Pet Health Plans, dental staging and x-rays, eVets  hour pet care and Nurse clinics.So now its back to you, readers of the Borderand Peeblesshire News, to vote for your favourite and pick the Top .Yoursquoll find a voting token on the inside back page, so make sure you get voting now.Wersquoll print tokens every week and our second round of voting will last until noon on September , . Remember you can enclose multiple tokens in one envelope to save on postage!

title: galashiels-selkirk-benefit-south-scotland-funding-boost
story: GALASHIELS and Selkirk are both set to benefit from the latest round of South of Scotland Economic Partnership funding.Almost pound, has been awarded to Philiphaugh Estate to improve its salmon viewing centre, establish a Golden Eagle visitor centre and expand the Waterwheel Cafe.And Energise Galashiels have been granted more than pound, to help enhance the town centre ahead of the Great Tapestry of Scotland visitor centre opening.A total of pound,, was announced by Rural Economy Secretary Fergus Ewing to help support five projects across the region.On his visit to Philiphaugh, he said: "The Scottish Government, working with the South of Scotland Economic Partnership, is determined to help the South of Scotland to realise its full economic potential."Wersquore doing that by targeted investments in projects which we believe will act as the catalysts for creating new businesses, providing vital skills, and making the region an even more attractive place to visit.ldquoThe work of the South of Scotland Economic Partnership, the establishment of a new enterprise body for the region, and the pound million we are investing in the Borderlands inclusive Growth Deal, underline our commitment to continuing to deliver for the South of Scotland and its people.Also included in the funding announcement was pound, for Community Enterprise Support.The pilot project aims to increase the number of financially sustainable community enterprises across both the Borders and Dumfries and Galloway.Initial target areas for the programme, which will build business and financial skills, are Galashiels, Jedburgh, Hawick, Eyemouth  East Berwickshire, Stranraer, Langholm, Upper Nithsdale and Dumfries.An already successful programme which is being run in Dumfries and Galloway is being expanded into the Borders with the help of almost pound, of funding.Growing Rural Skills will build on the success of a recent dairy sector pilot and broaden the sectors supported to include forestry.And concluding this weeks funding announcement was almost pound, going to the Eyemouth-based social enterprise ReTweed, which helps women start and grow their own business within the creative industries sector.South of Scotland Economic Partnership Chair, Professor Russel Griggs, said: "This major funding announcement is fantastic news for the South of Scotland."From wildle to town centre regeneration, these five projects will help support and deliver long-term social and economic benefits to communities in the Scottish Borders and Dumfries  Galloway by creating new businesses, providing vital skills and making the region an even more attractive place to visit.ldquoThe economy of the south of Scotland will benefit greatly from this new impetus to stimulate growth and success.

title: galashiels-digs-new-pioneering-tools-project
story: AN unique recycling project is now ploughing a new furrow in Galashiels.Peebles-based You Can Grow already supplies the Scottish Prison Service and a special needs support service with recycled garden tools.A two-year agreement with Scottish Borders Council allows the social enterprise to collect all garden tools which are being dumped at recycling centres.Everything from reconditioned second-hand hoes and hedge cutters to shovels and spades are being ed to use in gardens across the Borders and Edinburgh.And now they have branched out to include Why Not  on Chanel Street in Galashiels.Bosco Santimano from You Can Grow told us: "The whole idea is that we stop good garden tools going to landfill."We take any items that are still in good condition and can be refurbished or repaired and used by the community."Everyone can browse and pick up the refurbished and as-new tools they need for a fraction of the price in shops."We will keep adding outlets from where the local community in the Scottish Borders can buy the tools while saving huge amounts of waste going to landfill and insaving the environment."You Can Grows reconditioned tools are also available to buy from Change Works in Peebles and The Allotment shop in Innerleithen.Mr Santimano is delighted to have expanded to Galashiels.He added: "Why Not  provides a base for independent crafters, artists, small businesses and community groups rent pop-up spaces."They also provide concessions for community groups and not-for-profit organisations to publicise what they do."Adam Elder - one of the partners in this pioneering business venture - contacted us through social media and offered us a space to showcase these refurbished tools."You Can Grow is also in the process of setting up a tool library in Peebles.And they have also just launched a new website to promote their activities and projects relating to growing.

title: fun-sun-clovenfords-summer-fair
story: CLOVENFORDS Summer Fair took place at the weekend, providing two days of good old-fashioned entertainment for locals to enjoy.From traditional fancy dress competitions to a making animals out of vegetables and everything in between, there was not a dull moment to be had.Locals even had the chance to show off their culinary expertise in the Bake Off challenge.Cloven Fair committee member Alice Mackay said that "it was a very successful weekend for the village."With an array of stalls, food, music, games and a raffle, there was plenty to keep the children entertained.On the Friday, the fair hosted the duck race, a scavenger hunt and a teddy bear picnic.And Saturday was a scorcher the main day of the fair saw a performance from the pipe band, and a masterclass in fancy dress, which departed from the Clovenfords Hotel in the early afternoon.The results in the weekends activities were as follows:Duck Race st - Zara Cairney, nd - Tina Martin, rd - Sara GreenFancy Dress Primary Iniduals st- Mirryn Andreson , nd - Connor Wilsonrd - Abigail Brooke Fancy Dress Pre School Iniduals st - Amelie Wilson , nd - Anna Hunter , rd - Hadley Sharpe Fancy Dress Large Group st - Cloven at its Sweetest - Codie, Tyler, Zac, Mila, Finlay, nd - The In-Clovenfords-Ibies - Charlotte, Leo, Orla, Harry, Oliver, rd - Cloven build a Bear - Erica, Lucy  coFancy Dress Small Groups st - Apollo  - Cullen  Calder Halley, nd - Cat in a Hat - Sophia, Sarah, Myla, rd - Meigle Hill Rescue Team - Amy Scott, Eryn KimberBake Off st - Erin Liddle, nd - Rebecca Davie, rd - Ally TurnbullVegetable Animal st - Jack Wood, nd - Jemima Jewitt, rd - Joshua KerrGames Challenge st - Harris Scott, nd - Lottie Calder, rd - Abigail Brooke

title: border-guards-seen-intercepting-three-dinghies-off-coast-dover
story: Border guards have been seen intercepting three dinghies containing suspected migrants heading across the English Channel towards Dover.Around  people were seen being taken to a quayside Home Office facility in Dover after the boats were towed towards land by a Border Force cutter.This latest crossing follows a fresh wave of attempts by migrants to travel from France to the UK in small boats.People on board two of the dinghies were initially seen being escorted to shore at around am, closely followed by a third.----The Dover coastguard has confirmed they were called out to assist a Border Force operation on Tuesday morning, but refused to comment further.On Friday, Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned illegal migrants that they would be sent backthey risked crossing the Channel.He described the journey as ldquohazardous, adding: ldquoThe UK should not be regarded as a place where you could automatically come and break the law by seeking to arrive illegally.ldquoIf you come illegally, you are an illegal immigrant and Irsquom afraid the law will treat you as such.--vw,vw,px, px"A group of men are brought to shore by Border Force officers --Responding to the latest incident, Dover and Deal MP Charlie Elphicke said: ldquoThis crisis has been escalating into a summer of chaos on the English Channel.ldquoIt will only end when migrants and traffickers alike know the crossings wonrsquot succeed.ldquoThatrsquos why the French authorities need to get a grip and stop people setting off from France ndash before there is another tragedy in the title: ministers-told-hs2-over-budget-three-years-ago
story: Ministers knew HS was over-budget at least three years ago, it has been reported.The warning was given in May , two months after legislation for the first stretch of the line was approved by MPs, according to the BBC.A Department for Transportspokesman said HS is Europersquos biggest construction programme and ldquolike all major, complex projects, delivery plans evolve over time.Last week, a Government-commissioned review into whether the scheme should continue was launched amid growing fears it cannot be built to its current specication within the pound. billion budget.This is being led by Douglas Oakervee, a former chairman of HS Ltd ndash the taxpayer-funded firm building the railway ndash with Lord Berkeley acting as his deputy.----The BBC reported it has seen a May  letter written by then-transport secretary Patrick McLoughlin to George Osborne ndash chancellor at the time ndash stating that the first phase of HS was pound billion over budget.Phase  of the railway between London and Birmingham was initially due to cost pound billion.The BBC reported it also obtained a December  DfT briefing note labelled ldquoconfidential which states that ldquoa signicant gap to target price will remain for HS even with planned savings.Concern over how much the project could cost has risen since the documents were produced, with a recent Financial Times report stating that HS Ltd chairman Allan Cook wrote to the DfT, warning the final bill could reach as much as pound billion.Despite this, Transport Minister Nusrat Ghani told the Commons last month that ldquothere is only one budget for HS, and it is pound. billion.The feared price hike is believed to be due to ious factors including engineering costs, poor ground conditions, under-estimating the cost to purchase land and property, and the expense of running trains at up to mph, which is faster than comparable projects.In November last year, HS Ltdrsquos chief executive Mark Thurston denied the project was over budget but acknowledged officials were ldquoin talks with contractors about reducing costs.Whitehall spending watchdog the National Audit Officerevealed in June  that the DfT asked the firm to assess the impact of delaying the opening of the railway.An HS Ltd spokesman said ldquoregular updates have been provided on the scheme, and it has come under ldquoextensive scrutiny including studies and reviews by the NAO and parliamentary committees.He went on: ldquoSince , we have moved a long way as a project and organisation. We have now appointed a set of world-leading civil engineering contractors which enables us to have greater confidence about cost and construction schedules, as well as making signicant changes to our management team.ldquoOur CEO has spoken publicly for some time about the cost pressures facing the project and we are working closely with our contractors to bear down on cost before major works commence.Phase  of HS is planned to run between London and Birmingham from December , while a second Y-shaped phase will launch in two stages.Phase a from the West Midlands to Crewe is due to open in , followed by Phase b from Crewe to Manchester, and Birmingham to Leeds, in .HS trains will also serve destinations on conventional lines beyond the new high-speed network, including York, Newcastle, Liverpool, Glasgow and Edinburgh..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Ministers  utold HS was over-budget three years ago u

title: 5g-fast
story: The Government has announced plans to speed up the roll-out of G technology and improve mobile phone signals in rural areas as part of efforts to increase innovation across the UK.G networks have already begun to launch across parts of the country, with several mobile operators switching on their networks in a number of cities.Here is a look at how the technology works:ndash What is G G is the next generation of wireless mobile connections, following on from the G networks currently used by smartphones across the globe.As the name suggests, this is the fth generation of the network technology.ndash How fast will G be There is no official speed standard for G, but many experts expect it to be up to  times faster than G ndash and therefore potentially faster than home fibre broadband.Ernest Doku, mobiles expert at uSwitch, said: ldquoG is a next-gen network technology that should deliver speeds of up to Gbps ndash on paper, thatrsquos considerably faster than Grsquos top-end speed of Mbps.ldquoIn practice though, as wersquove seen with G, the speeds will likely be well below that but real-world tests do show itrsquos still much quicker than its predecessor.ldquoWhere yoursquoll see a real dference with G is in the speeds you can download Ultra HD and D video. At Grsquos theoretical top speed, you could download an entire GB Ultra HD movie in about  seconds.ndash When is G launching in the UK EE was first to launch its G network ndash at the end of May ndash in six cities: London, Cardf, Belfast, Edinburgh, Birmingham and Manchester, with more to follow before the end of the year and into .Vodafone switched on G in Birmingham, Bristol, Cardf, Glasgow, Manchester, Liverpool and London on July .Three began turning on its G network in August, while O said it will also launch at some point this year.However, the process will be a gradual roll-out, meaning G will not be widely available everywhere for some years to come.----ndash How does G work G is made up of unique radio frequencies that are broken up into bands. These frequencies are a lot higher than G, which means they can support a larger capacity.Experts say this means more connected devices can be used at one time.ldquoG tech also has the capacity to handle the surge in demand for bandwidth generated by the Internet of Things boom, Mr Doku said.ldquoG is considered a millimetre wave technology ndash with a shorter wave than G, it has a higher frequency, which gives it a higher bandwidth and consequently ability to handle more data.Experts have also suggested that some potential benefits of this could be the increased ability to operate data-heavy networks, such as those needed to power autonomous vehicles, in years to come.ndash How much will G cost So far, pricing of G plans has ied across networks, with prices higher than G on some networks given that it is a new technology.For example, EE offers a sim-only plan with GB of G data for pound a month, while GB of G data costs pound a month.However, Vodafone has priced its own G plans at the same rates as its existing G offerings.But experts have noted that, as we saw with Grsquos maturation, prices are likely to fall as G becomes more widely available in the years to come..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: What is G and how fast is it

title: private-firms-invited-operate-public-toilets
story: PRIVATE firms are being invited to tender for the running of public loos in the Borders.The pound. million contract would see all of the current  toilet blocks handed over to the company for the next decade.And Scottish Borders Council staff employed in the cleaning and maintenance of the facilities would be transferred.The move comes after the local authority recorded a pound, deficit during its first year of charging for entry.And a decision was made last year to invite expressions of interest from third parties into taking over the operation.Although the official tender notice was published this week, and is due to start next April, bosses at Newtown claim the transfer isnt a done deal.And that it will be up to elected members, most likely at their meeting next February, to decide the way forward for public conveniences in the Borders.A Scottish Borders Council spokesperson said: ldquoFollowing the completion of this tendering exercise a range of options will be put to councillors as part of the   budget setting process."The estimated value outlined in the contract advert is the overall estimated cost over a  year period."Officers at Scottish Borders Council had predicted the introduction of p charging at  of the  facilities would generate income of pound,.But after the first  months only pound, had been deposited in the automatic charging boxes.The deficit was blamed on tailgating, doors being wedged open and good Samaritans.And it was agreed last year to investigate alternative methods of keeping the facilities open amidst growing budget pressures.The spokesperson added: "As part of our ongoing public toilets review, and as agreed by councillors in June , we are seeking to establish the potential cost to the council of these facilities being managed by a third party."The advertised pound. million contract is to provide all of the public conveniences services and to provide an options appraisal of the network, identying commercial opportunities and enhancements.The five-year contract, with options to renew for a further three then two years, also asks companies to look at opportunities for potential installation of Changing Places Toilets as well as opportunities for potential charged Showers changing units at key tourism sport leisure destinations.Closing date for submitted tenders is September .

title: campbeltown rallies to independence march
story: The independence march through Campbeltown on Saturday was a huge success and put a real zest for le back into the town which has been too long forgotten.That was the view of organiser Manny Singh who despite his apparent sacking from the All Under One Banner organisation was very much still in charge at the Campbeltown march.Afterwards he said: #It was a huge success for Campbeltown and the biggest demonstration for decades. There was a lot of spirit and a feeling that a number of towns in Scotland which have been forgotten, like Campbeltown, will not be left behind after independence.#He put the turnout at more than , and added: #The fact that the march extended theof Longrow gives a fair indication of the numbers who were there.He also told the Courier this week that he remained the #legal indentity# of the All Under One Banner group, despite a bitter public row among the hierarchy which looks like splitting the group in two.It was the biggest rally held in the town in recent years with marchers coming from as far afield as Aberdeen and Alloa and as well as Oban, Glasgow and Islay, with many travelling on the weekend ferry from Ardrossan.#It really exceeded expectations and made a big splash in the town, Ron Wilson of Yes Kintyre told The National.#There was a real buzz as people came early and most of the hotels were booked up. The pubs and cafes were busy so it was good for local businesses. Campbeltown is a Yes town and it was brilliant to have all these people come here. Local people were coming off the pavements and joining the procession so it created a good, positive vibe.Pro-Unionists opponents held their own counter demonstation. However, the march went off without any incident and there were no arrests, with only one warning which was drug related.A spit of rain earlier in the day failed to develop into poor weather as the marchers would round the town to hear speakers and listen to musicians at the rally at Kinloch Green.Mr Wilson said he was particuarly pleased at the turnout as there had been some confusion over whether the march would go ahead due to internal sions within the hierachcy of All Under One Banner, which has organised independence marches across the country.Following Mr Singh#s sacking, founder Neil Mackay resigned from his position on its national executive pending an internal investigation.Pro-UK Unionist group A Force For Good met the march on the shore front and say they filmed and counted the marchers, as they have at previous events, and afterwards claimed the turnout was just .Director, Alistair McConnachie, said: #All Under One Banner is basically the marching wing of the SNP. AUOB, and SNP MPs and MSPs, lie about the numbers which attend their marches, sometimes up to  or  times.#Unfortunately, they are not challenged by the Scottish media. The good news is that A Force For Good has a presence at every AUOB march. We bear witness to the huge value of the United Kingdom.¬† Our #Thin Red Line# stands for everyone who likes being British, who likes the UK, and who wants us to stay together.#A group from Barrowfield at the Campbeltown cross ahead of the march. title: pupils stay cool to catch late winner
story: Campbeltown Pupils applied the perfect finish to their pre-season preparations with a hard-fought win over Rhu.Having been regular visitors to the Caledonian League side‚Äôs summer tournament, winning the competition in , the one-off match was played in a good spirit, but it was the Pupils who found their ruthless streak to snatch a win in the closing minutes.Rhu, fielding a team with plenty of height and energy, featuring several former youth players from Dumbarton FC # and former teammates of Pupils‚Äô playmaker Donald McCallum # threatened early on.At the other end, though, the McFadyens-sponsored Pupils had first-half chances, with Scott Souden and youngster Calum McKillop both having one-on-one opportunities, but their efforts were stopped by the Rhu keeper.The second half exploded into le on the hour mark as former Sons youth Callum Scott made his mark for Rhu, turning inside his marker to curl a classy left-footed finish beyond stand-in goalkeeper Ellis Robertson.Undeterred, the Pupils searched for an equaliser, and were given the opportunity minutes later when a Rhu handball in the box was penalised by referee Thomas d‚ÄôAlessandro.John McCallum, playing as sweeper in a back three with Fraser Wylie and Ross Souden, stepped up to send the keeper the wrong way and make it -.However, after a lapse in concentration, the Pupils conceded a second goal, a cleverly guided header from a near-post corner evading Robertson in goal.Then, with the -degree heat and high humidity making the game hard work for both teams, the Feathers-sponsored Pupils rallied to equalise.A sweeping move involving midfield trio Keith Mitchell, Stuart Crossan and Donald McCallum found Scott Souden, who made no mistake when bearing down on goal, lashing a right-foot shot past the Rhu keeper, to the delight of his teammates and the clutch of Campbeltonians making the long journey to spectate.Then, in the dying seconds, after seeing shots blocked at their own end, thanks to some vital interventions from Robertson, the Pupils stole a winner when midfield substitute Finn Scott was teed up by Scott Souden to slot the ball home low beyond the Rhu keeper, ensuring the visitors completed pre-season unbeaten.Pupils manager Campbell Robertson said: ‚ÄòThe conditions were tough, but the boys played really well, and our shape was good too. We would like to thank Rhu Amateurs for their excellent post-match hospitality.‚ÄôMeanwhile, the Pupils‚Äô centenary season officially starts tomorrowwhen they host Argyll rivals Lochgilphead Red Star at Kintyre Park, in the SAFL‚Äôs aptly named Centenary Cup, with a pm kick-off.And with two more Saturday group matches to follow in August, firstly away to Dunoon and then at home to Tarbert, the Pupils will look to continue their dazzling pre-season form once the competitive action begins.Photograph:

story: The main attraction at last Sunday#s event was a huge field covered almost entirely in purple phacelia but there was also a patch of sunflowers # a feature at the farm last year too # and several patches of five and seven flower mixes.While some simply enjoyed wandering among the purple plants which caught the eyes of motorists on the A just north of Campbeltown for weeks, others took advantage of the other activities on offer.There were nature walks of three ying s, hot drinks and snacks for sale, and information boards about the plants and wildle to enjoy, as well as workshops on seeding and flower arranging.Some of the younger visitors also enjoyed tractor rides and a look at some of the farm animals.Farmer David Young explained that the phacelia, although eye-catching for its beautul purple flowers, was actually planted as a soil improving weed suppressor. It has since been cut down to make way for the field#s next crop.The sunflowers remain at the farm and are available to purchase on a pick-your-own basis.In last week#s letters pages, Mr Young said: #I#m pleased to report the day raised ¬£ for the Waverley Boiler Appeal and thanks to Moira Gemmill#s selfless decision the sum of ¬£ from the teas will go to Woodlands Centre, Campbeltown.#He added: #We are very grateful for the community#s support on the day and we hope to make it an annual event.#From left: Andrea McShannon, Taylor Purser, Isla McShannon holding Cleo the dog, Alexander McShannon and Kerry Hopes in front of the purple phacelia. title: organisers buoyant after successful second regatta
story: More than  people attended the event, which offered dinghy sailing, paddle boarding, kayaking, canoeing, trips on yachts, scuba ing and beach activities, including numerous games and a sand castle competition.Despite weather worries in the week leading up to the regatta, there was bright sunshine for much of the day, a relief for those who remained on dry land, although more people than ever before took the opportunity to try the dferent water sports on offer.The event is organised by groups, including the Kintyre Seasports Project, Dalintober Beach Group and Campbeltown Sailing Club, with activities taking place at Dalintober Beach, the sailing club, Aqualibrium and Campbeltown Marina.Greig Walker,¬†commodore of Campbeltown Sailing Club, told the Courier: #It was great to see many young sailors who took part in our lessons over the summer coming along and taking their friends out on the boats.#We had an excellent group of volunteers helping not only with the activities but also with registration, catering and handing out equipment.#It was fantastic to see the community coming together to provide such a great event for Campbeltown.#Jamie McLean added: #On behalf of Dalintober Beach Group, I would like to thank the following: The emergency services who were present on the day # the Coastguard, RNLI, Young Firefighters and Police Scotland Youth Volunteers Tesco and the Co-op for their donations comp√®re Helen Gilchrist, who did a fantastic job as usual everyone who took part and all those involved in organising the day # it was a great success!#More more news on the regatta, see next week#s Courier.

title: second half blitz secures pupils cup win
story: A stunning second-half performance saw Campbeltown Pupils overrun hosts Dunoon in their latest Centenary Cup tie.Still reeling from a defeat in their opening fixture, the McFadyens-sponsored Pupils travelled to Cowal knowing three points would be vital to keep their cup hopes alive.A cagey first half, where the Pupils struggled to get into gear, produced few goal-scoring opportunities, with a dry synthetic surface and a swirling breeze combining to make the contest rather attritional.Into the second half, with the wind at their backs and perhaps the benefit of some hard weeks in their legs from a full pre-season schedule # including training nights at Westport beach # the Pupils, with the help of some quality introductions from the substitutes‚Äô bench, took control of the tie.The opening goal came from an unexpected source, young central defender Ross Souden, deployed at right back, scoring from close range after a corner kick wasn‚Äôt dealt with by the Dunoon defence.The Pupils doubled their lead from the penalty spot on the hour, after a handball in the Dunoon box. Ryan McConnachie opted to go straight down the middle and evaded the e of the Dunoon keeper.There was a moment of worry at the other end, though, when goalscorer Souden also committed a handball in the Pupils‚Äô box, and referee Peter Laing pointed to the spot. Dunoon halved the Pupils‚Äô advantage, making it -.Then, just  seconds later, the Pupils restored their two-goal lead through Donald McCallum, who met left-sided substitute Kenny Kerr‚Äôs low cross to squeeze a shot between the Dunoon defenders and the frame of the goal.Soon after, the Pupils made it -, when Kerr guided another delightful cross onto the head of John McCallum, who guided an effort past the keeper from six yards, but it was the goal creator Kerr who was rightly mobbed by his team-mates.Not content with four, the Feathers-sponsored Pupils scored again, with # stand by # Kerr making it three assists in one match.Played in by McConnachie after some strong play in midfield by fellow substitute Michael McKinlay, Kerr set up young winger Ross Brown, who gladly tucked home goal number five with a close-range finish.With the match drawing to a close, McConnachie sealed his brace # and the Pupils‚Äô sixth goal # with an excellent inidual effort, surging past a defender before rounding the hosts‚Äô keeper and slotting the ball low into an unguarded net, adding gloss to an already emphatic cup win.After a great team performance, the Pupils will be hoping for more of the same tomorrowwhen they welcome a Tarbert side # who last week also defeated Dunoon # in a Kintyre derby.The match is scheduled for a pm kick off at Kintyre Park.
