title: tim-39-s-tales-side-sunset
story: THE Boat Shore at Cockenzie is a magical place: a small natural cove, embraced by ancient rocks and a beach seeped in the history of the local community.Legend tells us that the name Cockenzie is derived from Cul Cionnich, meaning Cove of Kenneth in Gaelic.St Kenneth was a Celtic saint and a follower of St Columba. His missionary work took him all over Scotland, including the coastline of the Forth. It is said his arrival at this small natural harbour gave the place its name.Last weekend, artist Andrew Crummy, who lives in the village, organised three lsquosunset eveningsrsquo at the Boat Shore. Local musicians, singers, artists and actors gathered on the beach with an audience of fellow locals to share the sunset.I sadly couldnrsquot attend the first two but was able to make the last evening with some of my children. It was a wonderful mix of music and song, with a very funny short drama, and a setting sun as the backdrop.It was a poignant evening for myself, and I know for some others too a moment of reflection as well as coming together. I had planned to tell a tale about St Kenneth, but I changed my mind just before the event.Instead, I told a tale of a friendship between a tortoise and a butterfly and what sunsets meant to them. In story, anything is possible, and I made this tale to help ease someonersquos sadness in experiencing an ending.I was later askedI could share it, and so here is the story:There was once a tortoise who became friends with a butterfly. On the first day of their friendship, the tortoise invited the butterfly to sit with him on his favourite rock, to watch the sunset.However, Butterfly had no idea what a sunset was, and so when she saw the sun fall gradually from the sky she became concerned.ldquoWhatrsquos happening to the sun  she asked in a worried tone.ldquoItrsquos the sunset, said Tortoise, ldquoitrsquos when the sun goes down and ends the day.ldquoWhat, already! Thatrsquos it  asked Butterfly, horried. ldquoThis is just my first day being a butterfly and my days are over Tortoise smiled: ldquoNo my wee friend, itrsquos not all over. The sun will come back and there will be another day.But Butterfly remained anxious: ldquoHow can you be sure the sun will come back ldquoTrust me, I know. Irsquove seen many sunsets, said Tortoise. ldquoThe sun always comes back. Sometimes it takes longer than others, sometimes you canrsquot see the sun because of clouds, but it always s and makes another day.Butterfly was now reassured and so settled down to watch, as the sun dipped lower, painting the sky. She expected the sun to sizzle and the sea to steam when they touched each other, but of course that didnrsquot happen. The sun slid quietly below the horizon, leaving a trail of bright red and orange.ldquoThat was beautul, wasnrsquot it  Tortoise said.But Butterflyrsquos reply was unexpected: ldquoI think I donrsquot like sunsets very much.Tortoise curled up the wrinkles on his old face in surprise: ldquoWhy not, donrsquot you think it was spectacular, the way it painted the sky ldquoSuppose, but it was sad, really sad, said Butterfly.ldquoSad ldquoYes, because the sunset ends the day and thatrsquos sad. Endings are sad.Tortoise nodded in a way tortoises do when theyrsquore thinking: ldquoYes thatrsquos true, endings can be sad. But everything ends sooner or later. Nothing lasts forever.ldquoBut thatrsquos what I mean Tortoise, itrsquos so sad. I donrsquot want to sit and celebrate the end of something.Tortoise thought for a moment: ldquoAlthough endings can be sad, they also give meaning and value to our time. Without sunsets we would not treasure our days. Our le would become one long blah of sameness.ldquoA blah of sameness ldquoYes, my expression, smiled Tortoise proudly.ldquoBut thatrsquos easy for you to say, Tortoise, because you have more time than me, you will have more days.ldquoPerhaps, but that means your time is more precious than mine. And your sunsets are greater celebrations of your days.Butterfly thought about this. ldquoYou seem quite wise, Tortoise, she said, looking at her friend.ldquoYes, he replied immodestly, ldquoI do have that reputation. I suppose I have a lot of time to think, sitting on this rock.It began to get dark and colder.ldquoNow itrsquos time for our dreams. Soon there will be the sunrise, said Tortoise.ldquoSunrise  Is that when the sun s Tortoise nodded: ldquoYes, you see you donrsquot get a sunrise without a sunset. Although endings can be sad, they open the door to new beginnings. At the other side of a sunset there is a sunrise.Tortoise was indeed wise and Butterfly felt reassured by his wisdom.That summer, the two friends watched many sunsets together. They would share stories about their day as the sun went down. Then one evening, as flocks of geese were flying overhead, Butterfly spoke sadly.ldquoTortoise, I need to go. Itrsquos getting cold. Irsquom off to Africa. Do you think there are sunsets there ldquoIrsquom sure of it, replied Tortoise.ldquoI love sunsets now, said Butterfly. ldquoThey have shown me to treasure and celebrate my days. But I am sad this is our last one together.ldquoMe too, said Tortoise.The two friends sat together on their rock as the sunset commemorated their summer with a blaze of colour. Then they said goodbye.A new dawn now lay ahead for them both, for the end of one story is the beginning of another.And at the other side of a goodbye, there is a hello.

title: new-dunbar-grammar-school-head-boy-follows-mum-39-s-example
story: Thomas Leitch has been named head boy at Dunbar Grammar School, nearly  years after his mum, Karen Leitch, nee MacKay, was named as head girl.Thomas, , is joined by head girl Georgie Cross, with the duo looking to strengthen communication in the school and its eco credentials.Thomas, whose mum was head girl in -, said: ldquoBecoming head boy was always something I have been interested in.ldquoI would not say there was a pressure but I was pushed forward by my mum, who was head girl when she attended the school.ldquoI always wanted to give something back and I have enjoyed my six years and felt it was right for me.Georgie, also , previously planned to leave school and work for a year before looking to go on to university.She said: ldquoI made the decision to stay on towards the end of S.ldquoI was involved in the pupil council and the set-up already within the school.ldquoI made my decision to stay on and decided I was not a person to sit idle or who wanted it nice and easy I want to make a dference while I can, especially when I consider myself quite a confident person.Interested pupils put their names forward to become head boy or head girl and outlined what skills and attributes they possessed which they felt made them suitable.A hustings then took place within the school before speeches were given in front of senior pupils encouraging them to vote for them.An interview in front of Claire Slowther, headteacher at the school, and the outgoing head boy and head girl Ben Dorin and Hannah Dickson, followed before the results were revealed.Now the duo, along with deputes Ben Totten, Niamh Goldie, Alicia Lancaster and Emma Welsh, are looking forward to a busy year ahead.Thomas, who plays scrum-half for the schoolrsquos rugby team, told the Courier that communication had been at the heart of his manesto.He said: ldquoI really focused on communication within the school and making sure it is not just senior management and senior pupils who get a say.ldquoIt is everyone and I got that point across and set up drop-in sessions so we have always got younger pupils to get involved.Similarly, Georgie, of East Linton, was keen to strengthen the schoolrsquos eco profile.She added: ldquoOne issue I would push, which the school is doing, is to make the school as eco as possible.ldquoThere is a lot of buzz around climate change.Mrs Slowther said there was a strong list of candidates for the two roles.She added: ldquoBoth Thomas and Georgie stood out with their confidence, commitment to the school and a real sense of what they wanted to bring to the school.

title: pensioner-collided-schoolchildren-outside-musselburgh-grammar-school-avoids-driving-ban
story: Ian Steedman, , had just collected two children from outside Musselburgh Grammar School when he lost control of his car and ploughed into the three teenage pupils.Steedman, of Edinburgh Road, Tranent, believed that his brakes had failed, causing him to strike the schoolchildren, but tests carried out later on his Honda Civic showed no problems with the braking system.The grandad, who owns Bisset  Steedman in Tranent, later realised he had got his foot stuck under the brake pedal, causing him to lose control of the car last November.Steedman had initially pleaded guilty to dangerous driving last month but changed his plea after seeking legal advice.He appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court today , where he admitted an amended charge of careless driving by driving through a red light and colliding with three children and a vehicle at Musselburgh on November  last year.Fiscal depute Nicole Lavelle told the court that Steedman had collected a young relative and a friend from outside the school at about .pm before making his way onto the townrsquos Inveresk Road.Ms Lavelle said: ldquoAs the accused drove he became aware he could not stop his vehicle and he consequently drove onto the opposite carriageway to avoid two vehicles which had stopped at a red light.ldquoAs the -year-old boy passed halfway across the crossing, he was struck by the accusedlsquos vehicle, lting him up on to the bonnet."The vehicle also delivered a glancing blow to two others.ldquoThe accusedrsquos vehicle continued through the crossing and collided with the front near side of a car.The fiscal said two of the school pupils who were struck were  years old and the third was .Ms Lavelle added that the boy who landed on the bonnet of Steedmanrsquos car received a large gash to his upper leg after he ldquoended up between the two vehicles when they collided.Ms Lavelle said the boy then landed on the roadway and was rushed to Edinburgh Royal Infirmary for treatment he spent the night at the hospital.Steedman subsequently had his eyes tested by police officers and the court heard he had ldquoprovided a negative breath test following the incident.Defending solicitor Mary Moultrie said that her client had taken ldquoevasive action by pulling onto the opposite carriageway after realising he could not brake in time.Ms Moultrie added that Steedman ldquobelieved his brakes had failed at the time of the collision but afterwards realised he ldquomust have put his foot under the brake pedal.The lawyer said that Steedman had had a clean driving licence for the past  years and had been driving at a ldquovery low speed when he struck the three children.Ms Moultrie added: ldquoThis a genuine one-off, isolated incident that is very regrettable.Sherf Peter McCormack agreed and sentenced Steedman to a pound fine and placed six penalty points on his driving licence.

title: efforts-tackle-climate-change-east-lothian-39-small-slow-39-says-group
story: Action group Rewilding East Lothian is calling on East Lothian Council to increase tree and wildflower planting and for unused council land to be given over to wildle.But the local authority has defended its position and highlighted ious projects which it feels are making a dference.The campaign and action group has already gained more than  members since being founded in April.It has called on the council to adopt a lsquoRewilding Motionrsquo which could lead to a number of steps being taken, including reduced mowing and spraying of green spaces.Helen Carlyle, a group member from North Berwick, said: ldquoWe live in a beautul part of Scotland but our childrenrsquos futures are under threat.ldquoThe human race depends on bees and other pollinators and those creatures need wildflowers and weeds to live in. One way we can fight back against ecological collapse is to have wilder, unmown, unsprayed spaces around us. Short grass and manicured parks may look neat but itrsquos vital to have flourishing wild spaces too.Rewilding East Lothian wants the council to commit to planting thousands more trees to help absorb the carbon dioxide emissions that are driving global warming.In addition, the council has been challenged to radically reduce mowing and weed-killing, since weeds provide homes for bees and other pollinators, and to mitigate the loss of green spaces to housing by proactively making dedicated areas for nature to flourish.A council spokeswoman said East Lothianrsquos reputation as the Garden County was ldquoappreciated by residents and visitors alike. She pointed to the relaxation in the cutting of greenspaces and the use of plant species which attract a wide range of pollinators. She added: ldquoOur most recent residentsrsquo survey found high levels of satisfaction with our parks, gardens and open spaces.ldquoWe have a number of initiatives to increase sustainable management of our countryside sites and improve bioersity and pollination.ldquoThis is reflected in the work we have been doing with partners such as Buglersquos John Muir Pollinator Way project, the planting of , metres sqaure of wildflower meadow, low impact grassland management and targeted use of a weedkiller where appropriate.ldquoOur Green Network Strategy, part of our Local Development Plan, recognises the importance of vacant and derelict land for wildle, and seeks to identy suitable locations for tree planting given the important role that trees play in mitigating climate change. This links in with the draft Climate Change Strategy which considers in more detail how East Lothian can tackle climate change.

title: bid-cockenzie-pub-39-s-beer-garden-open-longer
story: The Thorntree Inn in Cockenzie has to close its beer garden at pm as part of its planning conditions.However, agents for the pub owners Caledonian Heritable argue that the beer garden, which overlooks the Firth of Forth, has become a popular destination in itself and is unfairly disadvantaged by the fact it has to close at the early time.And they say the closure has put severe limits on the use of the popular spot in the village by its customers.The pub is thought to be one of the oldest in East Lothian, opening its doors as Barclays Hotel in .It opened the beer garden, which runs along the bottom of neighbouring gardens and overlooks the seafront, five years ago.Applying for a change in the conditions to allow it to stay open until pm in the evenings, the agents said: ldquoAs drinking habits have changed and drinking has become more sociable, it is not uncommon for beer gardens to be destinations in their own right.ldquoThis beer garden in question has excellent views across the Forth and affords a relaxed atmosphere for friends and families to enjoy time together.They said that the beer garden had run without complaints and listed a number of other beer gardens across East Lothian that are open until pm.They said: ldquoClosing the beer garden at pm is having a detrimental effect on the business and is resulting in disappointed customers.ldquoIt seems unreasonable given the lack of complaints and incidents regarding our clientsrsquo beer garden that it should close at pm when other beer gardens in East Lothian remain open.

title: Rosemary Goring  Prince Andrew must end his silence on Epstein
story: Many of us have loved ones from outwith our own DNA pool to whom we are closer than all but our dearest relatives. The world is a much better place as a result but, unlike with family, the bonds and obligations of friendship are less clear-cut. Sometimes ties wither naturally, at others, rash or destructive relationships have actively to be severed. This is an unpleasant fact of le and one that Prince Andrew is discovering belatedly to his cost.For some time now, speculation has been mounting after the publication of a photo showing the Prince walking in a New York park with his friend, the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, who was recently found dead in a prison cell, where he awaited trial on charges of sex trafficking and conspiracy to engage in sex-trafficking.The headlines must have made the Palace shudder, their insinuations all too clear. After details of a US lawsuit mentioning him were released, a terse statement was issued distancing the Prince from historic accusations made against Epstein, and claiming that ldquoAny suggestion of impropriety with underage minors is categorically untrue.:Prince Andrew hosted Jeffrey Epstein at BalmoralClose observers of Buckingham Palace might have noticed a cloud of dust around the flagpole as the house was shaken to its foundations. When the Daily Mail published footage recently showing the Duke of York ushering a young woman out of Epsteinrsquos Manhattan apartment in , a further statement was issued. The Duke, it said, ldquodeplores the exploitation of any human being and the suggestion he would condone, participate in or encourage any such behaviour is abhorrent.Poor Prince Andrew. He is discovering what every child in the playground knows: that you are tarred and feathered with the same brush as those with whom you mix. If one of your gang throws a brick through a window, you are deemed guilty too, evenyou did nothing wrong.In the case of His Royal Highness, letrsquos put aside for a moment the suspicions his closeness to Epstein, following his release from prison, arouse. Bad enough that Andrewrsquos personal contacts are so dodgy they raise serious questions about his judgement, let alone his behaviour.If nothing , these images suggest one of two things: that the Prince was a loyal chum who stuck by Epstein, despite his ruined reputation and the risk it posed to his own. Or that, living as he did in a gilded cage, removed from real le and the consequences of any stupid decisions he made, he was utterly unconcerned about the effect their friendship might have on his prospects. When you are cocooned from birth in a cradle of privilege when you are feted, indulged, and pandered to by sycophants and liggers from the minute you can shake a rattle, it must be easy to believe you are above the normal rules and standards by which society works.Meeting in the park with Epstein was, at best, decidedly odd for someone in Prince Andrewrsquos position. Going to his apartment, however, where a stone satyr presides over the front door, was simply crazy. According to police who raided the property, they seized photos of underage girls. These and the fetishist decor would have led most ordinary visitors to make a swt exit.These images of the Duke of York date from the period when he was acting as British ldquoSpecial Representative for Trade and Investment. A bespoke role for an aimless aristocrat, it gave him licence to roam the globe, meeting fat cats in rich countries and opportunistic states in the hope that some of their wealth would find its way into Britainrsquos Treasury.:In Pictures: Commonwealth leaders gather for state dinnerDuring his deployment as an envoy, Prince Andrew made ious embarrassing ldquomissteps, among them some politically unwise associations. Nothing, however, could compare with being identied as one of Epsteinrsquos cronies, after which revelation he relinquished the post.As the grapevine quivers with anticipation over other high-profile names likely to be found in Epsteinrsquos fat address book, the Dukersquos predicament is increasingly grave. He can hide behind the Palace gates and hope the storm will pass, but this is a story that has been brewing for years. Until certain questions are satisfactorily answered, as far as hersquos concerned it is far from over.Doubtless, it will go against every royal instinct, but would he not be wiser to face the cameras, do an in-depth interview, and silence ndash perhaps even charm ndash his critics  In a situation like this, where unfettered gossip is fuelling supposition, Prince Andrew surely needs to explain his connection with Epstein and help suffocate the scandal. It would, of course, be a historic move. No member of the royal dynasty has ever voluntarily gone on record to put their side of a wildfire story, with the exception of Princess Diana. In her unforgettable, kohl-eyed interview with Martin Bashir, she was more focused on scoring points against Prince Charles than in illuminating her own often dubious actions.Sticklers for Palace protocol might feel sick at the thought of Prince Andrew going public. Even in the hands of the most measured journalist ndash Kirsty Wark, say, or Fiona Bruce ndash it would be viewed as stepping into the lionrsquos den, a suicidally reckless act. Added to which, the Windsors do not explain. They take a long view, recognising that the passage of time usually allows even the most unsavoury episodes to fade into oblivion.In this instance, however, that seems unlikely. So what is worse  Staying schtum, and waiting for more seedy revelations to be added to the blaze, or allowing the Duke to get ahead of the story, and give his version of events By remaining aloof, the Palacersquos response suggests it hopes to avoid further fallout. The implication of this is all too plain: royals might not be above the law, but its arm would have to be very long indeed to winkle one of them out of the front door and into a Black Maria. Inviting a Windsor to a police interview, let alone into a courtroom, would require Herculean effort, and a mountain of cast-iron evidence. By contrast,Andrew were willing to face, refute and defuse the rumours, it would be an act of bravery to restore family pride.

title: dads-army-peaky-blinders-series-five-episode-one-sanditon-episode-one-reviews
story: Peaky Blinders, BBC****Sanditon, ITV****HOW would you like your Sunday evenings served, madam: with bare naked laddies, cuddly nostalgia, or machine guns  Those were the dining options as the main channels attempted to lock viewers in for the autumn.Peaky Blinders made the move from BBC as a reward for its Bafta-winning, young audience-grabbing ways, while ITV was offering Sanditon, which sounds like a DIY product but is in fact an unfinished Austen brought to a close by Andrew Davies, the writer who puts the bonking into bonnet and carriage dramas.But who do you think you are kidding, Mr Scheduler  For a certain vintage of viewer, the main event was Dadrsquos Army: the Lost Episodes. Three shows, which first aired in , now remade with a dferent cast but the same David Croft and Jimmy Perry scripts.The sets were spot on, there was a bona fide Scot, David Hayman, playing Frazer, and the opening titles were intact. But some actors were more successful than others at the imitation game, with Cold Feetrsquos silky Robert Bathurst moving smoothly into Sergeant Wilson mode, ditto Hayman as Frazer, while Kevin Eldonrsquos over the top Jonesy veered unwisely into panto.: The Lost EpisodesThe script still worked, though. While raising more of a Mona Lisa smile than Laughing Policeman hysteria, there were a couple of choice moments, each springing from the showrsquos sheer, tin helmeted, silliness.Silliness is not something one would associate with the Peaky Blinders. Slo-mo walking through gritty urban streets, sex and death - thatrsquos your Peaky Blinders way. Season five opened with the Wall Street Crash. With a chunk of their change gone, it is to be back to basicsfor the Shelby gang.Head of the crime family Tommyhas always been given to rare but signicant pronouncements made in a low growl. Becoming a Labour MP seems to have loosened those cherubic lips. Last night he wouldnrsquot shut up, banging on about dark deeds in dimly lit corridors of power. Please God he is not turning into some Brummie Francis Urquhart. Now a more troubled figure, even his children are standing up to him, tiny as they are. More of a cheek, they are doing so in Estuary English.You can always rely on Arthur to lower the tone. ldquoWersquore ****** was his priceless assessment of the crash, while his pronouncement on the Shelby boardroom biscuits - ldquotheyrsquore nice - was delicious.: Damien Loves pick of the weekOver on ITV it was even older days as young Sussex lass Charlottecame to the aid of travellers in need. The passengers, a town planner and his we, were so grateful for Charlottersquos help they invited her to come with them to the titular seaside town.Charlottersquos dad was uneasy. Just be careful, he warned. Seaside resorts can be odd places. At home, anyone who had spent a September weekend in Blackpool would have nodded gravely in agreement.Sure enough, Charlotte was soon seeing some very rum things involving a local toff and a lady in the woods. The camera kept a discreet distance, but whatever the pair were doing it was not playing a round of whist.After  minutes, Davies was done with the titillation and flat out presented three butt naked men heading to the sea for a swim. The move, known in the trade as ldquodoing a Bodyguard, was not pulled on the female characters, who preserved their modesty in full-body swimwear.Come episode end, Charlotte was clashing with a tall, dark, handsome, borderline psychopathic typewho you just know will have a softer side under all that frowning. Yawn.: Lessons of my long career, by Anne ReidMore promising are the spiky female characters, among them Anne Reid as Lady Denham, whose fortune everyone wants, and the sharp as a Peaky Blinders blade humour. Lady Denham versus Tommy Shelby, sex and sand up against fascism and furs, who could ask for anything more Peaky Blinders and Dads Army continue on Monday night

title: letters-scottish-national-party-truly-internationalist-nature
story: I would remind Mr Smith that it is not the SNP which is displaying narrow nationalism by wanting to leave the European Union, on the contrary it is the SNP which is leading the fight for Scotland to remain within the EU, which was the decision taken by voters in Scotland at the referendum. Given its outward-reaching and positive attitude to the EU, and the desire to see Scotland remain at the heart of Europe and with a seat at the United Nations, perhaps it there ever was to be a name change, a better reflection on where the SNP stands would see it known as the Scottish International Party.Ruth Marr,Stirling.ldquoWHEN I use a word, it means just what I choose it to mean. The Humpty-Dumpty theory of language is obviously endorsed by Mark Smith.I am an unapologetic supporter of Scottish independence, but I never describe myself as a nationalist. Why  Because this word must be the most ambiguous in the English language, so much so that it has long ceased to have any practicalin discourse. It has no taxonomic value.Just think: Nelson Mandela was a nationalist, so also were Radovan Karadzic, Ho Chi Minh, Mladko Radic, Slobodan Miloscaronevi#, Mahatma Gandhi, and Adolf Hitler. A word that includes such contradictory definitions is meaningless.Mr Smith is hideously wrong in claiming that Anglophobia is at the heart of the SNP. In fact, many of its supporters are English.One cannot be a true internationalist without recognising the existence of nationalism.Brian Quail,Glasgow G.THE England Get Out of Scotland Banner, the subject of comments made recently by Nicola Sturgeon is not racist, bigoted or anti-English. The banner is a copy of an older Irish banner saying the same and is all about the conquest of Scotland by England in  when the parcel of rogues in a nation, our nobles, accepted the equivalence of more than pound, in bribes to sell out Scotland. The banner in its true meaning is calling for English institutions like Westminster, the Bank of England, the BBC, the English Monarchy and the Ministry of Defence at Faslane with Trident to leave Scotland so that we are no longer a province of England, no longer a colony of England.With regard to English people who live, work and retire in Scotland, they are always welcome. It is a mark of the timidity of some that such a banner has been unfairly criticised when Boris Johnson when Editor of the Spectator in  allowed a poem to be published that talked about putting the Scots in ghettoes and calling for our extermination and hardly an eyebrow was raised. That is truly racist and Scotophobic and should be condemned by all right-minded people but very few voices are raised.The banner will be shown in future with no apologies from me and I will give the final word to Police Scotland to whom complaints have been made about the banner when it was shown. When I explained what the banner was about they allowed it to be displayed as we had not broken any law.Sean Clerkin,Barrhead.I AM engaged in correspondence with the Electoral Commission about the conduct of a further independence referendum. The Commission appears to be unaware that in Scotland the people are sovereign and not the Scottish Parliament. Therefore the Commission requires to consult the Scottish people about such issues as yes no and remain stay questions also the need for a two - thirds majority to settle a constitutional question.Thus there may need to be a two stage referendum, the first stage consulting the sovereign Scottish people about how an independence referendum should be conducted.The SNP, allied with the unelected Greens, controls the Scottish Parliament and hatea being outranked by the Scottish people.William Durward,Bearsden.CORRESPONDENTS Philip Adams and Alan Fitzpatrick , express a preference for the question in the next independence referendum to ask whether the voter wants to remain or leave. Unfortunately, such a question would be legally unsound. The Treaty of Union of , which forms the constitutional basis for the United Kingdom, was negotiated as an international treaty between two sovereign nation states, Scotland and England. It follows thatthe citizens of Scotlandvote for independence there is then no UK to break away from. The UK disappears, to be replaced by the old new nation states of Scotland and England. The Yes No question posed in the  referendum, as approved by the Electoral Commission, was crystal clear, and I see no reason to depart from it.Professor Alan Murdoch,Perth.

title: scottish-government-looks-secure-cross-party-opposition-no-deal-brexit
story: Labour, the Greens and the Liberal Democrats have indicated support for a planned debate in the first week of the new Scottish Parliament session, which begins next week.The motion is expected to say "That the Scottish Parliament agrees that the UK should in no circumstances leave the EU on a no-deal basis".Constitutional Relations Secretary Michael Russell said: "When the new session starts we will be less than two months away from a catastrophic no-deal which the UK Government appears now to be actively pursuing."It is essential that the Scottish Parliament has the opportunity to have its say while there is still time to stop this disaster from happening."Mr Russell said the debate could prove a defining moment for the Scottish Conservatives.He said: "Their leader in the Scottish Parliament says she is opposed to a no-deal Brexit. This is an opportunity to make that opposition crystal clear and unambiguous."Crashing out of the EU without a deal is in no ones interest and I hope the Parliament can come together and unanimously agree that a no-deal Brexit should be ruled out in all circumstances."Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie said: "This parliamentary debate is an opportunity for all parties to come together and urge the Prime Minister to change course."I hope that will include Ruth Davidson, who once warned of the damage Brexit would do to our economy and way of le."Liberal Democrats will work with other opposition parties to prevent the looming national crisis, not just to prevent a no-deal Brexit but to stop Brexit altogether."Scottish Greens co-leader Patrick Harvie confirmed his party will back the motion in order to send a clear signal to the Prime Minister "that pursuing a reckless exit from the EU is not acceptable".He said: "The pressure is now on Ruth Davidsons party at Holyrood - will they join the rest of us in joining a rational majority to block Boris Johnsons disastrous agenda "

story: Nicola Sturgeon hit out at the PM after he conceded that reaching an agreement for the UK to leave the European Union by October  was now ldquotouch and go.The Conservative leader had previously insistedit was a ldquomillion to one chance that the UK would be forced into a no-deal Brexit.:Gordon Brown: The Scottish Parliament has failed to deliver a fairer Scotland"@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "First Minister Nicola Sturgeon criticises the Prime Minister","description": "First Minister Nicola Sturgeon criticises the Prime Minister following his change of rhetoric on the idea a no-deal Brexit.","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs jBkBJe-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests jBkBJe.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": With Holyrood set to pass a motion making clear that the UK ldquoshould in no circumstances leave the EU on a no-deal basis next week, Ms Sturgeon hit out at the Prime Minister, claiming he is ldquobehaving in a kind of carefree, shrug of the shoulders, reckless manner.Today I met @eucopresident Donald Tusk at the #G summit. We discussed the UKs exit from the EU and foreign policy issues #GBiarritz #TeamUK## pic tCVyTfvKmdash Boris JohnsonAugust , The First Minister told PA Scotland: ldquoHersquos gone in the matter of a few weeks from saying that a no-deal Brexit in his view was a million to one chance, to now saying itrsquos touch and go which suggest to me hersquos making it up as he goes along.ldquoThatrsquos not acceptable because the consequences of this are so serious for our economy, for our society, for the livelihoods and living standards of people theand breadth of the UK that thatrsquos just not good enough. She added: ldquoThe House of Commons s to session next week and the SNP MPs will be working hard with other parties to find whatever way we can of stopping no deal in its tracks because that would be catastrophic.ldquoScotland didnrsquot vote for Brexit in any form but a no-deal Brexit would be particularly damaging and wersquoll do everything we can to stop it.In addition to this Holyrood will next week step up its opposition to a no-deal Brexit when MSPsfrom the summer recess.Scottish Greens and Liberal Democrat MSPs have already signalled they will support the Governmentrsquos motion on this, stating that ldquothe Scottish Parliament agrees that the UK should in no circumstances leave the EU on a no-deal basis, ensuring that this will pass.:SNP boss faces sack after independence referendum Plan B blockedIt comes after Mr Johnson, who has pledged to take Britain out of the EU by October  ldquodo or die, held a series of talks with key European leaders.The PM used theG summit in Biarritz to hold talks with European Council president Donald Tusk, following a round of diplomacy which saw him meet Germanyrsquos Angela Merkel and Francersquos Emmanuel Macron.And following those discussions, herefused to repeat his previous assertion that the odds of a no-deal outcome were a million to one.ldquoIt all depends on our EU friends and partners, I think in the last few days there has been a dawning realisation in Brussels and other European capital what the shape of the problem is for the UK, the Prime Minister said.ldquoI think itrsquos going to be touch and go but the important thing is to get ready to come out without a deal.

title: theatre-review-crocodile-rock-oran-mor-glasgow-four-stars
story: Crocodile RockOran Mor, GlasgowMary Brennanfour starsA Play, a Pie and a Pint is still in the mood to celebrate  productions since its inception, so some previous successes are in the autumn roster alongside new scripts. Itrsquos one of these, Crocodile Rock, that kickstarts the season.The Crocodile Rock in question is the brightly painted landmark thatrsquos popular with tourists visiting the town of Millport on Cumbrae. For Steven ndash aged , in  ndash therersquos not much  thatrsquos eye-catching, or attractive, on his personal horizons: hersquos bored, and unsure of who he really is.He already knows he doesnrsquot fit in ndash not with any of his classmates, nor with the locals who drink in his dadrsquos pub. Inheriting that business ndash or indeed his mumrsquos BB ndash gives him the full-on heebies. Is there to be no escape for a shy, warm-hearted lad who craves a feel-good niche he can call his own As soon as Darren Brownlie arrives on-stage as Steven,and announces that this is going to be HIS story, wersquore totally onside with him. Itrsquos Brownliersquos affable twinkle, the little nod towards camperie that charms us so. That nod will acquire a wink, a shimmy and a a-tastic flamboyance as the piece progresses.This is all to the good because writer composer and directorAndy McGregorrsquos one-man musical about coming of age, coming out and coming into your own skin, has dips in its own energies ndash and Brownliersquos ability to play a iety of distinctive characterswhile singing and going into a sassy strut, counterpoints a short-fall in melodic lsquobigrsquo moments. For Steven, the le-changing encounter is with a larger-than-le drag queen.The dialogue between them ndash Brownlie switching superbly between voices and personalities ndash is the lsquoopen sesamersquo that unlocks the buttoned-up inner Steven. Gavin Whitworth and Gary Cameron are the dab hands as versatile backing musicians in what is a tour-de-force by Brownlie.

title: great-british-bake-off-not-turn-tv-stodge
story: The wholesome baking show may not possess the ability to halt the current political chaos but it has been known to unite indferent office colleagues over the water cooler and inspire even the most kitchen adverse to start churning out loaves of banana bread.It might even allow you to forget about Brexit for  minutes.Almost a decade after it first hit our screens, The Great British Bake Off is still clinging to its title as unlikely cultural cornerstone.After a half-baked first season, the show came into its own and won over viewersrsquo hearts.As far as the current climate of reality TV goes, Bake Off offers relatively low stakes.The rules of the show are delightfully simple. Each week follows a loose theme ndash think bread, pastry, or desserts ndash and contestants complete in three rounds, after which the weakest is knocked out and the strongest is declared Star Baker.It sounds banal enough but each episode comes with a sprinkling of mild peril. Like when Diana mistakenly took Ianrsquos baked Alaska from the freezer, triggering an, erm, meltdown which saw him fling his creation in the bin before judging. And donrsquot forget #Custardgate, when Deborah accidentally picked up competitor Howardrsquos custard and used it in her own trle.Yet it is something more endearing that keeps viewers coming back for a second helping. Like, in the first season, when Mark Whithers was comforted by Sue Perkins over his sunken marmalade tea loaf. ldquoYou put your heart and soul into this, said then-host Sue Perkins, as the lorry driver burst into tears.There was series six winner Nadiya Hussain.Known for her cartoon-like facial experiences and on-screen wisecracks, her victory speech moved the country to tears. ldquoIrsquom never gonna say, lsquoI donrsquot think I canrsquo, she said. ldquoI can and I will.Most recently, Rahul Mandal won over fansrsquo hearts as he defied crippling shyness to be crowned last seasonrsquos winner. Sweeter than any of the showrsquos desserts, the research scientist confessed to taking up baking to ldquomake friends, with one particularly heart-melting series scene showing him walking into Rotherham Leisure Centre to deliver a cake to staff.The Great British Bake Offrsquos th series will be the third to air on Channel  after the show parted ways with the BBC. Cold hard ratings may have waned , but enthusiasm certainly hasnrsquot.The line-up for the new series is the youngest in the showrsquos history. It includes seven people in their s, with the oldest contestant aged , making an average age of  in the tent.Henry Bird, a -year-old student who features in the upcoming series, said he was inspired to pursue baking when series two was filmed down the road from his house.And lorry driver Phil, , who made it on to the show after three years of applying, said Bake Off reignited his baking bug.ldquoI first got the baking bug in my last year of secondary school [in ], he cheerfully explained.ldquoI was extremely happy bringing home freshly baked bread to share with my family, then it all went quiet until GBBO started.ldquoI didnrsquot take much notice at first, but as the series continued it caught my attention and I was hooked again.The new series, which starts tonight, will see a bakerrsquos dozen of contestants tasked with creating a fruit cake and a showstopper based on their dream childhood birthday cakesin its first episode.The episode even opens with hosts Noel Fielding and Sandi Toksvig, as well as judges Prue Leith and Paul Hollywood, dressed up as characters from The Wizard Of Oz, with Fielding sporting bunches, red glittery shoes and a blue gingham dress as Dorothy, Toksvig dressed as the Scarecrow, Hollywood as the Tin Man ldquowho doesnrsquot have a heart and Leith as the Lion, joking: ldquoI was late, it was the last costume.Marking the th series of the show, the episode includes a montage of previous winners, including Nadiya Hussain, Candice Brown and John Whaite, as Toskvig says: ldquoItrsquos our th anniversary, but who will be our th Bake Off champion While the country is staring down intense political turmoil, Bake Off provides relief when a bit of polite fuss over the density of a fruit cake is about all we can handle. Light and sweet, is it any wonder our appetite for TVrsquos answer to comfort food has endured for nearly a decade The Great British Bake-Off begins on Tuesdayon Channel  at pm.

title: look-bright-side-life-want-live-longer
story: For science has proven that the glass half full side of society ndash optimists ndash do live longer. According to major new research spanning -years, scientists found a clear link between optimism and prolonged le.The findings show that people with greater optimism are more likely to live longer and to achieve ldquoexceptional longevity ndash living to the age of  or even older.Optimism was defined as a general expectation that good things will happen, or believing that the future will be favourable because we can control important outcomes.Previous studies have identied many risk factors that increase the likelihood of diseases and premature death, but much less is known about positive factors that can promote healthy ageing.The latest American study was based on , women and , men.They completed surveys to assess their level of optimism, as well as their overall health and wellbeing habits, such as diet, smoking and alcohol consumption.The women were followed for  years, while the men for  years. When participants were compared based on their initial levels of optimism, the researchers found that the most optimistic men and women had, on average, an  to  per cent longer lespan, and had  to  per cent greater odds of reaching  years old compared to the least optimistic groups.The results were maintained after accounting for age, demographic factors such as educational attainment, chronic diseases, depression and also health factors such as alcohol consumption, exercise, diet and primary care visits.Study corresponding author Dr Lewina Lee, Assistant Professor of psychiatry at Boston University School of Medicine, said: ldquoWhile research has identied many risk factors for diseases and premature death, we know relatively less about positive psycho-social factors that can promote healthy ageing.ldquoThis study has strong public health relevance because it suggests that optimism is one such psycho-social asset that has the potential to extend the human lespan.ldquoInterestingly, optimism may be modiable using relatively simple techniques or therapies.But it remains unclear how exactly optimism helps people attain longer le. Study senior author Professor Laura Kubzansky, of the Hard TH Chan School of Public Health, said: ldquoOther research suggests that more optimistic people may be able to regulate emotions and behaviour as well as bounce backfrom stressors and dficulties more effectively.The findings were published in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

story: Ministers said the South of Scotland Economic Partnershiphas awarded a total of pound,, to five projects ndash including a scheme to improve Galashiels town centre.Rural Economy Secretary act as the catalysts for creating new businesses, providing vital skills, and making the region an even more attractive place to visit.ldquoThe work of SOSEP, the establishment of a new enterprise body for the region, and the poundm we are investing in the Borderlands inclusive growth deal, underline our commitment to continuing to deliver for the south of Scotland and its people.It comes after the latest population estimates published by the National Records of Scotland showed swathes of rural Scotland have experienced decline.Almost  per cent of ldquodata zones ndash small areas used to Berwickshire, Galashiels and Jedburgh.The pound, announced for Philiphaugh Estate will help it ersy and employ more people, as well as improving visitor attractions and collaborating with local Scotland.ldquoFrom wildle to town centre regeneration, these five projects will help support and deliver long-term social and economic benefits to communities in the Scottish Borders and Dumfries and Galloway by creating new businesses, providing vital skills andmaking the region an even more attractive place to visit.ldquoThe economy of the south of Scotland will benefit greatly from this new impetus to stimulate growth and success.A pound.m ldquoBorderlands growth deal was signed in July, aimed at pumping investment into the five local authority areas on both sides of the Border between title: letters-equal-status-crucial-independence-negotiations
story: There are many ways to achieve that,bearing in mind such factors as the present state assets and liabilities, the national debt, the effect of Westminster policies over the past few decades and so on.The idea that Scotland would have to walk off with, for example, a budget deficit of seven per cent of GDP compared to Englandrsquos one per cent, without there being in place other financial compensating arrangements, some which may be spread over some years, is naiumlve nonsense, and the sooner we stop discussing it in those terms the better.Scotland will be well placed to make sure that a lsquogoodrsquo deal is achieved, and it is time we looked at this matter through that equal status prism.Nick Dekker,Cumbernauld:SNP boss faces sack after independence referendum Plan B blockedWHEN Peter A. Russellclaimed that a letter from European Commission official Viviane Reding defined an independent Scotlandrsquos position in Europe I chose to ignore it. However his subsequent insistence that being on official paper meant it was the definitive legal position of the EU left me with no choice but to intervene and correct him .I now note that despite this he still seems to be maintaining his stance that Ms Redingrsquos letter is still ldquothe best available information on the issue. This appears to be on the basis that Alex Salmondrsquos contrary claim is ldquounsupported by independent legal opinion . I would challenge that latter assertion.Ms Redingrsquos letter is itself unsupported by legal opinion. The situation of a member state splitting in two has not occurred in the history of the EU . So there is no legal precedent.However there is a legal precedent to support Mr Salmondrsquos case for a third country joining the EU without the requirement to go through any negotiations or any revision of the Treaties. When East Germany joined the EU in  it was deemed to be effective from the moment unication with West Germany took place. It was seen to be merely the enlargement of an existing member state with the new combined entity being called lsquoGermanyrsquo.:Neil Mackay: Where have all the big ideas on independence gone An independent Scotland would be in a similar situation, but this time as a third country formed by the reduction in size of an existing member state as opposed to enlargement. Unlike East Germany, however, it would already have met all the criteria for membership by dint of having been in the EU for  years. As such it would be unique and therefore unlike any other third country applying for membership. That is the key point.If the Commission stipulated that Scotland would require to apply for membership like all other third countries, it would have to explain to the European Court of Justice why the legal precedent established by East Germanyrsquos accession to the EU was being disapplied in this instance.By any measure this would be an extremely spurious legal argument for the Commission to advance, especially when Scotland has a stronger economy than East Germany had, was fully compliant with EU rules, and was a known and respected European country with no history of secret police involvement. Methinks the average barrack-room lawyer would simply laugh this one out of court.Robert Menzies,FalkirkTHE picture on page six of The Herald , which accompanies the item about the Peoplersquos Vote rally shows five EU flags being prominently waved. To me, this makes it abundantly clear that the only outcome that this campaign would seek would be to overturn the result of the June  referendum.Christopher W. Ide,Waterfoot, East RenfrewshireTHE SNP are up to their old tricks by barely mentioning independence in the Shetland by-election campaign.In the  general election, Nicola Sturgeon insisted the vote wasnrsquot about separatism, won a landslide - and instantly claimed a mandate for indyref. But the  general election came weeks after the SNP leader had formally demanded indyref - and she promptly lost  seats.Now cue the Shetland by-election campaign, at which the SNP are supposedly focused on opposing Brexit. Remember, Shetland voted Remain. Yet rest assured that,the SNP wins or even grows its vote share, Ms Sturgeon will enthusiastically insist that itrsquos an endorsement of her ambition to separate us from the rest of the UK.Martin Redfern, EdinburghINDEPENDENCE is all very well but sometimes an obsession with it gets in the way of everyday concerns.The Heraldrsquos reportwas depressing to read, The rising cost of living, stagnant wages and cuts in benefits are all contributing to the misery of many Scots. I think more of a focus on alleviating such distress should be at the forefront of our much-lauded SNP Governmentrsquos mind.David Brown, Glasgow

title: blackpool-earthquake
story: The tremor at the Lancashire shale gas site was recorded at about .am on Monday and is stronger than those that forced owners Cuadrilla to suspend test fracking in .It is the fourth quake to hit the area since last Wednesday.How bad were the quakes On Wednesday there was a magnitude . tremor, on Friday night there was one measuring . and on Saturday there was a magnitude . quake and yesterdays was the largest one yet at ., with a depth of . miles.People reported their walls and furniture shaking during the tremors, and hearing a "loud roar" for the duration.Cuadrilla, the oil and gas production company that own the site, said it understood the quake "caused concern for local people" but added: "it is worth noting that this event lasted for around a second and the average ground motion recorded was mm per second".:Issue of the day: Operation YellowhammerWhats causing the quakes Cuadrilla said it was investigating the tremor and no fracking was being carried out at the time.The Oil and Gas Authority have suspended fracking for more than the required  hours while it assesses the seismic activity.What is fracking Fracking, or hydraulic fracturing, is the process of drilling down into the earth before a high-pressure liquid is directed at the rock to release the gas inside - gas which is being considered by governments as a potential energy source.Backers, including Westminster, claim accessing the fossil fuel through fracking could reduce reliance on imports, secure supplies, help cut carbon emissions and create jobs.But opponents say it can cause earthquakes, irreparably damage the countryside and keep the UK hooked on fossil fuels instead of focusing on renewable energy to help tackle climate breakdown.Drilling for shale gas is still at an exploratory phase. However, reserves of shale gas have been identied across large swathes of the UK, particularly in northern England. More than  licences have been awarded by the government, allowing firms to pursue a range of oil and gas exploration activities in certain areas.The Scottish Government has a moratorium in place until further research is completed into frackings environmental impact.Campaigners against the invasive gas-extraction technique are calling on Holyrood to place a full-legislative ban on the process so the more fragile policy ban cant be overturned by future governments.:Issue of the day: Greggs on a vegan rollShould we be worried In , Cuadrilla suspended test fracking operations near Blackpool after earthquakes of . and . magnitude hit the area. It resumed last October after campaigners failed to get an injunction.A subsequent study found it was "highly probable" that shale gas test drilling triggered the tremors.Environmental campaign group Friends of the Earth said in  days of fracking last year there were  tremors in Lancashire and that it cannot be carried out without triggering earthquakes.

title: neil-mackay-big-ideas-independence-gone
story: There are two sides ndash Yes and No ndash but no real debate, and certainly no obvious vision. On the Yes side, nothing has substantively changed, when it comes to big ideas, since the SNP laid out its blueprint for independence in .Brexit has altered the backdrop of the constitutional debate, but apart from a decision by SNP members to support the creation of a new currency as quickly as possible after independence, which many Yes voters donrsquot agree with, therersquos been little in the way of political imagination, creativity and innovation. The plan for Citizensrsquo Assemblies was visionary but itrsquos been undermined by SNP politicisation.Thatrsquos not to say that hard work hasnrsquot been done on the nuts and bolts of independence. The SNPrsquos Growth Commission report on the finances of an independent Scotland presented some serious economic thinking, but this is not the stuff upon which visions of new nations are built, this is the stuff of the seminar room.: Neil Mackay:Irsquom a Yes voter, but Irsquom now sick and tired of my own sideThe No side is even worse. All thatrsquos heard from the No camp is the word lsquoNorsquo. Wherersquos their vision of what a Scotland remaining in the union will look like  Brexit has shown both the Tories and Labour to be intellectually bankrupt when it comes to the future of Scotland. Yoursquod get more vision walking around a darkened room with your eyes closed than you would listening to most unionist politicians in Scotland.The new co-leader of the Scottish Green Party, Lorna Slater, seems to share concerns about the level of intellectual debate around the future of Scotland. She too worries about the vision thing.Slater has identied a few problems. Firstly, the impression that the SNP ldquoowns the idea of independence. Many Yes voters donrsquot support the SNP ndash yet itrsquos the SNP which dictates most of the discussion around independence. When a monolithic, managerial party controls debate then the drain on vision wersquore experiencing is inevitable. Whatrsquos good for the SNP in terms of holding on to power isnrsquot necessarily in the best interests of independence.A resurgence of all those grassroots Yes organisations which sprung up as the first referendum approached would provide an intellectual counterweight to the SNP, and a laboratory for new ideas.Slater is also concerned that ldquomuch of the debate around independence has focused on whether or not there should be a referendum. We should be focusing on what we want an independent Scotland to look like.Shersquos right. A second referendum will happen at some stage in the relatively near future, but what really matters,you are a Yes voter, is making sure the vision for the country is in place in order to convince the people that independence is the right course of action when the time comes.Brexit has taught us hard lessons. There was no real discussion, no real vision, about what a post-Brexit Britain would look like. A national conversation needs to begin in Scotland about the kind of country we want to be after independence.What about a constitution  The monarchy  The nature of the army  Our relationship with America  A second parliamentary chamber  Our role in Europe These issues cannot be left up to the SNP. Politicians make decisions in the best interests of their party, not the country. Parties care about power not people.We need to know the substance of what wersquore voting for, rather than the intellectually bereft binary of Yes and No. The Greens are certainly setting out a clear vision for Scotland after independence. The environment will be the top priority, there will be a move away from oil and gas.Of course, the Greens also flatlined on around eight per cent of the vote during the European elections in May. However, that disappointment may account for their renewed push for a big vision for Scotland now.The Greens need to get out from under the shadow of the SNP. Being seen by voters as "the other party which also supports independence" isnrsquot a strategy, especially when Greens can provide a clear, progressive vision for the country which the SNP with its disparate factions cannot.The SNP is ready to splinter into left, right and centre the moment Scotland becomes independent. In the era of climate change, the Greens have a simple and important story to tell which other parties do not.However, honesty is the greatest storyline ndash the strongest vision ndash to present to Scotland. So letrsquos be honest. If Scotland votes Yes to independence in any future referendum, we need to accept that it is inevitable that the nation will need a confirmatory referendum on any deal negotiated with the rest of the UK regarding separation.Dr Alan Renwick, of University College Londonrsquos Constitution Unit, has raised this issue saying that a confirmatory vote would avoid the ldquoacrimony and gridlock of Brexit. He refers to the ldquograve democratic quandary where the public has not been allowed to make ldquoan informed choice about the type of Brexit the country goes through. Renwick suggests opting for a confirmatory vote might increase the turnout for Yes with the public willing to back independence in theory and then see what the politicians negotiate.A future independence referendum would be a ldquopre-legislative ballot, instructing politicians to negotiate a deal which we then vote on. That seems perfectly democratic and the kind of vision we need for this country.:Majority now want Scottish independence, says phenomenal new pollIt immediately shows a commitment to democracy over party politics, a willingness to tackle emotional and isive subjects in a collegiate way, and it projects an adult image of this nation while many other countries seem to be reverting to childhood.The First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and some of her inner circle may be publicly voicing their discomfort with the baggage that comes with the concept of nationalism of late, in an attempt to woo soft No voters, but the one thing which will change swithering minds is honestly tackling the dficulties which the journey towards independence will involve.It will not be easy - it will be hard. Admitting those dficulties is a good way to start presenting a vision of integrity and honour for a new independent Scotland.Neil Mackay is Scotlandrsquos Columnist of the Year

title: oscar-marzaroli-man-captured-forgotten-moments-glasgow-life
story: The photograph is typical Oscar Marzaroli. Taken in , it preserves a moment asin aspic, an anonymous sliver of Glasgow le.But it wasnrsquot part of a y photo shoot. The celebrated photographer was in the city centre to photograph a student rag parade, which at the time was a busy, raucous event. It is alleged that it even featured an elephant.:Le through a lens: the unseen treasures of Oscar MarzaroliYet Marzaroli broke off to capture the quietly transfixed moment for this one shot, the only one of the child in the set of parade negatives.The same photographerrsquos famous image Castlemilk Lads  Again, he took only one.That is one of the reasons why a donation of Marzarolirsquos entire collection of negatives ndash on the th anniversary of his death ndash so excites the archivists at Glasgow Caledonian University . Nobody quite knows what it contains.He has become identied with ndash almost synonymous with ndash photographs of Glasgow in the s, not least after Deacon Blue used several of his images for single and album covers in the s. But Marzaroli worked primarily as a film-maker, making dozens of documentaries for the Highlands and Islands Development Board.His camera was ever present, however, and his photographs are now regarded by many as art.At an event at the university last night, Deacon Blue lead singer Ricky Ross launched a campaign to raise pound, to enable the entire collection to be made freely available online.The money is needed to carry out the work necessary to preserve, catalogue and digitise the images into a searchable online collection.Glasgow subway The image of the child at the bookshop window is one of  original prints, all but one developed by Marzaroli himself, to be auctioned to kick-start the fund in an event which runs until Thursday, September .Italian born, Oscar Marzaroli moved to Scotland at the age of two. He missed out on much formal education and did not go to art school as his brother had, largely as a result of childhood ill-health.He spent a year in Kingussie Sanatorium fighting TB in his late teens ndash there was doubt as to whether he would recover. Soon afterwards he was in a motorcycle accident.:Pictures of the dayldquoHe felt his whole le that he was living on borrowed time, says Marie-Claire Marzaroli, one of his three daughters. ldquoI think it gave him a kind of focus. She argues an egalitarian outlook also contributed to his ability to capture a sense of someonersquos personality.:THOSE WERE THE DAYSS: Oscar Marzaroli, Glasgows patrician with a cameraldquoHe didnrsquot like hierarchies. He would spend the same amount of time with someone, whether he was photographing a big film star or someone selling him fish.Through portraits and landscapes, he captured Scotland and its people at a time of great social change in the s, s and s. Many of his photographs of Glasgowprovide a record of signicant social change, as city slums were being cleared to make way for new social housing.The huge body of work is perhaps surprising given his untimely death on August , , at the age of .During a three-decade search for a permanent home for their fatherrsquos work, Marie-Claire and her sister Nicola say it wasnrsquot until meeting archivist Carole McCallum at GCU that they felt confident they had found a solution that satisfied them and which would have pleased him.Both teachers, they are thrilled at plans to digitise the collection and make it freely available online. ldquoIt was our motherrsquos wish we find the right setting to preserve his legacy and the family are excited by the universityrsquos plans, Marie-Claire says.There is excitement too about what might be found when the negatives are fully catalogued. While there are contact sheets in some of Marzarolirsquos files, only around , of the images have ever been printed up, and there is no certainty about what is contained in many of the negatives.Some spools of film, retrieved from his camera bag, have never even been developed. Nicola says: ldquoThere are so many images, even we do not know what treasures our dad has left hidden in thereLaunching the appeal, singer-songwriter Ross said: ldquoI got in touch with Oscar after I became fascinated with his work, and he ended up coming out with us and shooting some photographs for our first Deacon Blue album in dferent locations.ldquoIrsquod told him about the idea of Raintown and he called me one day to say there was a picture he thought suited it.St Enoch SquareldquoItrsquos the one of the sunshine coming through the clouds. We loved it and our music from that period has been linked to Oscar ever since, he said.University archivist Carole McCallum says the Marzaroli Collection is of international importance. ldquoOscarrsquos photographs are instantly recognisable ndash particularly the iconic images he took in the Gorbals before the tenements were cleared away.Theyrsquove become rooted in popular culture, but people donrsquot realise Oscar worked all over Scotland and further afield both as a photographer and filmmaker. We are tremendously excited about putting the archive online.

Weinstein due in New York court in sex assault caseWeinstein mostly kept quiet during a brief appearance in a Manhattan courtroom aside from some brief exchanges with Judge James Burke, who at one point scolded him for pulling out his mobile phone during the proceeding.After the judge agreed with defence lawyers that the trial needed to be put off so they could have time to respond to the quipped.Weinstein, , who is free on one million US dollars bail, has denied all accusations of non-consensual sex.After the hearing, his lawyers said they would ask the judge to dismiss the accusing him of raping a woman in  and performing a forcible sex act on a dferent woman in .The case remains about those two women, but prosecutors said the new indictment was needed to allow a third woman, Annabella Sciorra, to give evidence.Sciorra, who is best known for her work on The Sopranos, says Weinstein raped her inside her Manhattan apartment after she starred in a film for his movie studio in .:New BBC documentary explores Harvey Weinstein allegationsProsecutors cannot charge Weinstein with the alleged attack on Sciorra because it took place too long ago to be prosecuted under state law, but they want to use her evidence to prove that Weinstein had a pattern of assaulting women.That is necessary to prove the charge of predatory sexual assault.Sciorrarsquos lawyer, Gloria additional witnesses testy  she said.Sciorra went public with her story in a story in The New Yorker in October .Court papers filed by the defence called the attempt to make Sciorra a prosecution title: farmers-hold-key-make-country-greener
story: Farming is hugely important in this debate as over % of land in the UK is farmed in some way or other.The report will have increased the publicrsquos awareness of the interdependence between agriculture and the environment, but not in a manner which will make farmers sleep more easily at night.The challenges set out in the IPCC report come on top of uncertainties in the level and nature of future farm subsidies, and uncertainties in the future for food trade as a result of us leaving the EU.Together they mean that the UK farm sector is facing an existential crisis, which all but The Archers seem to be aware of. Behind the headlines, the IPCC report includes a much more positive message about the potential agriculture has for helping to mitigate climate change.:Fe farmer bids to put buffalo mozzarella on the menuUnlike other sectors, agriculture can, through appropriate changes in land use and new land management practices, not only reduce its greenhouse gas emissions but sequester more carbon, offsetting emissions in other sectors.The same changes in land use and land management will also help stem the decline in bioersity and our natural resources, or what the economist Dieter Helm and others refer to as our ldquonatural capital.In his latest book ldquoGreen and Prosperous Land, Helm argues that protecting and enhancing our environment is one of the best investments that a society can make and that agriculture, with the support of appropriate policies, has a key role in moving us towards a sustainable future.The signs are that, post-Brexit, UK agricultural policy will place more, rather than less, emphasis on the environmental objectives of farming.It follows that farmers should welcome the increased attention being given to the environment.In reality, agri-environmental policies explicitly focused on ensuring farming delivers environmental public goods are not new. However, despite the clear and long-standing policy support for protecting the farmed environment, and notwithstanding recent commitments by farm lobby groups to achieving net-zero production, many farmers see their primary, and in some cases sole, role being that of producingfood.Why is this  In part it could be attributed to the nature of some past agri-environmental schemes.Many have been bureaucratically demanding while others have, inadvertently, included conditions which placed future farm support payments at risk.While some measures have clear environmental gains and are relatively easy for farmers to adopt, eg restoring peat bogs on land, not in productive use, often the schemes are necessarily more complex.:Five Scottish farm-themed wedding venuesNatural habitats need to be connected toeffectively, often across farm boundaries, therefore requiring new levels of co-operation between neighbouring farmers the right sort of trees need to be planted in the right types of land for net positive carbon sequestration to occur, and the time period within which the trees will generate income may not align with a farmerrsquos needs. However, new farming technologies and methods are emerging that will hopefully breakdown this  dichotomy between food production and environmental protection.Another example is agroforestry which provides productivity and welfare benefits to livestock as well as the carbon sequestration benefits from trees.The uptake of these and other agri-ecological approaches is being demonstrated by innovators in the sector and will be supported by UK policies, which recognise the importance of farm-based natural capital.Moreover, disruptive technologies are fast emerging which will provide yet more opportunities for the sector to show its environmental credentials.For example, indoor vertical farming offers huge environmental benefits in terms of reducing food waste, eliminating the need for agro-chemicals in crop production, reducing water requirements, and, by producing food where it is needed, reducing food miles and sparing land. A recent Scottish Government study found that  per cent of the public rated the environment as one of the top three government portfolios that should be prioritised in terms of spending.Agriculture came much further down the list, with just % of the public rating it. In particular, over half of the participants in the forumwanted to see a greater share of agricultural support funding going to support the natural environment. The publicrsquos views were changed. The question is therefore whether farmers will embrace the opportunity Deborah Roberts is director of science at The James Hutton Institute.

title: dons from the don telling it like it is
story: Stand By Your Man!By the time you read this week‚Äôs DFTD, Aberdeen‚Äôs board may have panicked and relieved our manager of his duties.This would be a ridiculously short-sighted move, perhaps temporarily appeasing the sixth-form style thinkers in their creepy chatrooms or the small deluded bunch still loyal to the big loon who enjoys a pint doon the Govan Bowling Club.Indeed the stadium was awash with stories of histo the fold, Heaven forbid. The nine-nil reverse at Celtic Park was undeniably sore and damaging to the football club.However, it was fty-nine minutes of complete and utter madness that saw Celtic convert every one of their attempts on target bar two.It followed a decent half hour for the Dons that included a great chance for Chris Maguire.The game was of the freakish type that beset a far better Dons side at MacDiarmid Park under Alex Smith for example.Paul Hartley knows that he let his new club down but to criticize our skipper would be churlish in the extreme, given what he has already contributed to the cause.It was a miserable afternoon that will have been incredibly welcome for Doogie McDonald, the debacle temporarily removing the untruthful official from the media glare.The heavy loss understandably made Tuesday night‚Äôs Inverness clash take on extra importance but Aberdeen‚Äôs luck was totally out.If anyone thinks any of the Dons players didn‚Äôt give % against ICT they don‚Äôt know football.Watching the game upon getting home from the match you actually started believing that the Dons had to win, given the total dominance in the second half.Inverness took the lead due to simulation of the most repulsive type.The poor referee had a night to forget from beginning to end and the last thing he needed was players feigning and faking.The farcical penalty only served to double the Dons‚Äô resolve.First half additional time was measured at two minutes which means that no injury time was played once factoring in the four yellows that had been flashed in the first period.The second half saw the passing and movement back to what we were enjoying back in August and the goal from Velicka was a belter, sent on his way by the best player of the field by a country mile ‚Äì Scottie Vernon.The ref was given the chance to correct his penalty howler by awarding one to the home team but one assumes he must have been unsighted for the blatant hand-ball.The Inverness winner came from a free-kick that never was at the half way line, poor defending but rough, rough justice on a Dons team that gave everything.There was still time for Foran to try and get Ifil sent off and the game‚Äôs close saw the classless Butcher provocatively gesticulating in front of the RDS, doubly stupid given the pressure on a fellow boss. Mark McGhee was bullish and quite excellent in his post-match interviews on Tuesday.I do hope that the board hold their nerve and properly take into account the budget they have forced their employee to work with and by definition the worryingly youthful squad that has resulted.Standing good for a manageable debt is fine and dandy but more and more fans are scratching their heads and querying why fantastically rich iniduals are involvedthey have no intention of investing in the area‚Äôs only senior football club.Someone called the new ground ‚Äòa vanity stadium‚Äô this week and that is a brilliant description.Great rationale, lousy location.It‚Äôs taken the focus off the football.Mark McGhee will undoubtedly question his own decisions and soul search to get things right at a football club he loves but the great and good need to do likewise.The Dons are on the cusp of a very exciting team in the next couple of seasons but onlyeveryone in the Dons family sticks together.Celtic‚Äôs Anti-Poppy ShameGlasgow Celtic were said to be embarrassed and angered by sections of their support unfurling ious disgraceful banners on Saturday.The club, who has had issues at this time of the year before, ironically has since enjoyed warm plaudits for the swtness of their ‚Äòcondemnation‚Äô.Talk of bans has ensued, but you will forgive mewe file this under ‚ÄòOld Firm Lip Service‚Äô.British Heavyweights No boxing fan would ever claim to have Harrison or Haye anywhere near the all-time British greats type description, but I can‚Äôt help but be sucked into the intrigue as the two Brits go toe-to-toe on Saturday night.Many a sneaky tenner will be placed on Harrison to spring a surprise.Haye will need to take care of business as soon as possible as even Lennox Lewis was twice undone by random rogue punches ‚Äì something always on the radar in this ision.
