title: aberdeenshire part of a new national network to save our sound heritage
story: Unique and rare recordings of Scottish traditional music made in Aberdeenshire in the s through to the s are to be preserved as part of a national initiative led by the British Library.Unlocking Our Sound Heritage is a major ¬£. million sound preservation and access project, which has received a ¬£. million National Lottery Heritage Fund grant.It has seen the formation of the first ever network of ten sound preservation centres, including one at the National Library of Scotland.This UK-wide partnership of institutions aims to digitally preserve half a million of the nation‚Äôs most rare and at-risk sounds and share them as widely as possible.Reel-to-reel tape recordings from the John Junner Collection - recently donated to Live Le Aberdeenshire‚Äôs Museum Service - were selected as one of the Scottish beneficiaries.The full collection comprises musical instruments, recording and playing equipment, and music recordings on wax cylinders, tapes and cassettes.Junnerwas a schoolteacher and esteemed musician from Strachan, Aberdeenshire.An acknowledged authority on the music of James Scott Skinner ‚Äì Banchory‚Äôs famous dancing master, violinist, fiddler and composer ‚Äì he was interested in sound, its mechanical production and reproduction on ious machines.Over the years he recorded many local musicians. His musical collecting and recordings pre-dates the Folk Revival of the s and s and consequently are unique.David Cook, sub-committee chair of Live Le Aberdeenshire, said: ‚ÄúWe are delighted to accept this unique collection of local and national signicance into the permanentcollections of Aberdeenshire Council Museums.‚ÄúWhilst the recordings are in good condition, they are threatened by physical degradation and some are stored on formats that can no longer be played. Being part of this national initiative will ensure some of our local recordings of Scots music will be digitally preserved and available to folk at home and abroad for future enjoyment and learning.‚ÄùAlastair Hardie, one of the trustees acting on behalf of the late John Junner, said: ‚ÄúIn his will, John Junner asked for his collection to be kept ‚Äòat a suitable location in northeast Scotland‚Äô.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Aberdeenshire Provost Bill Howatson said armed forces personnel make huge sacrices to keep us all safe"  Aberdeenshire Council achieves gold award for work with armed forces, families, veterans and cadetsviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"It is claimed the Violet Route for dualling the A could endanger Fyfe House"  Action group ‚Äúappalled‚Äù at threat to Guiding house viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser""Ten years after his death, his wish has finally been fulfilled with this donation. Having the collection in the care of Aberdeenshire Council Museum Service will help to ensure the long-term wellbeing, development and accessibility of the John Junner Collection for posterity.‚ÄùThe major grant from the National Lottery Heritage Fund is allowing the network to develop a range of engagement activities to connect the wider public with their sound heritage. A key element of Unlocking Our Sound Heritage will be an interactive website hosted by the British Library, launching in , allowing listeners to explore a wide selection of recordings.Dr John Scally, Scotland‚Äôs National Librarian, said: ‚ÄúOur sound heritage is under threat as tapes, minidiscs and lacquer, vinyl and shellac discs degrade or equipment to play them becomes obsolete.‚ÄúThis is a vitally important project that will help to save the nation‚Äôs sounds and preserve them to be enjoyed for many generations to come.‚Äù

title: garioch sports centre serves up an ace with new tennis plans
story: With the nation currently hooked on Wimbledon, it#s a fitting time for Garioch Sports Centre to unveil its new tennis-focused proposals.Inverurie Community Council has submitted fresh expansion plans to Aberdeenshire Council on behalf of Garioch Sports Holdings.Full planning permission was secured last year for a major extension of the Inverurie facility, but changes in the community‚Äôs requirements and pressures on funding have prompted a reduced development.Initially the plans would have seen the Burghmuir Drive centre expanding into one of the largest amenities of its kind in Scotland, incorporating tennis courts, a multi-sports arena, fitness suites and an all-weather G pitch for Inverurie Loco Works FC which has now been dropped.But while the scale of the expansion might not be as ambitious, the new plans do reveal tennis courts and improvements for fitness along with an Early Learning Centre for younger children.Thanks to signicant input from Judy Murray ‚Äì mother of tennis stars Andy and Jamie ‚Äì the plans feature three dedicated tennis courts and the centre has committed to a three-year partnership with the JM Foundation, highlighting the commitment of the centre to develop the sport across Garioch.The centre and JM Foundation will work in partnership in upskilling their workforce and identying potential coaches while funding coach education.In a supporting statement the centre writes: ‚ÄúThe matter of securing the appropriate funding for the ious options which have been considered over the last couple of years has impacted upon how the plans have altered with the focus very much now being on the new tennis provision.‚ÄúThe most recent plans reflect the discussions with the Lawn Tennis Association and also Tennis Scotland.‚ÄúThe advice and guidance of Judy Murray has also been pivotal in how the plans particularly for the tennis courts have progressed.‚ÄùThe applicants also believe that despite the downturn in oil and gas and other industries, there is still a demand for its facilities.It reports: ‚ÄúAs many of the activities and programmes now carry waiting lists, there is proof that despite a downturn in many industries the timing is now right to expand in tandem with the growth in participation and the increase in the town and rural residency.‚ÄúAn expansion of the present facility and delivery of its sporting, health title: new staff support for recycling sites but permits also on the way
story: On average, % of materials taken to centres in the area are recycled, with rates ying from % to % at the ious locations. The aim is for all recycling centres to reach % by .Up to  new staff are due to be in place by mid-September and will provide advice and assistance to householders about what can be recycled. The additional roles are part of package of improvements agreed by councillors in January.However, a new permit scheme is also being introduced to move business waste away from recycling centres to create more space for new recyclable materials to improve services to householders.While most businesses pay the necessary fees to dispose of their waste and recycling responsibly, the current open access to recycling centres means some business waste is being presented as household waste so that it can be processed free of charge.To tackle this, a new permit scheme is one of the measures being introduced next year to prevent such abuse. Under the new scheme householders using commercial type vehicles - vans, pick-ups, minibuses or trailers - to take materials to recycling centres will require a permit to do so.The permits will be free of charge and can be used at any of the  recycling centres operated by the council.Households will be able to apply for the free permits in advance and a yearrsquos supplywill be issued at one time to minimise inconvenience.Permits can be applied for online or by post at any time of the year and will be valid for  months.Aberdeenshire Council does not expect the new scheme to have an impact on most householders as permits will not be required for cars, estate cars, people carriers, MPVs or xs, unless they tow a trailer or a horse box.Permits can be obtained for trailers up to  x  ft in size.Certain types of vehicle typically used by businesses will not be permitted at HRCs, specically those over . tonnes gross weight, tippers, tractors, large trailersand vehicles with twin wheels or more than four wheels.Aberdeenshire Councilrsquos Waste Manager, Ros Baxter, said: ldquoThe approval of the new permit system is very good news as it will allow us to make space for more recyclable materials at recycling centres and improve services for householders.ldquoMost households will not be affected by the permit system at all as cars, estate cars, people carriers, MPVs and xs will continue to have unlimited access to recycling centres.ldquoWe are keen to minimise inconvenience to those householders who use commercial type vehicles or trailers to take materials to recycling centres."Only one application is required to get a yearrsquos supply of permits and we have also increased the number of permits to  per year to make sure householders have enough permits to cover the grass cutting season.ldquoWe will be communicating the details of the new permit scheme over the coming months, so there will be plenty of time to apply for the permits before the new scheme starts.ldquoBusinesses will be provided an alternative service at waste transfer stations, and with a lower price for recycling, will be encouraged to segregate and recycle as much of their waste as title: 10 of the strangest uk parking laws
story: Researchers from LeaseVan have revealed some of the most obscure rules that drivers could fall foul of when parking on a public road. Here are  of the strangest UK parking laws to be aware of to ensure you avoid being fined by authorities.. Dont save a spaceUsing wheelie bins, cones or other objects to reserve a parking space near your house or work space could result in a fine, as it may be regarded as causing a dangerous obstruction on the road.ShutterstockotherBuy a Photo. Leave the lights onVehicles parking on a road where the speed limit is more than mph, facing away from the traffic or outside of a designated parking area should technically have their side lights on overnight to help prevent collisions.ShutterstockotherBuy a Photo. Check all mirrorsDrivers and passengers need to check all of their mirrors before exiting a parked vehicle as it is always the responsibility of occupants to ensure opening doors will not impede passing pedestrians, cyclists or other vehicles.ShutterstockotherBuy a Photo. Avoid the pavementParking on the pavement has been outlawed by default in London since the s, unless permission is otherwise granted. title: final flight for flying banker
story: A Royal Bank of Scotland employee who has flown almost , trips in Orkney is celebrating retirement after  years as the UK‚Äôs only full-time ‚Äòflying banker‚Äô.Clocking up more than , journeys on Loganair‚Äôs eight-seat Britten Norman Islander, which provides the Orkney Inter-Isle air service, Anne helped Royal Bank of Scotland customers in the isles branches.Anne served around  to  customers during each visit, from crofters to fishermen to those in the tourist industries.She is only the second person to have held this exclusive role, taking over from Maisie Muir who started the flying service in . Prior to that a banking boat, known as the Otter Bank and skippered by Anne‚Äôs great uncle, docked at each of the islands served by the bank.Officially recognised for her service, Anne was awarded an MBE in  and has worked for the bank for  years, serving customers at the branch in Kirkwall before she took on the flying banker role.Her recent farewell flight was the -minute journey from Westray to Kirkwall, piloted by long-serving Captain Colin McAllister. The aircraft was met with a water cannon salute by the airport‚Äôs fire brigade and Anne was presented with retirement gts and a Loganair membership card entitling her to two freetickets and unlimited ticket upgrades whenever she travels.As Anne left the final flight of her career she was met by Liam McArthur MSP, Bill Spence, Lord-Lieutenant of Orkney, her Kirkwall branch colleagues, Loganair and airport employees ‚Äì who gave Anne a guard of honour as she walked to the terminal.Another resident of Orkney, Lois Canning, who joined Royal Bank of Scotland in  has been appointed to the role. title: next phase of kirkwall thi announced
story: The second phase of works under the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiativeand the Places and Spaces project is due to get underway at the beginning of next month.Orkney Islands Council is reporting that the works include new paving outside the Orkney Museum, a new parking area outside the former Spence‚Äôs newsagent and new paving into Victoria Street.This will take place from September until February, with work suspended through the whole of December to support shopping on the street during the festive period. Free parking of up to one hour will apply as usual in metered car parks over the winter period.Tankerness Lane will be closed to vehicles throughout the works, with one-way systems in place at ious times on Broad Street and Palace Road ‚Äî with Victoria Street closed to vehicles for approximately five weeks from  January . Pedestrian access will be maintained throughout.The council has said the key aspects of the Place and Spaces project are to improve the area at the bottom of the Strynd and top of Castle Street, provide a new path to the war memorial to enhance it as a place to stop and reflect on the signicance of the monument and improve the head of Victoria Street to encourage more people into this part of the¬†town.Depute council leader, councillor Leslie Manson, said: ‚ÄúThe works carried out in Kirkwall‚Äôs town centre through our Townscape Heritage Initiative Scheme have given our streets and buildings a much-needed new lease of le, whether that be improvements to the shop fronts or the attractive new paving at the head of Broad Street.‚ÄúThis latest phase is aimed at improving the entrance to Victoria Street to encourage more shoppers and visitors to take a wander down this street ‚Äî a long-held aspiration of the businesses that are situated there.‚ÄúThere will, of course, be some inevitable disruption, but we‚Äôve worked hard to ensure that this is kept to a minimum, including suspending works for the Christmas period. I look forward to seeing the improvements that are made and the effect these have on our historic streets.‚Äùcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: work set to begin at scapa flow museum
story: Work to restore and improve the Scapa Flow Museum is set to begin next month, Orkney Islands Council has said.This follows a recent decision by the local authority to take forward a revised project at Lyness.The council has said the aim is to concentrate efforts on renovating the historic pump house and on building an extension to the museum, with an Orkney-based company recently appointed to carry out the work. A refurbished and extended museum is expected to re-open during the summer of .Council leader James Stockan said: ‚ÄúThis is a project of tremendous signicance for Hoy and for Orkney as a whole.‚ÄúIt has taken longer than we first hoped to get to this stage and it will be excellent for all involved to see work getting underway soon.‚ÄúI am delighted that, like the council, the project‚Äôs external funders remain fully committed to the scheme.‚ÄúWhen complete, the restored and extended museum will for the first time in many years open all year round, encouraging more people to visit Hoy and boosting tourism throughout the island.‚ÄùThe museum‚Äôs role is to chart Orkney‚Äôs military involvement in the First and Second World Wars and provide a safe home for a major collection of wartime artefacts, many of national and international importance.After a competitive tendering exercise, the contract for the work has been awarded to Orkney BuildersLtd.A temporary exhibition on the wartime history of Scapa Flow is on show at the Hoy Hotel while the museum is closed. This has been part-funded through the Island of Hoy Development Trust.Repairs to the Romney Hut at Lyness and options for the Oil Tank will be considered at a later date.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: border-guards-seen-intercepting-three-dinghies-off-coast-dover
story: Men brought ashore on dinghyBorder guards have been seen intercepting three dinghies containing suspected migrants heading across the English Channel towards Dover.Around  people were seen being taken to a quayside Home Office facility in Dover after the boats were towed towards land by a Border Force cutter.This latest crossing follows a fresh wave of attempts by migrants to travel from France to the UK in small boats.People on board two of the dinghies were initially seen being escorted to shore at around am, closely followed by a third. -- --The Dover coastguard has confirmed they were called out to assist a Border Force operation on Tuesday morning, but refused to comment further.On Friday, Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned illegal migrants that they would be sent backthey risked crossing the Channel.He described the journey as ldquohazardous, adding: ldquoThe UK should not be regarded as a place where you could automatically come and break the law by seeking to arrive illegally.ldquoIf you come illegally, you are an illegal immigrant and Irsquom afraid the law will treat you as such. -- vw,vw,px, px"A group of men are brought to shore by Border Force officers--Responding to the latest incident, Dover and Deal MP Charlie Elphicke said: ldquoThis crisis has been escalating into a summer of chaos on the English Channel.ldquoIt will only end when migrants and traffickers alike know the crossings wonrsquot succeed.ldquoThatrsquos why the French authorities need to get a grip and stop people setting off from France ndash before there is another tragedy in the Channel.ldquoThere also needs to be   surveillance of the French coast ndash so boats are spotted, intercepted and ed carefully and safely back. -- vw,vw,px, px"Border Force vessel Speedwell arrives at the Port of Dover--The Home Office said that on Thursday officials dealt with  people, including at least six children, who tried to reach the south coast of England on small boats.A further  migrants were picked up by French authorities on the same day and escorted back to the continent.The next morning, another  suspected migrants were intercepted on both sides of the Channel.The Home Office have been approached for comment.copy -. title: 5g-fast
story: The Government has announced plans to speed up the roll-out of G technology and improve mobile phone signals in rural areas as part of efforts to increase innovation across the UK.G networks have already begun to launch across parts of the country, with several mobile operators switching on their networks in a number of cities.Here is a look at how the technology works:ndash What is G G is the next generation of wireless mobile connections, following on from the G networks currently used by smartphones across the globe.As the name suggests, this is the fth generation of the network technology. ndash How fast will G be There is no official speed standard for G, but many experts expect it to be up to  times faster than G ndash and therefore potentially faster than home fibre broadband.Ernest Doku, mobiles expert at uSwitch, said: ldquoG is a next-gen network technology that should deliver speeds of up to Gbps ndash on paper, thatrsquos considerably faster than Grsquos top-end speed of Mbps.ldquoIn practice though, as wersquove seen with G, the speeds will likely be well below that but real-world tests do show itrsquos still much quicker than its predecessor.ldquoWhere yoursquoll see a real dference with G is in the speeds you can download Ultra HD and D video. At Grsquos theoretical top speed, you could download an entire GB Ultra HD movie in about  seconds.ndash When is G launching in the UK EE was first to launch its G network ndash at the end of May ndash in six cities: London, Cardf, Belfast, Edinburgh, Birmingham and Manchester, with more to follow before the end of the year and into .Vodafone switched on G in Birmingham, Bristol, Cardf, Glasgow, Manchester, Liverpool and London on July .Three began turning on its G network in August, while O said it will also launch at some point this year.However, the process will be a gradual roll-out, meaning G will not be widely available everywhere for some years to come. -- --ndash How does G work G is made up of unique radio frequencies that are broken up into bands. These frequencies are a lot higher than G, which means they can support a larger capacity.Experts say this means more connected devices can be used at one time.ldquoG tech also has the capacity to handle the surge in demand for bandwidth generated by the Internet of Things boom, Mr Doku said.ldquoG is considered a millimetre wave technology ndash with a shorter wave than G, it has a higher frequency, which gives it a higher bandwidth and consequently ability to handle more data.Experts have also suggested that some potential benefits of this could be the increased ability to operate data-heavy networks, such as those needed to power autonomous vehicles, in years to come.ndash How much will G cost So far, pricing of G plans has ied across networks, with prices higher than G on some networks given that it is a new technology.For example, EE offers a sim-only plan with GB of G data for pound a month, while GB of G data costs pound a month.However, Vodafone has priced its own G plans at the same rates as its existing G offerings.But experts have noted that, as we saw with Grsquos maturation, prices are likely to fall as G becomes more widely available in the years to come.copy -. title: dani garavelli we need to start treating journalism as a quest for truth
story: Nothing better illustrated the point of Dorothy Byrne#slecture than the warped coverage of Boris Johnson in Europe, writes Dani GaravelliThe timing of last week‚Äôs MacTaggart Lecture could not have been more serendipitous.As Channel  head of news and current affairs, and newly-crowned Queen of the Sisterhood, Dorothy Byrne, picked up a sling-shot and hit a succession of media Goliaths, including James Murdoch, squarely between the eyes, a squad of broadcast and print journalists appeared to have embarked on a mission to demonstrate the acuity of her take-down and the urgency of her message.Where to start  On Radio , where John Humphrys and David Davis were chortling like schoolboys over an act of domestic violence  Or on C, where a new reality TV show starring Scarlett Moffatt is gearing up to exploit a Namibian tribe while ostensibly exploring a clash of cultures Maybe we should take a look at the front page of the Daily Mail where an equivalence was being drawn between Prince Harry and Meghan Markle‚Äôs trip in Elton John‚Äôs private plane and Prince Andrew‚Äôs long-standing friendship with the late child sex trafficker, Jeffrey Epstein  Or other headlines on websites which suggested a -year-old ‚Äúwas forced to lose her virginity‚Äù to the former multi-millionaire. Christ, how many times  IT‚ÄôS RAPE, you troglodytes.However discomfiting these examples may be, they have nothing on the disingenuous coverage of Boris Johnson‚Äôs encounters with Angela Merkel and Emmanuel Macron. I mean, we could all see him sitting beside Merkel as protesters screamed ‚ÄúLiar‚Äù and ‚ÄúStop Brexit‚Äù we could all see him stick his feet up on Macron‚Äôs side table like a self-entitled brat .The most inexperienced of analysts would have understood that turning up in Berlin with bluster and braggadocio, but no actual plan B was hardly a masterstroke and that Merkel and Macron‚Äôs agreement to give him a month to come up with aalternative was just a tactic to keep him occupied while they get on with important affairs of state.And yet the Express and the‚Äì cheerleaders for the worst Prime Minister in history ‚Äì presented his bilateral talks as a triumph. The Express carried a photo of him raising his arms behind a fence with the headline ‚ÄúBrexit Victory Salute‚Äù, ashe were Winston Churchill giving his ‚ÄúFinest Hour‚Äù speech rather than a floppy-haired fop back from a European jolly. Thewent with the headline ‚ÄúJohnson Demands Fresh Border Plan‚Äùwhile columnists lined up to explain how he had seen off Macron‚Äôs attempts to intimidate him and had reset the EU negotiations. Neither paper pointed out that Macron reiterated that the Irish backstop was ‚Äúindispensable‚Äù and that this is the position they have held ever since Theresa May‚Äôs withdrawal deal was negotiated.Their spin ‚Äì or as Byrne would doubtless prefer us to frame it, ‚Äúlie‚Äù ‚Äì would be troubling at the best of times but as we are hurtling towards a No Deal, it is utterly irresponsible. At a time when journalists should be pointing out the perils of his misplaced ebullience, many are egging him on, feeding his self-delusion.In her MacTaggart Lecture, Byrne called out the inadequacy of much of our current news coverage and scrutinised some of the reasons for it. She blamed our contemporary leaders ‚Äì May, Johnson and Jeremy Corbyn ‚Äì for refusing to submit themselves to scrutiny as previous leaders including Margaret Thatcher did, and went on to compare the way Johnson does his own pieces to camera as Vladimir Putin-style politics.But she also castigated news organisations for believing audiences no longer crave forensic investigations and for talking down to young people. Citing Carole Cadwalladr‚Äôs Facebook Cambridge Analytica investigation and the popularity of hard-hitting podcasts, she said there was still an appetite for in-depth expos√©s, although she didn‚Äôt point out that they require resources as well as courage ‚Äì and that such resources are not widely available.Finally, Byrne talked fearlessly about the need for more ersity: for more women, certainly but much more pressingly for more BAME employees. Although she rejected the phrase ‚Äúpale, male and stale‚Äù, pointing out that many middle-aged white men make excellent programmes, she said TV made by a clique of posh boys was never going to challenge the status quo. ‚ÄúWhen you change who is making TV, you change TV,‚Äù she said.Much of what Byrne raised, we see in action every day the cabal of male presenters who revel in their outmoded attitudes . And the courting of a younger demographic with nattily-dressed presenters, bite-sized news items and YouTube influencers when what many of those who are politically engaged want is to be confronted with new perspectives on giant issues such as climate change. There are exceptions, of course: Jon Snow stands out as a journalist willing to challenge the prevailing orthodoxy, and Five Live journalist Emma Barnett has earned a reputation for skewering political interviewees.But time and time again, especially in  shows and radio phone-ins, broadcasters yield to the demand of  balance, treating journalism as a stand-off between two opposing sides rather than a quest for truth. Nor is BBC Scotland immune to these problems though much of the new channel‚Äôs output has been admirable, it is still overwhelmingly white. Meanwhile, The Nine has twice invited alt-right mouthpiece Brendan O‚ÄôNeill to spout his anti-scientic climate change-denying views. Shouldn‚Äôt we be better than this As the spectre of a no-deal Brexit casts its increasingly dark shadow, there does appear to be a collective raising of the game. Over the past week or so, the BBC has been running a series of news packages analysing what a no-deal Brexit might mean in terms of the supply of fuel and medicine and the slaughter of animals that can no longer be exported.But as Byrne says, whatever happens with Brexit, our country is undergoing seismic changes and our broadcasters must do much morethey are to play a crucial role in holding those responsible to account. ‚ÄúWe must find courage in this time of crisis,‚Äù the Scot said. ‚ÄúWe must unite to use the power of television to protect democracy because it is being seriously undermined.‚Äù The following day, the Express gave its default response, which was to refer to ‚Äúan online backlash‚Äù invisible to all but them.As Johnson engages in some pre-US trade talk willy-waving ‚Äì insisting he will tell the US president ‚Äúthe NHS is not on the table‚Äù ‚Äì Byrne‚Äôs rallying cry could not be more relevant. As men who couldn‚Äôt be trusted to tie their own shoelaces set the global agenda, the public is being failed. We need journalists to be less cowed. But we also need broadcasting companies to be willing to take risks, and newspaper owners to be interested in the actual news. And we need this to happen sooner rather than later. Because the hour of reckoning is nigh.¬©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: scots humour does exist and here s the proof aidan smith
story: So the Edinburgh Festival Fringe is over for another year and a couple of hundred manic-depressive stand-ups have packed away their joke books with their pill bottles. The quality of the gags seemed well up to standard and I liked this one: #Do you reckon the band Chic ever found any takers for that free cow they were always trying to get rid of #There was keen competition for the best bovine-themed one-liner from: ‚ÄúA cowboy asked meI could help him round up  cows. I said, ‚ÄòYes, of course. That‚Äôs  cows.‚Äô‚ÄùI also smirked at: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs driving Brexit  From here it looks like it‚Äôs probably the Duke of Edinburgh.‚Äù And this: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got an Eton-themed advent calendar, where all the doors are opened for me by my dad‚Äôs contacts.‚Äù Meanwhile the award for the best went to: ‚ÄúI keep randomly shouting out ‚ÄòBroccoli‚Äô and ‚ÄòCaullower‚Äô - I think I might have florets.‚ÄùThe capital, then, remains a centre-for-excellence for comics from all over the globe - the top rib-tickler came from Sweden - and venue for a World Cup of wisecrackery. But does Scotland give anything  to comedy besides the set-up for telling funny stories - leaking church halls and hideously expensive airbnbs  Does it, for instance, have its own distinct, unique, instantly-recognisable sense of humour Are you having a laugh  Of course it does. Caledonian wit is renowned and in Billy Connolly we have one of the funniest men alive, an emeritus professor of hee-haw. By the way, that‚Äôs hee-haw in the original, chucklesome meaning of the phrase, rather than our patter for nothing or very little. And the fact we have patter - an entire lexicon of made-up words, converted words and perverted words - would seem to suggest we‚Äôre absolutely bloody hilarious.Well, the Big Yin doesn‚Äôt agree. ‚ÄúI will get into trouble for this but I don‚Äôt think there is such a thing as Scottish humour,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI have bought books of Scottish jokes and then I go through them and there is nothing Scottish about them. There‚Äôs funny and there‚Äôs not funny, and that‚Äôs the beginning, the middle and the end of it.‚ÄùConnolly makes his remarks in the introduction to another book of Scottish jokes - his own. Maybe this one will confirm the existence of a tartan-trimmed sense of humour because I cannot imagine Connolly‚Äôs gag about the bloke who murders his we emanating from anywhere  in the world.You know it well so I don‚Äôt need to repeat it. If I did repeat it I might get into a whole lot of #MeToo - #MeTae  - trouble. If not his most famous or even his best gag, it‚Äôs certainly his breakout.His very telling of the joke on Michael Parkinson‚Äôs chat show in  - with Parky nervously tightening his tie when Connolly says: ‚ÄúI hope I can get away with this it‚Äôs a beauty‚Äù - speaks of Scottish bravado laced with ach-what-the-hell  fatalism.The central character in the joke - the bumper-off-er - is sardonic but more than that, he‚Äôs - good Scottish word - pawky. The joke is absurd. It is bleak and black. It is grim almost to the point of being macabre. Now, is the Big Yin of today really saying that these are traits with which the Scottish character is unfamiliar  There is local colour: ‚ÄúA close is the entrance to a tenement,‚Äù Connolly advises. Finally, there is resourcefulness - thrt, even - in the corpse being buried bottom-up. Very Scottish, that. The events sound far-fetched but the narrator with the Jesus haircut and the big-collared leather jaikit hints at veracity when he says he was told about them by a man in the street. If they‚Äôre fiction, however, and Connolly did hear the yarn second-hand, then it would seem that there‚Äôs at least one other guy out there with the same sense of humour - Scottish humour - as him.Of course there are many. Connolly‚Äôs Glasgow in particular is full of comedians. They might drive taxis or run pubs or go to the football. Their humour is not affected or aimed at any more of an audience than those in the immediate vicinity. When something bugs them or amuses them they feel compelled to let rip with their point of view. Iniably this is funny.Before the Fringe became overrun with stand-ups, the Olympic-standard test of a comedian was Glasgow‚Äôs Pavilion Theatre. There, would-be wits regularly stfed. Maybe they didn‚Äôt end up being used as bike-racks but they never worked that town again - further proof that Scotland in particular does not have a casual relationship with comedy, knows what it likes, is often funnier than the advertised act . In the years BC - Before Connolly - the funniest man in Scotland to my mind was Lex McLean. Stanley Baxter was a bigger star but ‚ÄúSexy Lexy‚Äù - the only time his history that a bauchle in a bunnet has managed to acquire the epithet - seemed more subversive, the Rolling Stones next to the Beatles. Not that I knew what subversive meant, aged ten .Chic Murray‚Äôs droll observations, tinged with the surreal, continue to inspire, judging by the sample gags from this year‚Äôs Fringe. It was Connolly, though, who took the comedy of Scotland - and often the comedy implicit in being Scottish - onto the world stage. Being Scottish, maybe unfortunately, is funny. It was Frankie Boyle who quipped: ‚ÄúGlasgow was a great choice of venue for the Commonwealth Games - a place where they think Hepatitis B is a vitamin.‚Äù But in Kevin Bridges‚Äô genius joke about the traditions of the ‚Äúempty‚Äù we refuse to become homogenised and certainly not Americanised. Wha‚Äôs like us  Nobody, and none funnier.¬©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: solidarity not subsidy underpins union between scotland and england brian monteith
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...Politicians should nurture ties among people that have more in common than drives them apart, writes Brian MonteithScottish unionists who bang on about a union idend are playing a very dangerous game, one that risks playing directly into nationalist hands and leaving them without arguments for remaining in the United Kingdom.Last week we had the annual announcement of the Government Expenditure and Revenue Scotlandfigures and with it the usual claims and counter claims by unionists and nationalists seeking to gain partisan advantage from the data provided. Please note before I go any further that the information is released by the Scottish Government it is prepared by its own statisticians and carries with it the First Minister‚Äôs seal of approval, even though she could not be bothered to give this key publication the time of day. Over the years the methodology has been refined to take account of any possible gaps in the information presented, while politically motivated hoaxes, such as the whisky export tax, or ‚Äúmissing‚Äù allocations of public spending projects like Crossrail and HS have been debunked. Importantly, allowance is also made for looking at the figures with or without tax revenues from oil and gas production.The essential finding was that for the period of - Scotland had a public sector deficit of ¬£. billion, slightly down on the year before. Average tax revenue per head was demonstrated to be ¬£ lower in Scotland than in the rest of the UK, while spending per head has climbed to ¬£,. Put together, these two figures define the fiscal transfer of ¬£, per man woman and child that takes place seamlessly between the UK Treasury and the Scottish Government, including apportioned UK spending for defence and other mutual services Scotland benefits from.By themselves the GERS figures cannot and do not sayan independent Scotland could be economically sustainable. What they tell us is where the likely starting point would be were we to decide to leave the UK, before any changes could be made in Scottish government policy to alter the existing landscape. There would be notional Scottish spending of ¬£.bn supported by an income of only ¬£.bn ‚Äì giving the estimated deficit of ¬£.bn. Against Scotland‚Äôs Gross Domestic Productthe deficit was  per cent, compared to a deficit of . per cent for the UK. To put this in context Scotland would have the largest deficit as a share of GDP in the developed world, certainly the worst in Europe and way beyond the EU‚Äôs guideline limit of  per cent for its members.Taking account of the regional figures available via the UK‚Äôs Office of National Statistics there can be no doubt that Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland provide a deficit against England‚Äôs surplus that leaves the whole UK in deficit, albeit reducing. Given the foregoing, Scotland‚Äôs receipt of this fiscal transfer is obviously not unique, indeed within England itself the tax revenues from the three regions of London, the South East and East notionally transfer to support all the other English regions, including the North West, North East, Yorkshire and West Midlands.This is the nature of fiscal transfers, where economically prosperous nations or regions fund a pool that is used to support those parts of the UK that are enduring harder times. Contributions and withdrawals to and from this pool will y over time, with some requiring help one year ‚Äì or even decades ‚Äì while at other times being the source of community municence.It is dangerous to justy participation in a country purely on economic terms while ignoring the greater historical, social and cultural bonds or strategic interests that make an entity greater than the sum of its parts. It is a good thing that when oil revenues collapsed the UK was able to ensure there was no catastrophic impact on Scottish public finances ‚Äì as there would have beenScotland had voted for independence in . It is not a good thing for Scotland to run a large deficit and be reliant on the UK to make that forever possible.To justy Scotland‚Äôs place in the UK because it receives a ‚Äúunion idend‚Äù of nearly ¬£, per person is like accelerating towards a blind summit, unaware of the hard landing that awaits politically.If unionists rely upon a figure to define the union idend then they must accept that correspondingly there will in some years be a union premium ‚Äì a time when Scotland‚Äôs allocated tax revenues are greater than the spending it makes. Personally, I think this is a good thing, for it is what the union idend is really all about. It is a process, not a number a process that is built upon British solidarity, a shared experience of helping each other in times of great need from our hardest endeavours, creative genius or even just fortunate bounty.Indeed we can see from the official figures over the last  years that there have been times when Scotland has contributed to the maintenance of the UK and others when it has itself been supported. Since  Scotland has contributed a net ¬£bn to the UK in real terms ‚Äì a figure that shall undoubtedly be cancelled out by next year‚Äôs GERS figures. I know it is hard to imagine at a time when the SNP Scottish Government demonstrates with impressive regularity its ability to miscalculate it own economic forecasts and deliver poorer results in too many sections of the pubic services year-on-year ‚Äì but the deficit could eventually change were the politicians to alter their centralising and incompetent ways.The private sector of the Scottish economy does relatively well despite the Scottish Government, rather than because of it. It could, with a change towards lower taxes and fewer regulations, achieve greater results and therefore contribute higher revenues while spending is restrained. When that day comes where stands the argument about the union idendit is measured by price alone How then will the argument fare that we should remain in the UK because of the Union Dividend when the GERS figures allow the SNP to complain about a similarly ridiculous ‚ÄúUnion Premium‚Äù  Unionist politicians should stop focussing on the number and start concentrating on the shared benefits of giving and receiving help amongst people that have more in common than drives them apart. They should instead talk about how the deficit is reduced and how Scotland can help the weaker parts of the Union just as we have been helped when we needed it.Brian Monteith MEP is editor of ThinkScotland.org¬©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: picture gallery oscar marzaroli s priceless photos of a bygone glasgow returning home
story: His photographs of children playing around the tenements in the Gorbals and people going about their daily lives in the s are regarded as being some of the most evocative and iconic ever taken of le in Glasgow and the west of Scotland.Now the priceless photography of Oscar Marzaroliare ing to Glasgow, his adopted city, after his family donated his works to Glasgow Caledonian University.Italian-born Marzaroli moved to Scotland with his family at the age of two and later attended Glasgow School of Art. He died aged .Through portraits and landscapes, internationally-celebrated Marzaroli captured Scotland and its people at a time of great social change in the s, s and s. City slums were being bulldozed to make way for new social housing and his images perfectly encapsulate the atmosphere of hope and trepidation surrounding those fundamental shts in society.On the st anniversary of his death, the university is launching a ¬£, fundraising campaign aiming to have the entire collection of approximately , images made freely available online.A selection of original prints developed by Marzaroli are being offered to the highest bidders in an online auction, which is now open and runs until  September.Marie-Claire Marzaroli, one of his three daughters, said: ‚ÄúWe are thrilled our father‚Äôs archive has found a permanent home at Glasgow Caledonian University.‚ÄúIt was our mother‚Äôs wish we find the right setting to preserve his legacy and the family are excited by the university‚Äôs plans to make the photos available online.‚Äù Her sister Nicola Marzaroli added: ‚ÄúThere are so many images, even we do not know what treasures our dad has left hidden in there.‚ÄùHis work reached a wide audience in the s when Scottish band Deacon Blue famously used his images on the sleeves of their hit records. Singer and songwriter Ricky Ross spoke of his personal connection with Marzaroli at a special event to celebrating the archive‚Äôsarrival and the launch of the fundraising campaign.‚ÄúOscar‚Äôs work is part of Scotland‚Äôs social history. I got in touch with Oscar after I became fascinated with his work, and he ended up coming out with us and shooting some photographs for our first Deacon Blue album in dferent locations. I‚Äôd told him about the idea of Raintown and he called me one day to say there was a picture he thought suited it. It‚Äôs the one of the sunshine coming through the clouds. We loved it and our music from that period has been linked to Oscar ever since.‚ÄùUniversity archivist Carole McCallum said the fundraising was need to preserve, catalogue and digitise Marzaroli‚Äôs work.‚ÄúOscar‚Äôs photographs are instantly recognisable. They‚Äôve become rooted in popular culture but people don‚Äôt realise Oscar worked all over Scotland and further afield both as a photographer and filmmaker.‚Äù¬©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: jets flew empty for 500 miles to pick up royals for aberdeen visit
story: Two empty jets were flown on behalf of Flybe some  miles as part of taking the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and their children to Aberdeen on Thursday, The Scotsman has learned.The revelation comes days after William and Kate were praised for using an economy flight from Norwich when Prince Harry and  Meghan have been criticised for a series of private jet trips.It is understood the empty flights made by the two -seat aircraft cost around four tonnes of carbon.An aviation source with knowledge of what happened said the plane which normally flies the route had been replaced by a Flybe-branded aircraft in an attempt to maximise press coverage for the company.Eastern Airways, which operates the route for Flybe, confirmed to The Scotsman it swapped a Loganair plane normally used for the flight for another of the same type of jet with Flybe markings. Eastern said this was so it would be ‚Äúwholly compliant and in control of the operation‚Äù.The substitution involved an empty Embraer  jet being flown some  miles from Humberside airport to Norwich to pick up the Royal party and regular passengers.Loganair‚Äôs own Embraer plane then also flew empty some  miles from Norwich to Aberdeen so it could operate the next flight back to Norwich.The Glasgow airline has been subcontracted by Eastern since February for weekday flights on the route.The source said: ‚ÄúAn Eastern Airways jet was flown empty from Humberside to Norwich and then flew the scheduled flight to Aberdeen with the Royals on board.‚Ä¢ : William and Kate catch budget ¬£ FlyBe flight to Scotland with royal children‚ÄúThe Loganair aircraft which normally flies this route for Flybe and Eastern flew from Aberdeen to Norwich as usual but then flew empty from Norwich to Aberdeen.‚ÄúI guess it was to ensurethey had any Press coverage of the Royal travel, an aircraft with a Flybe logo flew them.‚ÄúHeck of a carbon footprint to achieve it ‚Äì not exactly environmentally conscious.‚ÄùRoyal author Phil Dampier had said: ‚ÄúThe contrast between William, Kate and family travelling on a budget flight to Scotland and Harry and Meghan using private jets couldn‚Äôt be starker.‚ÄúAt the very least they know they would have been criticisedthey had taken a private jet.‚ÄùFlybe said the decision to change the aircraft had been Eastern‚Äôs. It declined to comment on the claim that the switch was to gain publicity.Its spokeswoman said: ‚ÄúWe were delighted to welcome the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and their family on board one of our flights again, this time operated by our franchise partner, Eastern Airways.‚ÄúPlease note that operational decisions generally are managed exclusively by Eastern on any route they operate under the franchise agreement, hence we are not in the position to comment.‚Äù‚Ä¢ : Duke and Duchess of Sussex share new image of baby Archie Mountbatten-WindsorEastern Airways said it had chosen to switch the aircraft after being told the Royal party had booked onto the flight.General managerRoger Hage said: ‚ÄúFollowing a call and details provided late evening on Wednesday as to members of the Royal Family having been booked onto the service, and that armed Royal Protection Officers would accompany the family on-board, we elected, given this service is operated for Flybe by Eastern, to provide our own aircraft and crew, given the approvals and clearance required  to accommodate such.‚ÄúThis then assured ourselves on our own Air Operators Certicate that we would be wholly compliant and in control of the operation in accordance with associated regulation.‚ÄúHence we positioned an aircraft on a short -minute leg to facilitate the above.‚ÄùAn Eastern Airways spokesperson added: ‚ÄúEastern Airways can confirm any decision as to which aircraft operated the Norwich-Aberdeen service on Thursday morning was entirely that of Eastern Airways and not that of Flybe and apologies to Flybe for any resulting confusion. Decisions taken wereto ensure operational control and responsibility remained that directly of Eastern Airways.‚ÄùA Loganair spokesman said: ‚ÄúOur aircraft have operated the [Norwich-Aberdeen] route on weekdays since we took on this commitment in February.‚ÄúAny comment on tasking requests in relation to the contract is a matter for our customer.‚Äù¬©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: main stands down as shetland manager
story: Outgoing Shetland manager Kevin Main.The Shetland football team are looking for a new manager after Kevin Main decided to step down from the role.This comes just over a week after his side regained the Milne Cup in a dramatic penalty-shootout win over Orkney.Main had been in charge of the Shetland team for the last four years, and said that he had decided the time was right for someone  to step in and lead the squad towards the next Island Games in Guernsey.This decision #certainly was in my mind for a few months,# he said, and he added that last month#s win over Orkney had #confirmed things in my mind# in regards to his decision.He said he had talked over the decision with a few of the team#s senior players before telling the whole squad that he would be standing down.#I thanked them all,# he said.Main refused to be drawn over who would replace him, or who he might like to take on the job next, but he said: #anybody that comes in will inherit a fantastic bunch of players#.He said that although he will take a short break from the sport, he will #not be far from Shetland football#. raquo..

title: goodlad claims conservatives are only party to stand up for fishing

title: by election hustings updates as candidates clash
story: The first of the two by-election hustings is currently underway in Mareel#s auditorium.Eight of the prospective candidates are in attendance at the hustings, with Ukip#s Stuart Martin still on the mainland and the Conservative#s Brydon Goodlad unable to attend due to medical reasons. He is being represented by Conservative MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston.BBC Radio Shetland#s John Johnston is hosting the event, with all eight candidates being given a minute to introduce themselves and their policies before moving on to audience questions.Independent candidate Ian Scott provided an impassioned speech, saying that he has¬†#stood specically steadfastly against the cuts, the Tories, the Liberal Democrats‚Äù before. He also reacted angrily to the news that Mr Goodlad could not be in attendance, shaking his head as Mr Halcro Johnston explained his absence.SNP candidate Tom Wills began by saying that #Shetland is ready for a change# and asked for  months to show what he can achieve in Holyrood, while Lib Dem competitor Beatrice Wishart opened her speech with a defiant message: #If you want an MSP who will speak up for Shetland, I‚Äôm your woman#.The first question of the night revolved around transport, with Ms Wishart and Mr Wills clashing immediately, interrupting each other#s answers as Mr Johnston appealed for both candidates to let the other finish.Mr Halcro Johnston responded to Mr Wills# five-point transport plan by saying that #Tom Wills¬†has a load of great ideas but they won‚Äôt be delivered#, while independent candidate Ryan Thomson added that #nothing gets done‚Äù because ‚ÄúShetland is the pawn‚Äù in mainland politics.Councillor George Smith directed a question at Mr Wills, asking him how he expected the SIC to afford one of his election pledges, free foot passengers on inter-island ferries.Mr Wills responded to say that this could be paid for #, and when# the Scottish government provided additional funding to the council.Mr Thomson criticised the NorthLink ferries in response to a question about increased capacity on the ferries. He focused his attack on the much-maligned sleeping pods, not for the first time, saying that we had been #lumbered# with these pods and said he was reticent to even call them pods, instead saying #it#s a chair#.#Bigger ships# and #daytime sailings# were potential solutions that Mr Thomson suggested as alternatives.On the subject of Brexit, only Conservative representative Mr Halcro Johnston said that he was in favour of Brexit, although he admitted that he voted to remain in the EU.Mr Scott and Mr Wills attacked the coalition of the Tories and the Lib Dems, with Mr Scott saying that the #Tories and Liberals approved austerity and that they had¬†#turned to the racists and the fascists# which garnered wide applause.Mr Halcro Johnston responded to say it was #always very amusing listening to Ian but I‚Äôm afraid he‚Äôs wrong#, which was met negatively by the audience.Mr Wills said that the SNP #could stop Brexit#, and added thatthey were pulled out of the EU by Westminster then a vote for independence could put Scotland back into the European Union.He expanded on Mr Scott#s point by saying the #reason why people voted for Brexit is because of the coalition of Lib Dems and Tories which approved austerity# to a rapturous reception. Ms Wishart responded to the issue of Brexit to say that it was #time for a peoples vote and time for people to work together across parties# to stop Brexit.Scottish independence was the next topic up for debate, and understandably provoked perhaps the most isive reactions of the night.Mr Scott, Mr Wills and the Green Party#s Debra Nicolson all came out in favour of an independent Scotland, while Mr Halcro Johnston, Ms Wishart and independent Peter Tait were against it. Both independent candidates, Michael Stout and Ryan Thomson, said they would wait to see what benefit Shetland could get from Scotland becoming independent before deciding how to vote, should another referendum come up.Mr Scott#s positive attitude towards independence was because, he said, # nothing  we#ll get rid of these damned Tories#.Ms Wishart wanted the audience to #imagine the chaos#Scotland tried to break up the union, citing Brexit as an example. She said the vote was supposed to be #once in a letime# and that there were better priorities for funding, such as healthcare.Mr Wills responded to this point: #which has been cut by the Tory Liberal coalition#, to audience applause.Conservative representative Mr Halcro Johnston said that #I think SNP talk about independence because its easier than talking about their failings#, and added that nobody would be surprised to find that he was against independence.I#m sorry, Tom Wills is havering. Independence will not keep Scots in, or bring us back into, the EU. EvenBritain stays in, Scotland will leave, automatically, with #No Deal#, on Independence Day and will have to reapply to join. The EU has confirmed this, in writing.Also,nothing changes, our starting budget deficit will be ¬£. billion per annumversus the EU#s limit of about ¬£ billion . The UK will stop paying funding that.We shall have to cut spending raise taxes by some ¬£ billion p.a. on an annual budget of about ¬£ billion, to satisfy the EU#s economic conditions for joining.That means we shall face years of withering austerity, just when we need to spend more to stimulate the economy.We also need to set up our own independent central bank which the nationalist think tank #The Common Weal# says will take nine years from an Indy Yes vote. So we shall be out of the EU, with #No Deal#, for at least, seven years from Independence Day.Scots are canny folk. They will not vote for such an independence prospectus.John, your oft repeated notion that an independent Scotland will start with a budget deficit of ¬£. billionis an entire fancy. Whatdebt an independent Scotland may have to take on as a share of the current UK#s debt, in the event of Scotland becoming independent, will be a matter for negotiation and agreement . Similarly, matters such as whether, and for what fees , the rest of the former UK might be permitted to retain its weapons of mass destruction on Scottish soil will be for negotiation agreement in the event of Scotland becoming independent.I would not hold my breath waiting for their answer.Ian Scott and Tom Wills have very selective memories. The austerity cuts introduced by the last Conservative  Lib Dem coalition were in response to the mess Brown and Blair made of the British economy. The outcome of this prudent handling of the deficit was obviously popular with the British people because David Cameron‚Äôs government won an overall majority in the subsequent election. David Cameron also delivered on another election pledge to have an in out referendum on Europe. How can the SNP criticise any party for that they have never delivered on an election pledge in their le. Finally, the only racism and fascism that has come out of this by-election has been promoted by the SNP anti-English racism. The SNP are Tartan Fascists.It#s like I wasnt even there.No mention of Labours position on Brexit or Independence. Thanks guysYou#ll have to listen tonight folks, there isnt even any mention of VE which was discussed@Brian Hill, It is you who fantasise, not I. I did not mention #national debt#. So let#s set aside the #smoke and mirrors#. I am talking about the ¬£. billion gap between Scottish tax revenue raised last year and money received from Westminster. We have been running similar, sometimes larger deficits for many years. Unless something changes this will become our annual budget deficit on obtaining independence as Westminster will no longer fund the shortfall.Don#t take it from me. A couple of years back, the SNP#s own Sustainable Growth Commission conceded that we would start independence with a budget deficit of .% of our GDP, around ¬£. billion per year, and proposed a multi-year plan to reduce it to less than %, which just happens to be the EU#s maximum permissible limit...

title: mowi pledge to tackle smell and noise issues at kyleakin fishfeed
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoineFor several months local residents, particularly on Old Kyle Farm Road, have been concerned about the strong smell emanating from the facility, and also the noticeable humming and bleeping noises at night.On Tuesday of this week an open day was held at the plant, which employs over  people, to reassure locals that the issues are being dealt with.Senior Mowi managers Peter Nilsson and Claes Jonermark were on hand to explain what has been done to date and what they plan to do over the next few months.As far as the night-time noises are concerned, they come from feed boats that are using their own generators for power and from reversing alarms from attending vehicles.Mr Nilsson said an onshore power supply would be installed and reversing lights quietened to cut out the noise. This would be completed over the next two or three months, he said.On the issue of smell, the two sources are from the -metre chimney and from the hatches of the fish meal boats. The former was cleaned out last week after contaminants were discovered inside the base of the stack, said Mr Jonermark, and the amount of bacteria used to pury the air in a filter chamber has been increased. Highland Council would be approached to seethey would agree to a -metre extension to the height of the chimney.As far as the feed boats are concerned, Mr Nilsson said the problem arises when the hatches are opened so that the fish meal can be delivered to the plant. This will occur for about  hours per year, he said, and the firm is currently working on a solution to that.Mr Jonermark added: #We do not want this to be a problem for anyone. We do not want this situation to continue.#We want to make a positive contribution to the village and we will continue to invest to make sure the problems go away. By next summer the plant should be quiet and there should be no smell.#

title: new stamp celebrates beauty on our doorstep
story: A much-loved beauty spot just a few miles from the centre of Ballymena has been celebrated on a new set of stamps that show off the beauty of the UKs forests. Glenarfe Forest Park‚Äôs famed Ess Na Grub waterfall is featured on the pound. stamp released to coincide with the th anniversary of the Forestry Commission.Amazingly, despite the proximity of the Forest Park to the town, a surprisingly large number of local people have admitted they‚Äôve never been there!Well, they don‚Äôt know what they‚Äôre missing!Glenarfe offers much more than a walk amongst the trees.Aside from its breathtaking waterfalls walk - ideal for selfies - the park boasts superb ‚Äòhigh walks‚Äô with wonderful views out towards Scotland.In the past few years, large sections of the forest have fallen victim to tree diseases but the resulting cutbacks have added to the rugged nature of the terrain andyou are looking for a tough but rewarding ‚Äòwellbeing walk‚Äô, don‚Äôt miss it!The Forestry Commission is a non-ministerial department of the government which manages forests owned by the public and also regulates public and private forests in England. It is responsible for protecting, improving and expanding forests and woodland in England. Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland look after their own woodlands.The Forestry Commission was founded on  September . Its job was to reforest the UK for timber after World War One had devastated huge areas of land for the war effort. Philip Parker from the Royal Mail said about the new stamps: On the Forestry Commissions centenary these striking new stamps celebrate the beauty and tranquillity of our public woodlands, and the inspiring range of environments which receive hundreds of millions of visits each year.Other forests featured on the new stamps are Glen Affric in Inverness-shire, Sherwood Forest in Nottinghamshire, Westonbirt in the National Arboretum in Gloucestershire, Coed y Brenin in Gwynedd, and Kielder Forest in Northumberland

title: prevention programme aimed at stopping diabetes surge
story: A programme to tackle the increasing prevalence of type  diabetes by PHA is operational across the Ballymena area.Approximately , people are living with diabetes in Northern Ireland, a startling .% increase since [].Type  diabetes accounts for % of all cases of diabetes and is a serious and progressive condition. The disease can lead to early loss of le, cause preventable sight loss in working age people, and is a major contributor to kidney failure, heart attack, stroke and even amputation, yet the illness is often preventable by adopting healthier lestyle changes.The new Diabetes Prevention Programme is aimed at people who have been identied as pre-diabetic ‚Äì those who have been tested and have a blood sugar level slightly above the normal range ‚Äì by their nurse, pharmacist or doctor.Cullybackey patient Thelma Shanks from Cullybackey was referred onto the programme this year. She said: ‚ÄúThere is a history of hypertension and diabetes in my family. ‚ÄúSeveral of my paternal aunts sadly passed away due to complications that came with the disease, and my mum was found to be diabetic following admission to hospital for routine tests. ‚ÄúI was born in London, but grew up in my parent country, Jamaica. I ed to the UK for good in , and my husband and I moved to Northern Ireland, where all my children were born, in . ‚ÄúAs a nation, we from the Caribbean tend to be a bit more susceptible to diabetes than others, so it wasn‚Äôt a complete surprise to be told I was at risk of developing the disease. ‚ÄúI am also a trained doctor so despite having given up my profession when I had children, I have knowledge of the medical risk.‚ÄúI have a wonderful busy family le. I have four children, all of which I home schooled, and of course, their needs always came before mine. ‚ÄúWhen you‚Äôre running a busy house and looking after everyone  it‚Äôs easy to forget to look after yourself. However, in  when I heard that a health fair was coming to the area I decided to go along. For a small fee they carried out multiple tests which showed I had hypertension or high blood pressure. ‚ÄúI decided to make an appointment with my GP who put me on a number of drugs, first Irbesartan, then Amlodipine and finally a diuretic to bring my blood pressure under control.‚ÄúI realised I needed to be more careful with my diet and tried to be a bit healthier but I admit it was a bit half-hearted. TESTS‚ÄúMy blood sugar levels were border-line they weren‚Äôt going down but they weren‚Äôt going up either, so I thought everything was all right. I was having routine check-ups with my nurse at this stage so I was on her radar and having blood tests taken intermittently. In April  I had my regular tests done and then hopped on a plane to London. ‚ÄúIt was my daughter‚Äôs birthday and I had decided to treat her by going away for the week. We had just made it to the hotel when I received a phone call from my nurse. ‚ÄúShe said tests showed my sugar levels were up and I was actually diabetic, which was the wake-up call I needed. Let‚Äôs just say it wasn‚Äôt quite the luxury week that I had planned! My daughter certainly ate well, but no sugar passed my lips that trip. ‚ÄúNeedless to say, I had the blood tests repeated soon after our , and was delighted to learn that due to my dietary sacrices, my blood sugar levels had again receded into the ‚Äòpre-diabetic‚Äô band.‚ÄúPrior to our trip away, my doctor had called me. She said there was a new Diabetes Prevention Programme starting soon in my area being run by the Public Health Agency. She askedI would be interested and of course I agreed.‚ÄúThe class has  others in it and we meet on Wednesday afternoons. There are eight women and two men, and together we re-learn what we should be eating, what to avoid, and how to step up our exercise routines. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve found it really helpful because everyone is in the same boat and we can share our experiences and encourage one another. ‚ÄúEach week we build on the goals of the previous weeks, paying attention to diet and exercise and gaining strength from each other.‚ÄúI used to believe that running after a busy family was exercise enough but now I‚Äôm walking every other day, trying to increase my pace and my distance. My daughter and I often walk together and I try to keep up with her. LONG TERM‚ÄúOne day I managed , steps in one walk and  of those miles were uphill. I‚Äôm trying to make long term changes and make sure these become habits I‚Äôll stick to for the rest of my le. So far I‚Äôve lost  kg, and my exercise levels have increased signicantly too. My blood sugar levels have decreased, but more importantly I feel better physically and psychologically. ‚ÄúThe Diabetes Prevention Programme and the team who deliver it have been amazing. I‚Äôm looking forward to seeing a new me at the end of the nine and a half month course.‚ÄùThelma was referred onto the Diabetes Prevention Programme by her GP Dr Jean McCaughern, Maine Medical Practice, CullybackeyThe practice serves around , patients that live within a six mile radius of the surgery. Dr Jean McCaughern joined the surgery around  years ago and was placed in charge of the practice‚Äôs diabetes clinic.At first she managed this alone, today she heads up this specialist clinic with the help of two practice nurses. She does this alongside her normal GP responsibilities.She said: ‚ÄúWhen I first started the clinic around % of our patients were diabetic and that included those who had both type  and type  diabetes. Today that figure has more than doubled. In  we have a prevalence rate of .%. That‚Äôs how quickly the disease is on the rise. ‚ÄúOften patients don‚Äôt realise just how serious the illness is. I have overheard patients saying ‚ÄòI just have a touch of diabetes‚Äô or ‚ÄòI only have diabetes‚Äô, but it‚Äôs a serious illness which can cause deterioration of vision, contribute to heart disease, kidney disease, stroke, and vascular problems which at their worst can lead to amputation.‚ÄúPatients of mine have had all these problems and more. The reality is dferent to the perception and it‚Äôs only when dficulties start that people begin to understand what living with diabetes can mean. The longer you have the disease, the more likely you are to have any one of those complications.‚ÄúHaving diabetes presents practical problems too. In some cases the DVLA can revoke people‚Äôs drivers licensestheythey believe there is poor management of diabetes. This can include raised sugars, but more importantly sugar levels dropping and causing confusion in patients as is would be unsafe to drive.‚ÄúFor some people having diabetes is out of their control. Those with Type  diabetes have no choice but to manage it using medication. ‚ÄúFor others who spot heightened blood sugar levels early, termed pre-diabetic, they have a window of opportunity to reverse or delay a diagnosis of Type  diabetes through healthy eating and exercise. That‚Äôs who the Diabetes Prevention Programme is aimed at and who it can help.‚ÄúOnce higher sugar levels are discovered, the earlier people can make changes and the higher the chance they have of reversing the outcome. Sometimes, it‚Äôs not about changing the diagnosis but delaying it by a decade or so. ‚ÄúThe longer you can hold it off the longer you can hold off the complications that come with it. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not all bad news though, having diabetes, whether Type  or Type , is largely manageable either by medication, treatment or diet. ‚ÄúInsulin, used primarily for treating type  diabetes, lowers blood sugar levels when diet and exercise alone aren‚Äôt sufficient, but the effectiveness of these medications depends on how early the disease is diagnosed and the size of the dose.‚ÄúI was happy to get involved in the Programme. Having an interest in diabetes I was approached by the Public Health Agency at the operational stage to look at the programme‚Äôs viability in my area. I‚Äôm a big supporter. ‚ÄúSo far I‚Äôve referred around  people from the practice onto the programme which educates and empowers people of the contents of foods, the need to exercise and develop better eating patterns. ‚ÄúOften I‚Äôve heard people say once they have to go on a special diabetes diet but that‚Äôs not the case, it‚Äôs just healthy eating, it‚Äôs the way we should all be eating.‚ÄúAs far as the success of the programme goes, it‚Äôs a little early to tell. The first cohort of people started on the programme in May and early results are positive. Certainly weight loss as a group has occurred and people have more knowledge of food, portion control and exercise.‚ÄúSo, there are benefits for all and for some the course is working really well. When you join the programme as a group you bond as a group, you encourage each other, you don‚Äôt want to let your group members down. ‚ÄúThat shared experience and cohesiveness is a real motivator and works across all ages and all groups. For many the programme offers them a chance to turn a future diagnosis around and gives them the tools to change their future. ‚ÄúThat can be le changing and what the programme is designed to do‚Äù.KEY FACTSThe Diabetes Prevention Programme is run by the Public Health Agency.It is aimed at people who have been identied as pre-diabetic ‚Äì those who have been tested and have a blood sugar level slightly above the normal range ‚Äì by their nurse, pharmacist or doctor.The Diabetes Prevention Programme is delivered over a nine month period and is free of charge.It is facilitated by health coaches who offer help and assistance to participants, helping them change their lestyle, diet and physical activity with the aim of postponing and even preventing type  diabetes.For more information on the ‚ÄòDiabetes Prevention Programmeemail your local Health Trustdiabetespreventionni@northerntrust.hscni.netst

Mr Cinnamon, said: ‚ÄúIt is an exciting step for us to launch our inaugural ‚Äònew concept‚Äô store here in Banbridge. This state-of-the-art design will allow us to streamline our processes and enhance our customer shopping experience even further while still offering top quality products at market-leading prices. ‚ÄúAnd this is just the beginning for us we will continue to invest in new stores and modernisations over the coming months and years, bringing the best of Northern Irish produce to customers in towns and cities right across the country.‚ÄùRepresenting a multi-million pound investment into the locality by the retailer, the state-of-the-art building measures nearly , square feet and stands at eight metres high. Lidl has  stores across Northern Ireland, bringing the number of employees to . Boasting a brand new architectural design and spacious layout incorporating a bigger warehouse, wider aisles, as well as improved staff and customer facilities, the state-of-the-art building represents the future of Lidl stores in Northern Ireland. title: lorry loads of support for charity
story: The Bronte Streak House and Grill Banbridge hosted a coffee morning on Saturday to launch the CLIC Sargent Logo on the McCallister Lorries. McCallister Haulage is a family run business and operates throughout NI, ROI and UK specialising in Road haulage, contractors, with warehousing and shipping facilities. Jane McCallister, Sarah Lennon and Suzanne Seffen with their children Hugh, Charlotte, Harry, Molly, Leah and Genevieve #Edward Byrne Photography INBL-EBOperator Jonathan McCallister said that he felt that he had to do something to help the charity after he spoke to a lady encouraging him to make a monthly donation to the CLIC Sargent. Jonathan said: ‚ÄúI have two small children who are my world and I don‚Äôt know what I would doanything was to happen to them.‚ÄúThe lady in BQ Newry told me about the work of CLIC Sargent Northern Ireland. ‚ÄúI really did not know about the impact of Childhood cancer had on families and the distances familes in Northern Ireland have to travel to get to the Royal Hospital or City Hospital.‚ÄùFiona McCann, Fundraising Manager for CLIC Sargent said: ‚ÄúWe are so grateful of McCallister Transport to support CLIC Sargent and put our logos on their lorries.‚ÄúIt is such a great opportunity for advertising especially when they transport all over the UK.‚ÄùJonathan and his we Fiona had the chance to visit the CLIC Sargent‚Äôs newly opened ‚ÄòHome from Home‚Äô, Amy‚Äôs House, within walking distance fromthe City Hospital, Belfast, for young people aged -.A ‚ÄòHome from Home‚Äô offers free accommodation for families and patients to stay when cancer treatment is required at the City Hospital.CLIC Sargent also has a ‚ÄòHome from Home‚Äô opposite the Royal Hospital called Paul‚Äôs House, for families‚Äô of children aged ‚Äì.Families in Northern Ireland make an average round trip of  miles up to five times a week to access the cancer treatment needs. The ‚ÄòHome‚Äôs from Home‚Äô can make a huge dference to these families.Every week two children and young people in Northern Ireland are diagnosed with cancer. CLIC Sargent is the UK‚Äôs leading cancer charity for children and young people and their families. title: michael keeps on trucking with second book about ni lorry drivers
story: A Co Down man is determined to keep on trucking as he publishes his second book about le on the road for the Province#s lorry drivers.Michael Wallace, a -year-old design graduate from Annaclone, is a driver with his family‚Äôs business Wallace Bros Haulage.Some of the Finneys Bros trucks that feature in the bookHaving grown up around trucks, in the past two years he has put together two photo-focused books about the heavyweights of the highways. The second volume of ‚ÄòTrucks of Northern Ireland: Through The Lens‚Äô was launched at the recent Causeway Coast Truckfest.He said: ‚ÄúThe response to the first book was phenomenal and this was why I decided to bring out a second volume. With the rise in truck runs and shows in recent years interest in trucks throughout Northern Ireland has really grown.‚ÄúA lot of people got in touch after the first volume and I‚Äôve been able to use photographs from a lot more dferent photographers this time round which has helped so much to tell the story.‚ÄùHe added: ‚ÄúTrucking is like no other job and people often spend more time in the lorry than they do at home. Drivers make huge sacrices including being away from their families and missing many important events just to earn a living. A classic Woodside Brothers truck from the late s‚ÄúHowever, when you ask any lorry driver how they find the job most will say that they are living the dream. It gets into your blood and once you‚Äôre a trucker you‚Äôll always be one, nothing could ever replace it.‚ÄùOf the changes to trucks over the years he said: ‚ÄúMany of the older folk would recall having to be able to fix the trucks as well as driving them, you were a mechanic as well as a driver, but nowadays they have to be plugged in so the computer can tell you what‚Äôs wrong with them.‚ÄùProceeds of the book will be going towards the Cancer Fund for Children and the Kevin Bell Repatriation Trust, a charity to help bring people home who have died abroad.The book, priced ¬£, can be ordered via the Facebook page ‚ÄòNI Truck Book‚Äô.These could be the  messiest car interiors in the whole of the UK Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BANB | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BANB | Article Teaser"
